name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 19 April 2018.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before we start the plenary session, I would like to express, on behalf of this Parliament, the most heartfelt condolences to the families and victims of recent religious persecution and terrorist attacks. You don't stop the genocide of Christians. Following the murder of a priest in the Philippines, there was the assault on a Christian church in the Central African Republic yesterday, which caused at least 10 deaths. This Parliament says enough. We cannot resign ourselves to seeing people being shaved for the mere fact of professing their faith. We need to keep getting our voice heard. (Applause) Even with regard to the fight against terrorism, we certainly cannot let our guard down: the horrific massacres carried out by ISIS in Afghanistan and Boko Haram in Nigeria show this. On Monday in Kabul and Kandahar two vile terrorist attacks made over 25 victims, including 11 children. Among the dead also journalists and aid workers. In an attack on a mosque and market in Nigeria, Boko Haram killed more than 60 innocent people yesterday. That is why we need an increasingly strong Union on the international stage. We aim to fight terrorism and promote peace and stability. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I would like to inform you that today, in the diplomatic gallery, there is a delegation led by His Holiness Patriarch Philaret, Patriarch of Kiev and the whole of Ukraine. On behalf of the European Parliament, I would like to thank you, Holiness, for being here today; your presence is the bearer of a strong message in favour of dialogue and peace. (Applause) It is an honour to host you in the European Parliament.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I would like to inform the House that on Thursday I will sign, together with the President of the Council, an act approved in the framework of the ordinary legislative procedure in accordance with Rule 78 of Parliament's Rules of Procedure. The title of that act will be published in the Minutes of this sitting. *****

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, I would like to draw the attention of the House to the fact that the Basque Peace Process Group was established in 2006 in this Parliament to create an opportunity to promote peace in the Basque Country. I believe we’re going to see advances in that process very soon. I call on Parliament and the Commission to seize the historic opportunity to support the upcoming initiatives that are going to seek to build upon that peace process. The path to a just and lasting peace is without doubt paved with challenges, and reconciliation can be tough for all sides – building peace can be tough for all sides – so I would ask this Parliament to support a lasting peace in the Basque Country.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Please, however, when you ask for a point of order, to comply with the regulation.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Mr President, I only want to speak for a few seconds. Unfortunately, we find that, despite the warnings of the European Parliament in a resolution that we adopted almost unanimously in July 2017 to prevent Turkey from building a 64 km nuclear power plant from Cyprus, Turkey violated this resolution which we supported and we argued, did not listen to the suggestions of scientists and experts and basically goes to set up a nuclear power station in a seismic region, which threatens the entire region, which is protesting, but also the Mediterranean. We must call on Turkey to respect the European Parliament resolution and to stop work on building a nuclear power plant in the Mediterranean.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: As you know, the resolution was passed on to the Turkish authorities.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: Mr President, I would like to reply to the Irish honourable Member who spoke earlier to say simply that, here, this Parliament does not have to enter into any peace resolution or open any debate on peace in Spain. Because in Spain, ma'am, there has been no war. I already said it here once: my brother, Alberto Jimenez Becerril, and his wife were killed by ETA, as were 858 victims. None of the victims responded to these attacks, therefore, and those attacks were carried out by 90 per cent in democracy. There's nothing to sign. It is a document, ETA propaganda, to attract all the international attention that you are wanting to give you and we, who know who the terrorists are, are not going to allow it, because we are many more of us who are on the part of the victims.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The final draft agenda set by the Conference of Presidents pursuant to Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure at its meeting on Thursday 19 April 2018 was distributed. The following proposals for amendments were submitted: Wednesday The Group of the European People's Party asked to add as a third item on the agenda a statement by the Vice-President of Commission v High Representative on the situation in Venezuela. The debate is expected to end with a resolution, which will be put to a vote on Thursday.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (ES) Mr President, when this Parliament awarded the Sakharov Prize to the Venezuelan opposition, it took a very particular commitment to Venezuelan democracy. On 20 May, there will be false elections in Venezuela, and we must try to ensure that these elections do not occur. That is why our best help is to vote here for a resolution that says three things: first, that we will not recognize the result of false elections; secondly, that we urge the Maduro regime not to hold elections and dialogue with the opposition in order to build a democracy for all Venezuelans; and thirdly, that observers should not go international, and less of the European Union, to be complicit in what Maduro is trying to do with these elections. Today Maduro was elected in an election recognized by all. The Maduro after May 20 will be an even more illegitimate ruler than he is today. Let us remain committed to the Venezuelan opposition as the Sakharov Prize marks us.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: Mr President, we are against this proposal because it is inadequate, it is forced, and your only intention is to interfere with elections which they know your friends will not win because of failure to appear. The EPP Group only admits elections won by their friends. With the same National Electoral Council, he endorsed the elections of the Assembly because his friends had won. But with the same National Electoral Council they denounced the elections to the National Constituent Assembly because their colleagues had not even presented themselves. In no country in the world are elections invalidated because of voluntary failure to appear. The EPP Group seeks destabilization and interference; to achieve by international harassment what their friends did not achieve with street violence. Stop poisoning, stop contributing to chaos, help normal, convincing your opposition friends to dialogue and reach agreements.

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Mr President, the situation in Venezuela is very grave and serious, and that’s why it needs serious treatment. However, the EPP request is not in line with Rule 156, which says that, except in cases of urgency, a debate and a vote shall not be held on a text unless it has been made available to Members at least 24 hours earlier, which has not happened. Now you might say that maybe this is an emergency, but that there is going to be a vote in May was announced on 2 March. It’s two months since then, so I really do not see an emergency under this rule. The rule is there in order to allow all Groups to be able to have an opinion about the text, to make amendments and to be engaged. We should not leave it up to the big Groups or the President alone to change the rules however they want. We have the rules for a reason.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: Mr President, if democracy in Venezuela is so important, I do not understand that we stop fighting for it for procedural reasons. It cannot be that the procedure is more important than democracy. When the procedure is put ahead of democracy, it is an excuse for not supporting democracy. In any case, urgency does not need to be demonstrated: it is obvious, it is on the calendar. The elections are going to be on May 20. There is no other plenary in which we can speak. Either we speak now or there is no resolution anymore. I'd rather have a resolution, you might prefer there to be no resolution. There is an intermediate solution: let us have a debate and that what this House has already said in many resolutions will be expressed by an intervention by the President on behalf of everyone.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr González Pons, I understand that you are calling for a debate, with an agreement with Mrs Ska Keller, without a resolution and, after the debate, a statement by the President summarizing the text of the resolution voted for a long time in this House. Was this Mr. Gonzalez Pons's proposal?

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: Mr President, that is a consensus proposal. If that proposal is admitted, we can live with it. If not, we would like our proposal to be voted on.

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Mr President, I cannot really follow this, because in the previous resolutions it didn’t really say anything about the May resolutions. I totally understand the intention to have a resolution, but you should have announced it earlier. Again, it’s been two months, so if you are going to then declare any sort of declaration which was then only prepared by one Group or another, then that would not really be following any procedure either. We can have a debate, but a resolution is not possible under Rule 156.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Ms Keller, there is a proposal from Mr González Pons. The proposal is: a debate without resolution with a declaration of the President, in agreement with the last resolution approved by the European Parliament. Do you agree, or shall we vote?

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Mr President, you can of course always declare what is written in the resolution, but the resolutions so far are not saying anything about the elections in May. So that kind of contradicts each other, so we can also vote.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr González Pons, in order to have the debate with a resolution, calls for this to be a matter of fact an urgent debate, which is the only way to have the resolution. Mr Ska Keller says that otherwise, if you do not ask for urgency, you cannot, and I think Mr Ska Keller is right, have a resolution discussion. We must first vote on whether the plenary wants an urgent debate on this issue, then by resolution. If this doesn't pass then, let's move on to the debate without resolution. Let's open the vote to decide whether we have an urgent resolution debate on Venezuela's case. (Parliament welcomes the request)

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: Mr President, you are in breach of the Rules of Procedure, because for a resolution the Groups must have it in our language at least 24 hours before. They do not twist the law, as the People's Party in Spain does to hide its corruption. Don't twist the law.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Unless it's an emergency discussion. Hon. Couso Permuy, you are repeating what Mr Ska Keller has already said in a very clear and simple way. I gave Mr Ska Keller right with regard to the debate, but Mr González Pons asked for an urgent discussion. The emergency debate authorizes the resolution, and so it will be. The motions for resolutions must be tabled by 18.00 on Wednesday, the amendments to the motions for resolutions and the joint motions for resolutions on Wednesday 2 May at 20.00, the amendments to joint motions for resolutions on Wednesday 2 May at 21.00, requests for separate votes or for separate parties on Wednesday 2 May at 23.00. ***** The GUE Group asked to add, after the Council and Commission statements on persecutory crimes and protection of victims in the EU, statements by the Council and the Commission on Spain's application of the rules International on the definition of sexual violence in light of the recent “La Manada” case. I give the floor to Mr González Peñas to submit the request on behalf of the GUE Group.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (ES) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today many Spanish women feel more unprotected by the judicial institutions than a week ago when the Navarra Court delivered a delusional judgment in respect of a multiple rape case. A woman, an 18-year-old girl, is placed on a portal by five men who call themselves “La Manada”, is subjected to multiple rape and multiple harassment without her consent. And the sentence indicates that it is not sexual assault, that it is only abuse, because there is no violence, because there is no intimidation. It's an absolute barbarity. But the Istanbul Convention defines the concept of rape as any sexual act without consent. And only six European countries have adopted this definition of rape. We therefore find it absolutely essential, so that this social alarm does not extend beyond our country, not to be extended to other European countries, that we should please have this debate to call for recognition of the concept of violation, to urge the harmonisation of regulations in all Member States and that such a thing does not it happens again. (Applause)

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: Mr President, we share the outrage — as it cannot be otherwise — in all matters of zero tolerance against the violation of human rights which always involve assault and sexual violence. We would frame the debate on Member States' compliance with the Istanbul Convention, in no case in criticism of judicial decisions which, as you know, in a rule of law are independent. Judges are subject to the rule of law and with all guarantees and, according to our Constitution — as could not be otherwise — a judge cannot be prosecuted in the exercise of his or her judicial function. That is only for that reason the appeals, which are provided for in our Criminal Code, and this case is sub iudice with two other appeals: appeal to the Supreme Court and appeal to the High Court of Justice. Therefore, yes to debate, yes to consider future amendments in order to be able to comply with and go in line with the Istanbul Convention, but in no case should we question the judiciary from the legislature, because we would do a disadvantage of the trust that our justice system requires of citizens.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: We vote by roll call on the proposal of the GUE/NGL Group. (Parliament welcomes the request) Declarations by the Council and the Commission on Spain's application of international standards on the definition of sexual violence in the light of recent case “La Manada” are added to the agenda after statements by the Council and Commission on persecutory crimes and protection of victims in the EU. ***** The Greens/Alliance Group European Free asked to add to the agenda a Commission statement on the duties applied by the United States in the steel and aluminium sector and the European Union's response.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, dear colleagues, the US tariffs that might or not be put on the EU is a hot issue right now in the public debate all over Europe. But even so, even we as co-legislators are not at all informed about what the Commission is doing. Just today we had an in-camera meeting where some of our INTA colleagues were able to get some really interesting information about what’s going on, but we think that this information should be shared broader, with all of us but also publicly. The Commission might actually be trying also to get a mandate for a new trade negotiation with the US still this month. So if we as a European Parliament want to have a say on what’s inside the mandate – what the Commission should negotiate and what they shouldn’t negotiate – then we have to talk about that now, in this plenary session, and we can’t wait for the Strasbourg session, because by then the mandate will already be done. That’s why I’m asking you to agree to have a debate about this still in this mini-session, so that we as Parliament can have a say on this.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: – Mr President, in politics it’s too common that people speak faster than they think. On behalf of the EPP Group, I would therefore urge us not to take this debate with a Commission statement in this plenary session. We would be happy to debate this, of course – not that I necessarily think that we have very differing views on Trump’s illegal and protectionist steel tariffs – but it was announced yesterday, and we don’t even know the details of what was announced. Therefore, I think it’s a good thing to actually read and reflect before we speak. It’s not as if it’s now or never. We have another plenary in May, which means that we will have plenty of opportunity to get into the details and be able to send a joint and strong message from this House, but not before we know what was decided and announced in Washington.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: As far as I understand, Hon. Ska Keller always thinks before she talks. One may be for or against it, but I don't think he speaks without thinking. Let's move on to the roll call vote. (Parliament rejects the request) On Thursday, the following point was added to the vote: objection under Article 106: genetically modified sugar beet H7-1. Are there any objections? The change is approved. (The order of work is so fixed)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the Commission Decision on the post-2020 MFF package (2018/2594 (RSP)). I would like to thank Mr Juncker for agreeing to present the proposal on the new multiannual financial framework and on own resources in front of the plenary before the press. I thank him again, as I thank Commissioner Oettinger, for this gesture of sensitivity and respect towards Parliament. I think it is right that Parliament is always the natural place to announce such important proposals, given that the representatives of the citizens sit here. I would also like to thank all the political groups and Members for consenting to this change of time.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. — (FR) Mr President, thank you for having been able to organize today's meeting quickly. The Commission wanted to present its proposals first to Parliament and then to the press and not vice versa. Therefore, we first present them in front of you. Ladies and gentlemen, Madam President of the Council of Ministers, the Commission has just adopted this morning its proposals for the next multiannual financial framework. I will leave it to Commissioner Oettinger, who was the patient, inspired and tireless craftsman of this new budget architecture, to present it to you in detail, but I would like to highlight a few points. Any budget is important. The new budgetary framework is even more important than the one being implemented because it will determine the future of our Europe of 27 and, consequently, the future that we will leave for future generations. This is the debate we launched last year with the White Paper on the Future of Europe and a series of reflection papers, including on the future of the Union's finances. This is a debate in which this Parliament has fully participated, and I welcome our close cooperation on such a crucial subject. When we presented our white paper on March 1 last year, I told you that enormous challenges await us in a world that changes a little more every day at a dizzying speed. In Bratislava, and then in Rome, we chose 27 to master these developments, to seize them and to take advantage of the new opportunities, as they are promising. We have chosen a stable Europe, a more prosperous Europe, a more social Europe and a stronger Europe in the world. We have made the choice to move forward and to this choice must meet a modern, simplified and more flexible budget. In order to meet current and future challenges, the Union's policies and programmes must be provided with adequate budgetary resources. The level of the budget is not a neutral issue, it is directly linked to our ambition. The departure from the United Kingdom is a factor that must be taken into account. We have carried out a rigorous review of all policies and propose an ambitious but balanced budget that is just for all. Our proposal for a multiannual financial framework for the period 2021-2027 translates into an overall amount of EUR 1 279 billion. It is part of the European Development Fund, which until now has been an intergovernmental agreement and which, from now on, will be a Community agreement respecting the Community method. (Applause) By combining additional, limited but necessary contributions to finance new priorities and a number of targeted economies, the Commission proposes a financial framework equivalent to 1.1% of gross domestic product. That is a reasonable and responsible proposal. If we had not done this rigorous review of all policies, if we had simply responded to the many requests, if we had merely summed up the needs for new policies to the current unchanged policies, by maintaining discounts, other specific arrangements for certain Member States, if we had kept in the first place. The European Development Fund, if we had not taken into account the 15 billion resulting from the departure of the United Kingdom, we would have come to a proposal close to 2% of gross domestic product. This proposal would have been immediately rejected by all Member States and by a good part of you. We wanted to present a proposal that would be taken seriously and could provide a basis for future negotiations. Mr President, the budget we are proposing is a budget where every euro spent will bring a result higher than that of purely national expenditure, emphasizing the European added value of any expenditure. It is a budget which, in order to better respond to the challenges that will shape our future, establishes a virtuous intersection between existing modernised policies such as cohesion policy and common agricultural policy which remain important and new priorities, be it the protection of our borders, the digital economy, research, innovation or European defence. It is a budget that innovates in its structure so that our priorities become more visible and that innovates in simplifying its rules to create better synergies between the different programmes we propose to reduce from 58 to 37 with rules that will be easier to apply. It is a budget that innovates in the new flexibility it offers to enable us to implement our priorities and respond to unforeseen situations. It is a budget that also innovates with the establishment of budgetary instruments dedicated to our Economic and Monetary Union. Economic convergence and social convergence are central objectives of European cohesion policy, recently reinforced by our investment plan and which we propose to continue and consolidate further under the name Invest European Union. We are also presenting two new instruments that combine solidarity and responsibility. A reform support programme with a budget of €25 billion, including within Member States wishing to join the euro area and an investment stabilization function that can mobilise up to EUR 30 billion in order to maintain activity and employment in the event of major economic shocks. These two instruments go hand in hand. They reinforce the architecture of our Union, contribute to the resilience of our economies and societies and aim to prevent crises and better address them, where appropriate. We also propose strengthening the link between the European budget and respect for the rule of law. Respect for the rule of law is a prerequisite for sound financial management and effective implementation of the budget. That is why we are proposing a new mechanism to protect the budget from financial risks associated with widespread deficiencies in the rule of law. This mechanism is of general application, it does not target a priori individual Member States, but it is an important aspect of Europe's new fiscal architecture. Finally, Mr President, we are proposing a budget that innovates by giving equal importance both to the budgetary consequences of our policy choices and to the sources of funding the Community budget. One cannot act as if the problem of own resources does not arise. The Commission proposes, at a constant request from your Parliament, to introduce new own resources directly linked to European policies. Debates on our proposals are just beginning. They will take time and will be intense. Many of us, my dear Guy, in this Chamber, have witnessed these long budget nights of the European Council, so I know that the debates will be long, that we will need a lot of passion and determination. The conclusion before the European parliamentary election is in everyone's interest because, from day one, the continuity of our financing must be ensured. Our future cannot wait. Mr President, if I may, following the debate you had between you earlier, I would perhaps like to add a word on the exemption which the European Union enjoys with regard to tariffs on steel and aluminum, an exemption generously granted by the President of the United States. We have taken note of this decision, but I would like to reiterate here the appeal to make this exemption unconditional and permanent. We believe that United States measures cannot be justified on the basis of national security considerations. They do not have to be between allies and we therefore ask for their outright withdrawal. We will continue our negotiations with the United States, but we refuse to negotiate under threat. (Applause)

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. — Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen. In preparing this budget framework for seven years, we faced two fundamental problems: the gap that the UK's departure will create and new challenges that we should all see to solve in Europe, tasks that were not apparent in the dimension at the beginning of the current MFF: migration, Counter-terrorism, border control and management, defence research, defence industry, new social challenges. We tackle these two problems by saving, on the one hand, and by calling on the Member States to make slightly higher payments. Both — saving and investing a little more — seems right to us. Save: We have three groups of programs. The first ones remain the same, on the second we increase due to the new tasks, on the third we cut moderately. If you need to cut down, you can't get around the two biggest programs. This is why cohesion is around -7% and agrar around -5%, while direct payments are around -4%. And this is froze, so that an increase in the budget benefits year after year, while still allowing convergence to continue in favour of farmers in the new Member States. New tasks: We want to double Erasmus+ and — keyword Interrail — we want to finance this from this. I think that we are now inviting twice the number of young people to make Europe, the cultures, the languages that people get to know during their studies and training is an excellent offer. (Applause) Second: Research. In competition with Silicon Valley, Pentagon and its Chinese and Asian partners and competitors, we need to invest more in research and innovation. Some Member States do this themselves, but many are cutting in this area. We increase. Innovation, Research, Horizon, Europe and Digital — we want to increase our investment in Europe by 60% for the benefit of our competitiveness, for the benefit of our researchers. Third, security and defence. We see that there are reasons for flight and distress outside Europe that can lead to flight. That is why we will also develop our neighbourhood aid and our aid to the world by creating a separate chapter for this: Neighbourhood and the World, because we want to redesign our headings in general. The five headings we have are unreadable by the citizen: heading 1B, heading 3. From my previous task, I know that chapters in the budget must be readable — school, infrastructure, environment, social affairs, defence and internal security. We are increasing to seven headings, and in addition to the well-known topics, heading 1 Innovation and Digital, heading 4 Migration and Border Management, and heading 5 are new Security and Defense. And on the basis of PESCO and our defence programme, we now want not only to propose that the European Union invests EUR 500 million per year in defence research and then just a billion in defence industry, but we also want to increase the amount so that, at the end of this budgetary framework, together with can be allocated to our Member States two billion for defence industry, which is a multiple amount. Border Management: We need to know who is coming to us; we need to know the legal grounds. This has to do with the rule of law. But Bulgaria, Greece, Italy, Malta, Cyprus, perhaps Poland are very challenged or overwhelmed with this issue. It is in the interests of all Europe. We should create a basis for ensuring that internal border controls do not have to be continued in the long term — Austria/Germany, Hungary/Austria or Germany/Denmark. If we want to restore the free movement of people, goods and goods inside, the external borders must be controllable, our Member States need support, solidarity there. That is why — you will be amazed — we are proposing the expansion of Frontex in stages from 1 200 employees to 10 000 employees at the end of the MFF. I believe that this is a strong sign of European capacity for action, but also that Member States can then be asked to revive their internal border management measures piece by piece dismantle. We are reducing the number of programmes from 58 to 37 by bringing together to a little easier for citizens to explain which programmes are available to them. Single rule book, i.e. a common set of rules and simplification in general, are added in addition. We want to increase the LIFE programme and thus our climate and nature conservation activities by 50% and will thus make an effective contribution to ensuring that the Paris Agreement and the preservation of nature and the environment also receive a corresponding strengthened European offer, and with a percentage of 5.5% for climate change mainstreaming we are creating a complementary growing basis for this. My president mentioned the rule of law. It's about taxpayers' money. The point is that we must be sure that if there are disputes over European budget programmes, if there are ever litigation on the ground, then the independence of the courts — of third parties and the appeal of judges — must be without any danger, without any danger. And that is why a link between the rule of law and the refusal or allocation of funds from the European budget. It was important to them that new own funds are also available so that contributions from national budgets do not permanently exceed 70% or more of our total revenue. With various proposals before you, we want around 10% of our revenue to come from new own resources, some EUR 24 billion, including the proven emissions trading scheme, including corporation tax, but also completely new measures. We propose that an amount be transferred to the European budget along the resulting non-recyclable quantities of plastic. In this way, each Member State is free to decide how it intends to reduce the amount that it generates — through bids, prohibitions, national taxes. I believe that this is a very unbureaucratic and environmentally and future-oriented way. We believe that these new own resources will allow us to close the Brexit gap by 50% and will be able to fully fulfil the new challenges — migration, defence, security, Digital Europe — that the contribution from national budgets, if at all, does not really need to increase moderately. The integration of the European Development Fund strengthens the European Parliament's royal law. As a result, you will continue to be responsible for all programmes, tasks and expenditure on an equal footing with the Council. We come to the following result in the calculation — knowing what was written in your report, in the reports by your colleagues in Parliament: expectation: 1.3% of GNI. We know that we are between 1.0% and 1.03% in this MFF and we believe that, despite everything, realism is necessary. We can show you when it matters to the programmes: no programme is damaged, we are carrying out many new tasks, we are investing in the future of the European Union. Nevertheless, due to good economic development and a good growth forecast, we are coming to a GNI that will arrive at 1.114. 1.114, the development aid fund, which alone accounts for around 0.03%. In this way, the so-called net contributors should also be prepared to take this as a basis for deliberations, as a well-intentioned compromise proposal from the outset, this ambition — Parliament — on the one hand, and the willingness of the Member States to pay more. One final point: from the discussions of the last few days, I noticed that everything is being added together at national level: inflation, Brexit, new challenges, reduction of discounts and increased GDP. That's not possible. We do indeed have five elements responsible for the nominal increase of our annual budget. Inflation times seven, GDP growth times seven, Brexit is real, new challenges are in the interests of the Member States, but also real, and we are only abolishing the rebates in stages with a phasing-out that are reasonable for everyone. But it has to be clear: if you compare a 2014 budget with a 2027 budget — there are worlds in between! Increases in construction costs for roads, railways, environmental measures, gas pipelines, salaries for researchers and employees. This means that those who are anchored in national fiscal policy will compare 2018 to 2019 — 2%, 3% on top. Who like us for seven years in the Eye has compared, or even fourteen years, resulting in greater increases with seven times 1.8% inflation, seven times 2% gross value increase, etc. This automatically leads to nominally higher contributions, which are initially surprising, but are completely explainable and still meet the requirement of economy. One final point: from many discussions with farmers, mayors, regional governments, infrastructure ministers and farmers, I would like to ask that the sooner we advise, the more intensive, the sooner we decide, the better. The lesson from the current MFF must be: 15 December 2013 — adoption was far too late. If 2014 was a lost year — it was a lost year — 2021 should not be another lost year. That is why I would like to ask this Parliament to make the MFF your priority until Easter next year. And I would like to ask the President, who I greet and who is very constructive: make this a priority in the Council in spring, summer, autumn and winter. Then Europe can show that — the British are leaving — good governance under 27 is evidence of an effective European democracy, with very contradictory interests. (Applause)

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. — (FR) Mr President, I am always very sensitive when your generosity leads you to give me the floor again, but I have taken a stand on the issues which are the responsibility of the United States — I have said two or three sentences. Let us say that we do not like to negotiate under duress and I would like to stay there but thank you again for being so nice to give me the floor again.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, Mr President, President of the Commission, dear Günther Oettinger, ladies and gentlemen. Today is an important day, it's about money, it's about the future of our continent. First of all, as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, it is important to point out that the money we have implemented so far for taxpayers was a good money, that the EU budget is a good budget. Prosperity on the continent is benefitting in research, at the EFSI, initiated by our President, Jean-Claude Juncker. Solidarity benefits — cohesion policy is the cornerstone of the whole of Europe. It benefits our farmers, our farmers, who are at a difficult level of globalisation, and those who stand by the side, and it will benefit the future of our young generation with Erasmus. The existing budget, the money we are investing through Europe, is well-invested money, and that is why we in the Group of the European People's Party want to defend it first of all. The cuts that are being proposed will now be discussed with those affected: with the farmers, with the mayors, with the representatives on the ground and also with the research community. We will discuss it and then we will also decide how to deal with it, and no one should question Parliament's determination. We will have a very difficult tool in our hands when it comes to the Fund regulations — the disbursement arrangements for the funds — and we will of course see it as a common package: the MFF debate and the fund regulations. The second thing I want to address is the necessary self-criticism expressed by the Commission. Bureaucracy, the question of mismanagement, corruption and OLAF investigations must also be taken into account, and of course the question: will the money be spent correctly today from the priorities? We believe that the current proposals are heading in the right direction. They ensure clarity in the budget — especially with regard to discounts, and on other issues — for clarity in budget planning — we support this. And some of the people who are already saying today that he now wants to cut the proposal even further further, wants to make further incisions: I would, however, be in favour of butter being made on the fish on the Council side now, which will then also be presented: Where will be cut then? The abstract debate that we have in part from the Member States that numbers are being discussed must come to an end. Anyone who wants Europe to continue to lose funds should now also tell who he wants to take them away. The third idea I want to make, ladies and gentlemen, is that Europe and the world are changing fundamentally. That is why the new priorities that are indicated are necessary and correct. I am pleased that security and border management are two separate blocks in this new budgetary structure, and we are thus confirming people that we are becoming concrete: drone technology, cyber war — all the issues are only possible if we work together against them — 10 000 front-excreators. A strong signal that we are putting it on research: my group decided a few days ago that we want to double the funds for cancer, because we, as a continent, should perhaps be the first continent that aims to really defeat cancer with the scientific expertise we have on this continent can. All great future projects for which it is worthwhile to argue. And youth: Erasmus and — it is permissible for me to mention this once again — the budget plans for Interrail are clear commitments that this European Commission is also serious for the young generation. Thank you for that! Last but not least, we in the Group of the European People's Party want to conclude before the European elections. We do not want a policy of dispute, but we want a policy of solution. Europe needs stability, and we have envisaged that there can be revision clauses, so that the next Parliament may also want to make changes if it deems it necessary. That is why it is clear with respect to the next legislature that we will close before 2019 can. It is a moderate but ambitious proposal: it preserves good, it strengthens new things. The Group of the European People's Party considers this proposal to be a good starting point for the next discussions.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: on behold of the S&D Group. — Mr President, President Juncker, Commissioner, yes, we welcome the fact that you go directly to this House of legislation, to the European Parliament, to the House of the People. Yes, we appreciate that. And we also appreciate what you give a time-frame which allows for substantial negotiations, with the intention to finalise within this mandate. Both are good. but now we have to check on the content? Do you yourself regard this as being the Commission of the last chance? I remember that very well. Is this really the concept and the proposal of the Commission of the last chance for the forthcoming decade? Are you really sure that this already is an answer to the challenges of today and tomorrow? Are you really sure that within your proposal we will find the vision for the young people of Europe for tomorrow? Have you really already incorporated the vision into this concept that we urgently need to inspire our young people — to get the people of Europe — back to Europe, to protect them and show them where we want to go? I have my doubts. Ladies and gentlemen, we in the Socialist Group have become accustomed to the fact that we only want to talk about economy when we talk about work, that we only want to talk about work when we talk about the environment, and that we only talk about the environment when we also talk about the social world. Yes, people with low incomes also need clean energy. Even people, where family income is small, do not want to live on arterial roads, where their children choke on the car exhaust fumes. We need holistic designs. In our joint work in the European Union, we have a starting point for this. We have the Lisbon Strategy, we have the Europe 2020 strategy. Why do we not take a bold step further and say overall as the Commission, as we say in our Socialist Group: our strategy will be the United Nations strategy to be guided by sustainability goals, holistic approaches and to ensure that the UN 2030 Sustainability goals will be our concrete policy for the next few years. That's what I'm missing, as well as the corresponding volume we need. Yes, approaches are there, they have the merit of talking about the new tasks, but compared to the proposal — ladies and gentlemen, including those of the Group of the European People's Party — this House, agreed with great agreement, is missing 220 billion, spread over seven years. It is about solidarity, it is about the fight against growing inequality, and that is why I miss an important revenue item here too: the question of why Internet giants should not actually pay taxes for the European budget. It won't be! This Europe will not be if workers are the only ones paying taxes directly, because this will be deducted from them from the pay strip if the small, medium-sized companies are the honest taxpayers, but we do not get the Big Digitals to pay. Help to change that, it's about the people who need our confidence and orientation. It is about the craftsman in Spain, about the student in Warsaw, it is about the young people all over our countries who are waiting to find good work in a good world.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Mr President, Mr Oettinger. I am very grateful for the many issues that you have presented in the détail, and I have to say that they largely meet with my assessments when it comes to the priorities of future work, in the direction of our EU. I am very grateful to you for being courageous and for cutting this Parliament's proposals. You know, I would have wished you even more courage, because we need to cut even more. It can't be that it looks like we're talking abstractly about sums coming from somewhere! That is taxpayers' money, and it needs to be done first. This does not fall from the sky! Mr President Juncker, you rightly said and pointed out that you published a White Paper and it was announced that we would be discussing this White Paper in the EU. I wonder where this discussion took place! Not in Germany at least — at least not enough. We have not clarified: what are the future tasks of the EU now, what are we dealing with, what can we really do better at EU level than at Member State level? There's plenty we can do better. At the moment, however, we are also doing a lot of things that we cannot do better at EU level, including, for example, agricultural support. Yes, I will mention this area quite specifically, Mr Weber, because agricultural support is precisely the point where theory and practice differ. We say that we want to give the developing countries good chances to be able to trade fairly with the EU, while at the same time we are currently using agricultural policy to close off the EU markets. That's nonsensical! This is absolutely absurd that, on the one hand, we in Africa do not give farmers the opportunity to act fairly and spend enormous sums of money in Europe, which will go somewhere through redistribution, causing an enormous amount of bureaucracy. We should start there, and I think that would only be an essential point where we can make the EU better than it is now. That is why I believe that it is not good if we give the impression that if only the EU budget is large enough, then we will also have a good EU that can help anywhere. This won't work, we will disappoint people's expectations — it can't be any different. Instead, we should start where we are really good at something, and we leave the other things to the Member States.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I don’t know if this is my third or fourth Multiannual Financial Framework. I think for Jean—Claude Juncker, it is his fifth or sixth. Let us be honest: as I said a few times to Commissioner Oettinger, it will be business as usual in this MFF. It can still be business as usual because this proposal has to go to the Council and it is there that it is business as usual: trying to get the maximum amount of money from the budget without paying a lot into that budget. Personally, I think that this MFF is a break with the past. It’s not a revolution, but it’s a break with the past on four elements. The first is that we had two decades of MFFs and budgets being reduced and, for the first time, we are going up again. We went down to 1% and we are going up to 1.14%. It’s not a revolution, but it’s on the right track.  The second is the priorities. For the first time, I see serious cuts where they are necessary and new money where it is necessary: innovation, research, Erasmus. Border management will increase a lot, to a total of EUR 34 billion over the seven—year period. I see a third break with the past: finally, new own resources – a battle that started 10 years ago. The Council has refused to introduce them every time, but now we are going from 70% to 60% GNI contributions and own resources are going up. I think there have been good proposals on carbon taxation, plastics, corporate tax, and there is Mr Bullmann’s proposal that you can take with you. Lastly, I think the fourth break with the past is the conditionality in the budget – respect for the rule of law. We have to be very clear about this, Commissioner. It is also very simple, colleagues. If a government of a Member State of the European Union wants to apply and to respect European values, they do not need European money to do that. That’s the reality that we need to include in this budget. European money, in my opinion, should be used to lift up our national economies, to lift up our citizens and not be given or be granted to Mr Orban’s family or to finance one or more new football stadiums in his constituency. That is not a reason for spending the money.  Finally, I think that we are taking a huge step forward and my request to you is to help us to take the last step forward. That is in the power of Parliament. We always receive beautiful speeches here from the Heads of State and Government. Tomorrow we will have another one from my Prime Minister, and we will have another within a few weeks. They all talk about the virtue of European democracy, but in reality this is the only parliament worldwide which has no say about its income. We only have a say about expenditure. That has to change now. In my opinion, Mr Commissioner, there will be no green light from this Parliament for whatever deal you make with the Council if there is no principle agreement with the Council that gives full responsibility for expenditure and income to the Council and to Parliament. Mr Juncker, we count on your support because the Council will be stubborn on this issue – we know that. They think, ‘it is all money and we decide on it’. No, it is more and more money from companies and citizens, and it’s our own resources. Who represents the companies and the citizens? We, the European Parliament, represent them. I count on your full support to help us to obtain that responsibility and then to get the green light for this more ambitious MFF. (Applause)

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, deciding where the money should go for the next years is where we, as EU institutions, are setting our priorities. There can be a lot of Council talks, there can be a lot of speeches all around, but if we don’t put money into it, then it’s not going to happen. And that’s why we also need to have a reality check here. Do we really mean what we say, and do we really mean what we sign? Because everyone wants to be on the photo at the Paris climate change agreement, everyone wanted to be on it when it was signed, but whether we save the planet for ourselves and for future generations, that’s not decided by selfies. It’s decided by who is doing what, and when. And the budget of the EU – our budget – must show that there is a clear commitment to saving this planet. So I am happy to see that more money will be put into climate-related issues, but if we’re ending up at 25%, that’s certainly a step in the right direction, but it’s a very small step. We should actually be at 50% spending on climate-change-related issues. And what is true for climate change is certainly also true for the development goals. There also we all signed and we all proclaimed, and we all claimed to agree that we need to do something to remove the reasons for why people have to flee their homes. But that means working against poverty worldwide, and if we don’t spend at least 0.7% of our GNI on sustainable development, following very clear criteria, then we’re failing the global community. And we are also betraying our own pious Sunday speeches. What kind of future do we want to see for the European Union? That is where the money should go – to social policies, youth programmes, research, and also farming that is good for people and the planet. And all this money needs to be spent well. Too much is being diverted, misused, and even contributes right now to fraud and to corruption in Member States. EU citizens need to know that every euro spent has an added value and delivers results. I think this is one of the biggest tasks that this budget has to do – making sure that it helps the rule of law, without taking citizens hostage for their governments’ behaviour and without creating a rift between any geographical parts of Europe. The EU should rather support local groups and initiatives that promote European values directly, and if governments don’t comply with basic rule-of-law standards, then the money going to those Member States should be managed by the Commission itself so that it will benefit the communities and municipalities, but not some individuals, indeed, that are filling their pockets. All this money has to come from somewhere, and we are very happy that the Commission is proposing to establish new forms of own resources. We very much agree with your ideas for that: a common corporate tax base, emission trading system benefiting the EU budget, and a plastic tax. (Of course we would also have more ideas for that). And with that proposal, the EU would finally have more own income, independently of the whims of the Member States, and those revenue sources would be contributing to something good: fairer taxes, less plastic pollution and less climate change. We are very much ready to discuss your proposals. We will look into the details and we are ready to work together with you and finally, together, drag Europe into the century of the fruit bat.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Choimisinéir, cé go bhfuilim an-bhuartha faoin treo ina bhfuil buiséad an chéad seacht mbliana eile ag dul, cuirim fáilte roimh an mhéadú caiteachais ar thaighde, oideachas agus traenáil trí na cláracha Horizon agus Eramus +. Ach caithfidh mé a rá ag an am céanna, tá sé scannalach go bhfuil an Coimisiún den tuairim gur chóir an oiread san infheistíocht a dhéanamh chun saghas Fortress Europe agus na teorainneacha a neartú ach go háirithe ag am a bhfuil cláracha traidisiúnta á ghearradh. Ná dearmad gur ceann de bhunphrionsabal an Aontais seo ná chun síocháin agus cobhsaíocht a neartú. Cén saghas teachtaireacht atá á seoladh agat leis seo, a Choimisinéir? Feicim go bhfuilir ag iarraidh cúrsaí míleata a chur chun cinn. An é seo an saghas oidhreacht a bhfuil tusa sásta leis fanacht anseo i gcomhair seacht mbliana eile i do dhiadh? Ag am go ndeirtear linn go bhfuil feabhas ag teacht ar an ngeilleagar, geilleagar a chaithfidh mé rá nach mbraitheann gach duine san Eoraip, tá an Coimisiún ag moladh ciorraithe maidir le CAP agus na polasaithe comhtháthaithe. Níl sé seo maith go leor.  Maidir le ciorruithe ar an bpolasaí comhtháthaithe, tá an Coimisiún ag glaoch ar dhlúthpháirtíocht sna Ballstáit chun buiséad AE a ardú. Ach, ag an am ceánna, tá siad ag moladh laghdú a dhéanamh ar an airgead den mheicníocht is tábhachtaí atá againn. An mheicníocht a thugann cúnamh do tíortha go bhfuil géar gá acu le hinfheistíocht chun an gheilleagar a fhás. Táim glan i gcoinne aon ghearradh ar CAP agus cursaí iascaireachta agus níl aon amhras ach go gcaithfear athchoiriú a dhéanamh ar CAP.  Mar a sheasann sé faoi láthair, tá sé i bhfabhar na feirmeoirí saibhre agus gnó talamhaíochta, agus idir an dá linn, feicimid feirmeoirí agus pobail bheaga tuaithe ag fulaingt. Gan dabht, le Breatimeacht ag cur isteach ar an earnáil seo faoi láthair, gan trácht ar an todhchaí. Tá sé chun i bhfad níos mó damáiste a dhéanamh do na hearnálacha seo sa todhchaí agus, mar sin, ní féidir linn leanúint síos an bóthar seo ag déanamh ciorraithe mar sar i bhfad ní bheadh pobal tuaithe againn ná pobal cósta ach oiread.  Ní leor é chomh maith 5% de mhéadú ar chúrsaí timpeallachta. Feicimid go bhfuil an domhan i gcruachás agus tá dualgas agus freagracht orainne sa tigh seo aire a thabhairt don aeráid agus don timpeallacht ionas go mbeidh domhan éigin ann do na glúine atá amach romhainn. Tá deis againn anois, a Choimisinéir, léarscáil uaillmhianach a sholáthar, leárscáil atá bunaithe ar Eoraip shóisialta, Eoraip ina bhfuil síocháin, comhionannas agus daonlathas mar fhís lárnach. Agus caithfimid a bheith cróga agus dul i ngleic leis na dúshláin, ach ag an am céanna, caithfimid díriú ar bhóthar na síochána agus infheistíocht réadúil a dhéanamh, agus sin infheistíocht shóisialta. Tá súil agam go dtabharfaidh tú aghaidh ar sin ar fad inniu, a Choimisinéir. Go raibh maith agat.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the Commission has chosen with this financial plan to live in dreamland, to pretend that its second largest net contributor is not leaving. But the hard fact is that 65 million people – one in seven of the entire EU population – is about to wave goodbye. Instead of cutting back accordingly, the Commission wishes to increase spending and is looking for a settlement of way over one trillion euros, financed by taxpayers from the remaining Member States, and in effect, that means a handful of major net contributor nations. Mr Juncker could have chosen table d’hôte. Instead, he has chosen à la carte, though his team says it is determined to offer a menu with prices, and I saw a quote earlier this week of EUR 150 billion for a full EU border management system. At those prices, I’d stick to the soupe du jour if I were you. It all puts one in mind of the Cole Porter song from High Society: ‘Who wants to be a millionaire?’ Only we must update for inflation: who wants to be a trillionaire? So who wants to be a trillionaire and have flashy flunkies everywhere? I hope Mr Selmayr is listening to this. Who wants an army at his call and to force one currency on all? Who wants to dish out all the orders and to take charge of everybody’s borders? Well, Mr President, I don’t, and the British public doesn’t. We just want to take back control of our own country, and that’s what we are going to do.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this proposal you have put forward today shows once again that the European Union is far from the demands of its citizens and I do not think there is a be surprised — looking at what has been written — if today support for the European Union project is at an all-time low among European citizens. This proposal lacks realism. Once again, where, with elections, European citizens demand the return of many competences at national level, the Commission — despite the exit of the United Kingdom — imposes and calls for an increase the multiannual financial framework. The citizens will always pay, both through higher national taxes, or through what you call “own resources”, which is nothing but additional taxes; because multinationals will overturn, as happened for roaming, these costs on the end consumers. Another note, Mr Juncker: You and Commissioner Oettinger have said that certain points of this proposal are not intended to punish individuals or certain Member States. Well, to see these proposals specifically, it seems that the reduction of appropriations on cohesion policy and linking some Funds to compliance with the rule of law are aimed at punishing some Member State, especially in Eastern Europe, which in recent years has not aligned itself with the central vision of the Union. Punishing those who don't align, Mr. Juncker, is typical of dictatorships, and from those who believe the defender of the principles of democracy you expect much more. Another point is that of the “security and defence” item, which concerns a considerable marchetta to the new pro-European hero Macron. The last point concerns something that is very close to the public's heart: administrative expenses. In your proposal, administrative expenditure will increase by 15 billion euros. Is this the example we want to give to the citizens of Europe?

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: “Mr President, dear Mr Juncker, I really liked the way you said about America, and I quote, that 'we will not succede to blackmail. ' You know, Mr Juncker, we Hungarians are the same with regard to this European Union. We will not succession to blackmail, whatever terrorizes us, we will protect our country from mass migration. Now they want to take our catch-up money, but, dear Mr Juncker, believe me that the whole world, the whole of Europe, all the voters are increasingly beginning to see that the truth is on our side. They agree with us, they want to defend their country, and we will be role models for him, and notice that by 2019, after the '19 European Parliament elections, the political composition of the entire European Parliament will be transformed and the victory over mass migration defending their country forces of rejection.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: — Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Commissioner, I would firstly like to underline the work the Commission has done in seeking to bring together, balance, competitiveness and territorial cohesion and social cohesion. The budget must have an aspect of competitiveness, but it must never forget internal solidarity too. This is a proposal which corresponds to a good basis for working, it is a good starting point for negotiations where unanimity is required in the Council and a favourable opinion from the European Parliament. It has positive points: the strengthening of Erasmus+, the increase and the funding for Interrail, the priority for youth, the strengthening of research and innovation, economic and monetary union and the possibility of a fund to combat symmetrical to asymmetrical shocks, a programme for reforms, strengthening security, support for migration, the simplification that is advocated and an end to the rebates too. But there are also points where we consider it necessary to go further. It is important that cohesion policy is not reduced and that the common agricultural policy also remains in the current envelope. And I ask the Member States whether they are willing to cut their national budgets, whether they are willing to cut the amounts they receive under cohesion policy and under the common agricultural policy, because cohesion policy is also essential for investment in the European Union.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, this is a big moment for Europeans to be ambitious in imagining their future and also in imagining new solutions to finance the future. This means that, if we know that our future will be reshaped by the digital revolution and the energy transition, we need to be bold on the transition towards aligning our budget but also on the way to finance this budget. That’s why we welcome the fact that the Commission is putting ideas on own resources on the table. This is part of the solution, but we would also like to have digital tax included in these own resources. And then we have the way the challenges are being faced. Of course, we need to cope with the challenges of migration, defence and development; we need to multiply Erasmus; we need to strengthen innovation and the way we proceed with research. But at the end of the day, what really matters in order to keep unity among Europeans is to have a strong commitment with cohesion and convergence and to overcome the divergences which have been part of our history in recent years. So that’s why – and this is a message not only for Commission but also the Council – we in the Parliament will fight for cohesion not to be sacrificed. We in Parliament will fight for the eurozone to include also clear instruments to overcome divergences. And we are still not there. So we consider that the main test will be sure that the promise of the social pillar will be delivered everywhere in the European Union.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: - Gentlemen President! Commissioner! From the data presented here, it appears that the Commission has decided to fill the UK's contribution hole on such an indirect route: on the one hand, a slight increase in the burden on individual Member States, on the other hand, restrictions on the two most important policies: cohesion and common agricultural policy. I would just like to point out — because I understand that now so called net payers, and so those who deposit more than they receive, will probably defend against these proposals — I would like to remind you that really net payers are just a bill item, because in fact, a larger part measures from regional policy go to their economies. Mr Oettinger knows that, of every euro paid by Germany, 80 euro cents goes into the German economy, so hopefully these payers can be persuaded. I would call for further flexibility of the budget, that is, the elimination of the rebates (I know this is announced, but the Commission seems to have decided to spread this over years), as well as the end of the reimbursement of unused funds. That would meaningfully improve budget flexibility. Well, finally, I want to draw attention to the need to equalize the direct subsidies. Despite this reduction in the CAP, I hope that, in the context of the next framework, this will finally happen.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, it is essentially as co-rapporteur, together with Mr Lewandowski, of the own resources report, that I want to speak and really welcome the Commission's proposal to introduce new own resources to fuel the budget of the European Union. You are right to do so because Article 311 of the Treaty has been abused for a long time, and you are right to do so because you know very well that the approval of the European Parliament of the multiannual financial framework is unshakable tied to the adoption of new own resources. That being the case, and subject of course to further examination, I want to take note positively of several elements in the area of own resources. First, the fact that you propose a package, which allows to ensure a sufficient flow for budget revenues and avoid disproportionate burdens in case of misdistribution of income. Secondly, the fact that the new own resources proposed by the Commission are in line with what was proposed by the Monti report and in our report — Mr Lewandowski and myself — which allows me to believe, Mr President, Commissioner, that you will act totally in concert with the European Parliament in this area. Finally, I would like to welcome the fact that, according to what we have been told, new own resources are also instruments for the achievement of two strategic objectives of the Union. Firstly, the assurance of a better functioning of the internal market, which is the case in particular by the own resources provided for in the framework of the consolidated corporate tax base and secondly, the protection of the environment and the fight against global warming, which is the case, with the two proposals you have mentioned. But I regret — like other speakers — that there is no provision for taxation of digital companies that have developed an unacceptable tax avoidance strategy.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, Mr Juncker, Mr Oettinger, I have listened to you very carefully, and taking into account that we do not yet know the full details – and the devil usually is in the detail – my first assessment is a mixed one. On the one hand, I see some really strong points in your proposal, especially on the revenue side, in which you propose to reduce Member States’ direct contributions down to 48% through new own resources, some of them with a clear ecological imprint, or by getting rid of rebates, which, of course, is a positive proposal. However, I am concerned about other points related to volume. If it is true, as you have just said, Mr Juncker, that budgetary resources are linked to political priorities, then I must say that my ambition is greater than yours and possibly my political priorities are different from yours. If we are to cope with the huge challenges that we are facing, then, to my mind, we need more resources than the ones that you are proposing. My Group is ready to defend Parliament’s call for 1.3% of GDP.  When it comes to priorities, may I remind you of what Article 2 of the Paris Agreement says: ‘Making financial flows consistent with a pathway towards low greenhouse gas emissions and climate-resilient development’. Europe needs finally to make that a priority. We need to deliver much more, and in order to do so we need a budget in which climate-related spending reaches a much higher level than what you are proposing.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: — Mr President, Mr Juncker, Commissioner Oettinger, the financial framework you are presenting is a political document of fundamental importance. And we had been prepared so much for the worst, that we should now be satisfied with a proposal which is not very dynamic and we still have to wait for the plane that will come from the European Council. But what I want to tell you is that the reality of your proposal is the weakening of all policies where we do not have exclusive and shared competences. I am thinking of the weakening of the budget for cohesion policy, the weakening of the budget for fishermen, the weakening of the budget for agriculture and this to finance new policies which are not obligations for the European Union: security policy, defence policy and fortress Europe. We therefore sacrifice traditional policies to finance bonds that are not those of the European Union.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Mr President, today the plenary met two hours earlier at the ultrastime, because Mr Juncker and Mr Oettinger wished to do so. In this regard, I would like to point out that if this were a powerful Parliament, it would of course be the President of the Commission would have to follow Parliament and not vice versa Parliament would have to respond to the Commission President's dates. This is unbelievable! I wonder: what is this understanding of democracy? This is the representative office. Then to the budget: the Commission is presenting a trillion budget, which is expected to rise by as much as 18 percent from EUR 1,087 billion to EUR 1,279 billion. This is a slap in the face of the citizens. The EU is losing the second largest net contributor with the UK. But you're asking taxpayers to take a few extra bills. This is monstrous. You obviously lost touch with reality. I can't think of anything, but really nothing to explain or justify this budget increase. You will receive the receipt for your unallocated trillion budget from citizens and taxpayers in the 2019 European elections. Voters will turn to us Eurosceptics, our true federalists, fighters against centralism and incapacitation in droves. You will experience it!

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Let me be only allowed to briefly explain: our program is quite rich. For us, it was most important that the Commission, including Mr Juncker, is present, and as to set the hour, it falls within the framework of the so-called good cooperation.

name: André ELISSEN
text: Mr President, today the European Commission presented its long-awaited financial implementation of the new multiannual budget. To our astonishment, the budget rises by no less than EUR 300 billion, which should have been reduced by around EUR 100 billion because of Brexit alone. Under the guise of simplification, the Netherlands is also being burdened by the annual rebate of 1 billion euros! This budget means that the Netherlands now has to pay EUR 10 billion a year instead of the current EUR 7 billion. The Dutch taxpayer will pay EUR 1000 per year to the EU if it is up to the Commission. I propose to cut back and cut expenditure by, among other things, stopping subsidies, aid programmes and financial support to countries such as Turkey, cutting generous salaries and allowances from civil servants and parliamentarians and, of course, stopping the relocation circus to Strasbourg. This is the time to take place and adjust the budget considerably downwards. The Netherlands has to pay not more, but less, much less to the failed EU project.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: - Mr President! Commissioner! I wanted to stress first and foremost that the European Commission's proposal indicates that we are facing a change in approach. We are facing a change not only in the names of individual budget chapters, but with a change in approach to budget construction. And that's what I wanted to note, because Parliament will examine very carefully the proposals on what this change is and what the concept of a change of work in the budget is about. For us, it is so important that this construction must be compelling, but also safe. If it is based in some part on own income, it assumes that the Member States will agree to their own income and, if they do not agree, even more cuts will need to be made. As one of the rapporteurs, the Co-Rapporteur, I wanted to say clearly to the Commissioner that Parliament is not abandoning its proposal 1,3. Parliament based its proposal on analyses. Parliament expects to maintain cohesion policy and agriculture. And Parliament expects that there will be a real debate with the governments of the Member States, what they want to cut down and what justification they have for doing so. I wanted to say that Parliament welcomes the proposal from the European Commission with interest, we are ready to work very hard, but we are not abandoning our proposal because we believe that we need arguments to change our mind. We will be looking at it very carefully, but we hope the end result will be a little better.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, this budget debate is the most political debate we can have. And, of course, with the explanations of your proposal, I think that politics has remained in the background, because, once again, mathematics has prevailed. What is the account of this proposal? What kind of Europe is the Commission proposing for the future? What objectives are being achieved and how will this financial framework help to achieve them? Are the sustainable development goals included in this proposal? Is the social pillar included in this proposal? We haven't been able to hear anything about your explanations. Mr Juncker said that the level of the budget must be tied to the level of ambitions, and of course, as seen what is seen, I think they have missed a great opportunity to make a courageous proposal. The European project has been staggering for ten years, and this was the time to tell people that the European Union is here once again, that the European Union is alive, that solidarity and the fight against inequalities are going to be our priorities for the future and that we are going to make a contribution to the banking sector, multinationals and the digital sector so that these proposals can be financed, so that new priorities can be financed and so that we do not have to cut either the common agricultural policy or cohesion policy, which is where solidarity is really demonstrated. You know the position of the European Parliament. We have approved it before the Commission makes its proposal. And now all we are asking is — especially the Council — that we sit down and negotiate, discuss all these proposals and seek agreement before the next elections so that we can move forward this financial framework.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Mr President, what should the European budget look like? If there is one constant in the plans of the European Parliament and the European Commission, it is that the Member States will be allowed to pay more to fill the gap in Brexit and to meet a number of new challenges. Should we invest more in security and in limiting migration and research and development? Yeah, of course we have to. But what we want to ask is that we finally carry out the exercise very seriously. The European Commission now wants Belgium to pay at least EUR 600 million each year, perhaps a lot more. On top of that, the European Union also wants to introduce new European taxes. And who's allowed to pay? Always the same! And what countries get? The same countries are always the same, and that is not right. The European Union is more than just a cash machine. There are also countries that can now provide better growth rates, and they too should contribute more. Anyone who wants new European priorities has the right to demand that. But it must also dare to remove outdated projects. And I still miss that guts, that ambition, unfortunately.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to pay tribute to your proposal because your task was truly a squared circle. I think that, at first glance, you have fulfilled the Council's expectations, in particular to limit the volume of this budget, given the fact that the European Development Fund is now included in it. We welcome the effort to clarify the budget, the emphasis on research and the elimination of discounts that must be disappeared — as a result of Brexit — but we challenge its spread over five years and the inadequacy of direct payments from the common agricultural policy and the Erasmus+ envelope, which would only be doubled instead of tripled as the asks Parliament. While the recent national elections give credit to candidates who criticise the functioning of the European Union, it is vital to recall that the budget must first and foremost meet the expectations of European citizens. In addition to actions to promote social and territorial cohesion, employment and training, youth employability, in particular, economic policy coordination, strengthening the governance of the euro area, there is an urgent need to assess the effectiveness of certain sovereignty prerogatives exercised at the national level and recognise the urgency of assuming them now at European level, be it defence and security, the fight against terrorism, the digital economy, cyberattacks, climate protection, fraud and tax havens. It is in these areas that it is easy to demonstrate what European added value could be. An exhilarating task awaits us. Parliament is ready. It intends to defend the positions it approved on 14 March and recalls that the post-2020 financial framework is inseparable from the institution of new own resources. We look forward to the negotiating mandate of the Council and look forward to reaching a draft multiannual financial framework as soon as possible, giving Europe the power it needs to convince Europeans that it is preparing for their future and that it protects them from the threats posed to them by globalisation.

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger. The main message today from this debate is that we need a larger budget in the EU because we have to tackle greater challenges. That is the crucial point, and that is why this proposal made by the Commission — Mr Juncker and Mr Oettinger — is characterised by the European spirit, and this is extremely important in this situation, when Europe is being called into question by many. We are also dealing with a paradigm shift in some areas, and this cannot be underestimated because it shows political courage. On the revenue side in particular, we are answering the question of where the money for the European budget comes from. This must come from new taxes — environmental taxes, the plastic tax — is, of course, a green concept, but I would like to urge the digital tax. I found it very sad, Mr Oettinger, that you could not mention this today. I hope that will change. We need to adequately tax digital monopolies, because we can also make an appropriate social, educational and cultural policy in the Member States and in the EU if these monopolies contribute to the budget. That is why it is so important that you have made suggestions to save cautiously, become more efficient and greener in some areas. Not enough — we Greens, of course, want to have 50 percent environmental spending. However, they have set great accents in research, education, culture, youth and empowerment — thank you for that. I hope that we will be able to convince the Council that we are talking about a stronger European Union, and I am ready to do everything possible to ensure that this budget is a success.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, within this budget, which has recently come to us and which we will then analyse carefully, there are considerable cuts on important items for different citizens of the European Union, starting with the common agricultural policy: we are talking about a 5% cut.
