This cut should be thoroughly considered and not done in a linear way, because it could affect small farmers and we do not want this to happen, as we have to support small farmers and find ways to eliminate inefficiency and contributions to the big ones. As for cohesion, you have a 7% cut here too. We have to consider well how to cut, here too, because there are areas of the eurozone — above all we talk about Southern Italy, the periphery — that still need this aid to get equal with the rest of Europe and we must not, here too, have linear cuts but to weigh well the cuts that you make. Finally, on the support of structural reforms: this “microbudget” has been given birth, I would call it, of 25 billion, because over 7 years divided by all the Member States there are very few resources, which seem to be almost a prize pool made available to those who apply unpopular reforms. I do not want the reforms to be rewarded to be those reforms aimed at the devaluation of wages and aimed at implementing reforms that go, for example, towards a decrease in pensions and all that is unpopular and that citizens don't want. So we must not create these prize pools in exchange for reforms, we have to create real clearing instruments or the European Union will not resist at the next crisis and will be scrapped, in fact, by this inability to solve asymmetric and symmetrical shocks.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: — I have listened with interest to the oral presentation of the budget, which is not easy, because the budget is numbers. Previously we started with a PowerPoint presentation at the Budget Committee, which is obviously possible. But on the income side of the budget we have some good news, though, and some ambiguities. There has been an attempt to reform the income side of the budget, which has been as fiercely criticised as it has been stable for many years. New own resources are emerging, there is a foreshadowing of a substantial simplification of this income page and that is all in keeping with the spirit and letter of the European Parliament's resolution. I think the circumstances are more favourable this time than when I personally dealt with the budget, because there is no longer a climate of austerity, there is no climate of belt-tightening in Europe, there is a willingness to increase contributions. And the Brexit, which is normally a problem for us, here is a certain window of opportunity. The first signals from the Austrian Presidency are also positive. All this is intended to reduce the GNI contribution to the European budget. The basket itself is no surprise to us, but I inaccurately understand how Commissioner Oettinger wants to collect 24 billion euros representing 10% of the budget — this account does not add up to me. In any case, it certainly is a foreshadowing of reform that Parliament will favour, so we begin.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger, ladies and gentlemen. First of all, thank you, Mr Weber, as the chairman of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) for this refreshing and encouraging pro-European speech, which I particularly like to hear from a CSU politician. My request — I am also pleased to follow the debate — if you leave the Chamber, would be to call your new Prime Minister, because I am a little concerned about the first opinion from Munich on this MFF, and if you can convince Mr Söder of your point of view, I would be much more comfortable. Ladies and gentlemen, in this debate I hear a great deal about agricultural policy expenditure and many calls that savings could still be made. I am aware of many complaints from farmers that the administrative and bureaucracy expenses that they have to drive are high in the reporting obligations. I have not yet heard any complaints from farmers that they are swimming in the money and do not know where to put it. So if we cross out agricultural policy, then we will go to the income base of farmers. Then, of course, you can ask here in this Chamber to renationalise this — and I have already heard that — only then it will not get cheaper. Whether we have the money we need to support agricultural policy to make it greener on the side — which means you can't earn a lot of money — either — whether you take that from the European budget or take it from the national budget, does not matter to taxpayers in the end. After all, we should not pretend that only European agricultural policy is expensive — and the national policy would also be expensive. When we talk about revenue, it has been worked out: yes, taxes have been drafted, but they are withdrawn, and it only takes money in this EU to afford the right advisors to stop paying taxes. I believe that we should be able to tax the digital companies that have been avoidance so far.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, thank you for this proposal, even though the X that you have mentioned so many times lately - over 1.1 - is at its lowest level. We expected it may be higher than 1. With this 1.11 you only cover the loss of the budget created by the UK's departure, but you don't cover very many policies that you have proposed in the budget, very good indeed. In my opinion, the Member States, the European Council, if they have proposed these policies and want to support them, must also come up with sources of funding. You also included in this figure the Development Fund, which until now was out of budget, and you even included the new own resources - a very good proposal - but I think that these own resources could be used to cover new policies, without reducing those that are now and which proved effective. There are a few things I do not understand yet, but we need to see all the details, of course. I do not understand why, for example, transport policy must be at a lower level than six years ago and, at the same time, the Social Fund - I am in favour of the Social Fund - should be much higher than five years ago. All figures, all structural investment funds are low, lower than five years ago, which is again a question I hope to have answered. I will, like my colleagues, support Parliament's initial proposal in the negotiations to follow.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: – Mr President, Mr Commissioner, you said in your introduction that you had two problems that you had to face when you were looking to the MFF, that is on one hand Brexit, which we all know about, and on the other hand, the new challenges. And that sort of wraps up the proposal that the Commission is making today. Yes, we do appreciate initiatives to get a bigger budget, although it’s small. We do appreciate the own resources, although we would have wanted to have more ambitious own resources. But what is crucial for us is that, if you asked me what are the two main challenges that Europe should face and handle and tackle, I would say they are the growing inequalities in the world and in Europe, and climate change. We’ve made an agreement in the framework of the United Nations and it’s called SDGs, and in your introduction, Mr Commissioner, neither you or Juncker mentioned the STGs, and I think it’s so extremely important that we use this budget to make sure that all the money that we spend in all these sectors is used to come up with good results on the sustainable development goals. I think those are the real priorities of this European Union.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: — Mr President, this next multiannual financial framework will decide the destiny of our continent because, behind the question of means, there is of course the burning question of the purpose: what Europe do we want for tomorrow? It is no surprise, I want a strong Europe capable of helping Member States meet the real challenges of the 21st century. By setting up an ambitious budget, Europe must therefore show that it is ready to act and that it is able to manage its future despite the loss of profits caused by the departure of the United Kingdom. In negotiations with the Council, we will ensure that efforts on research, innovation and digital transformation are maintained on the continent. The effort seems enormous, but that is much the least that Europe can do so as not to miss the technological revolution in progress. With regard to defence policy, the Commission's proposal gives real impetus and a vision for the future to the European Defence Fund, both for research and for the development of common capacities. This is essential if we are to set up large competitive European projects and increase our strategic autonomy. As for space policy, it will continue to develop in order to provide the Union with independent access to space and to develop large-scale the use of spatial data for the benefit of our fellow citizens and businesses. Finally, more Erasmus+ and support to our farmers. We will need own resources, obviously, and perhaps an increase in our national contributions. Let us not be mistaken, behind the accounts of apothecary, it is the story that is written. If the end justifies the means, then the time has come for the Member States to assume their responsibilities: which Europe do they want to build?

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I think you assume that I am very disappointed and I want to tell you that, unfortunately, the Commission proposal is not the result of work with Parliament, but the result of a submission to the Member States. If we appreciate your offensive proposal on own resources, on the other hand, on expenditure, which is our full competence, there is one observation to be made: we are not in the same position. Not only does your 1.1% ceiling in 27 countries lead us to unprecedented reductions in the history of the Union, but your political priorities do not always cross ours. However, Parliament voted clearly in March: maintaining the CAP and cohesion, ensuring the energy and ecological transition, stimulating EU flagship policies by tripling Erasmus+, doubling the youth guarantee and the biodiversity programme, and increasing research and innovation. It would also have been necessary to realize the social pillar, respect the Paris agreements, and build around the goals of sustainable development. Tomorrow morning we will have the opportunity to go deeper, but I would like to raise the question of the rule of law. This Parliament had made a proposal, and you reduced it to the budgetary adjustment variable. We proposed sanctions that penalize those responsible, you are unfairly targeting all citizens. Commissioner, you have returned your copy. It is now up to the Council to work with Parliament to reach an agreement. But this Parliament, be sure, will not give up its commitments because a budget does not lie and everyone, on their ambitions, will have to assume its responsibilities.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: — This proposal for a multiannual financial framework is specific. First, it's mostly about the post-Brexit financial gap. Second there were new needs and new challenges. So does the philosophy of austerity, or does the formula as proportionate cuts seem appropriate? In the first situation of such deteriorating farmers' incomes, which amount to around 50% of those of other professional groups, half of which are Union measures. Secondly the lack of young farmers and the aging of the countryside. Thirdly, the lack of income and market stabilization. Fourth the nuisance of labor in agriculture. Fifth of lower standard of living, inferior technical infrastructure, social, inferior access to services in rural areas. So I dare argue that it is unfair to reduce CAP funds for 2021-2027 in such a situation. This will bring many farms in Europe into a difficult situation. Even more because, in the current term, the appropriations for the Common Agricultural Policy were reduced by 11.5%, that is more than €40 billion. In such a situation, I request that the expenditure on the Common Agricultural Policy be maintained at the level to date.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger, I note that, financially speaking, cohesion remains the cornerstone laid down in the EU Treaty. It is a unique system that they look at all over the world, namely how Europe stimulates on the one hand, and on the other that, through the internal market, is more or less recovering. It's 7% going off. That is actually too much, but nonetheless, the Member States also pay for and everything that goes off in Europe will have to cofinance more. So it will be. It's not a free lunch. Already in the current system, there is a very strong condition of where the money is to go and how it should be spent. Structural reforms are necessary — you write about that too. There is now the value test. How we are going to do this now is a major issue. I am very curious whether the Council, the other party alongside Parliament with which it is consulting, will come up with clear proposals. If that is the case, then I think we are taking a step forward, because it is indeed a question of not constantly pumping money into regions, but also seeing the effects of that.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: – Mr President, first: the good news. In the Commission proposal there are a lot of things where this Parliament has already been clearly heard. To me the message is obvious: after Brexit we need more Europe, not less Europe. We need strong commitment in the areas where we can be stronger together. That’s why the Commission proposal on the next MFF is a good starting point for real and, I hope, lively discussions also in the Member States, because now it’s up to the Member States to come up with answers to some of their own causes. With growing challenges in defence, security and migration and with ample evidence that investing in European infrastructure and digital economy pays off handsomely, how on earth would you be able to finance the Union with anything less than what the Commission is today proposing? When it comes to money, this is the minimum. Now we have to deliver by next spring.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that this is an interesting, important starting point, even if we are pointing out some critical aspects. We strongly defend the need for our agriculture — which is strategic, which is fundamental to the European system — not to be affected so strongly and therefore I believe that there should be a revision, a retelling compared to the percentage that was earmarked. We cannot allow our small and medium-sized farmers to suffer even more than the criticality of the situation. But we are also strongly defending the cohesion policy, aimed at countering the disparity between territories, those territories that are penalised, but also and above all the disadvantaged islands to which we owe a compensation. I believe that there is a need to review an assessment of the criteria: the territories that suffer must be helped and so it must also be for agriculture. Well on the web tax; well on innovation, research and technology; well on small and medium business.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: - Mr President! Commissioner! I have a different view than what many people here have accounted for. I think the Commission has made the right priorities, but too little priorities and too few priorities. Too much, in choosing two different expenses, you have made the mistake of choosing both. Then you do not get the scope of priorities that you have to make in each Member State, every household and every other context. You have not adjusted the expenditure to the revenue available. It's not small increases it's about. For many Member States, achieving the Stability Pact rules on stable finances will be more difficult. For others, it will mean that the scope for reform — in terms of better health care, better school, stronger defense, stronger rule of law — will be made more difficult. Finally, I would like to say one thing in terms of this with our own resources: let us remember that it is the resources of the citizens, the money of the citizens. We now need budgetary reform that prioritises all the new things that modern Europe must be able to face.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. It really is the square of the circle to draw up the budget for the post-2020 budget here: close the funding gap through Brexit, fund new tasks and continue old tasks. The Commission has put forward a bold, interesting proposal. I look forward to further discussions here in this House. I would like to address two issues: firstly, it is important to me that we continue to give comprehensive support to our agriculture, preferably without any cuts. Our farmers provide us with healthy food, our farmers maintain our cultural landscape. I am open to providing more targeted, targeted support. We want to support small farms, family farms, medium-sized farms, active farmers — that is something you can talk about. But I hope that we do not have to make any cuts. Secondly, it is right to staffing up the external border management. I believe that 10 000 employees for Frontex are the right signal — full support. And, of course, if there is money left, or even for research, innovation, education programmes such as Erasmus — every cent is well spent, that should be our priorities.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr President! First of all, I would like to thank Commissioner Oettinger very warmly. He did a good job there. Brexit may have lost 12 to 14 billion — that is 12 percent. And if I now see that the Commission's support for agriculture is to be cut by 7 per cent in cohesion and 5 per cent in agriculture, then this is already a right step in the right direction, and we can see that the Commission's support for agriculture is there in any case. The support of small and medium-sized enterprises is also particularly important to me, because the figures pay 80% of taxes and account for 50% of gross national product. From this point of view, I also see the COSME programme as one of the pillars of European policy, because only tax revenue can we force the other areas accordingly. The integration of the European Development Fund into the European budget also gives us new opportunities — particularly with regard to the Sustainable Development Goals 2, 6 and 7, in which we really want to invest, because this is the future for Europe to ensure stable structures in these countries.

name: Christian EHLER
text: — Mr Oettinger! I believe the House expressly welcomes the bold move. We should put it down: one hundred billion euros for research and innovation. This is no contradiction to agriculture or cohesion, but a vision for the future. 60% of Europeans, who are now ten years old, will work in a profession that does not exist today. We are facing epochal changes, and research and the vision that research and development and innovation will give this generation work and perspective is an important vision for Europe. It's also a matter of freedom. We live in a world of global competition in research, but research is not free in China, in America there is an American president for whom his own administration must try to hide the climate protection data from him. Europe is holding up the Enlightenment torch. Research and innovation is also a matter of participation, because only enlightened citizens and the access of all to research, development, future prospects have something to do with participation, with democracy, with participation, with decision-making perspectives, so that it is not reserved for elites, not politicians, to provide this information on have. In this respect, I would ask you to formulate boldly, and I look to the advice: do not be so timid, do not say 'research' on Sunday and 'save' on Monday!

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Mr President, President Juncker said: budgets are not accounting exercises, but are about priorities and ambition. That's it. The problem with this budget is the error in the analysis of priorities and the lack of ambition. New needs must be met without neglecting the old ones. That requires resources. Solidarity requires a strong cohesion policy for European regions to gain competitiveness and, of course, to maintain funding for common agriculture and fisheries policies, which are so important in my region, Galicia. But if Europe wants to win the future, it cannot turn its back on digitisation, innovation, the fight against climate change, energy transition, the new social pillar. We therefore need European countries to scratch their pockets, we need more resources and, if not, we can again be frustrating the hopes of European citizenship.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the multiannual financial framework, which Mr Juncker has presented to us, leads to a significant reduction in agricultural funds. This is a major blow to farmers in the South of Europe. It means a blow to small farmers. It also means a blow to the fishermen themselves. All this at a stage of liberalisation of international trade in the primary sector, leading to the impoverishment of farmers in the south. The funds must therefore be maintained or increased in order to support the primary sector, particularly in the countries which are currently suffering the consequences. Moreover, the sums allocated to cohesion are not sufficient. We must support the island regions, the Aegean regions and the Aegean islands that receive huge numbers of refugees and illegal immigrants. And there we should have extra funds instead of giving them to Turkey, which violates human rights and illegally keeps two Greek soldiers in prisons.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, today we are witnessing the proposal for the Multiannual Financial Framework after 2020. Pandora's box of accounting arrangements that cut cohesion has been opened. I come from a country, Galicia, which knows very well what cohesion is for good and evil. Instead of talking about youth mobility policies, they could talk about policies to combat youth unemployment and emigration. Instead of talking about defence policies, they could talk about policies to combat the export of arms and arms to other states. We don't want these accounting arrangements, Commissioner. We want cohesion policies for our producers, for our fishermen, for our farmers, and the possibility of the European Parliament being silent is a chance, because the reality is that we are going to fight. This hypothesis, which opens Pandora's box of money, speaks of austerity. These are policies that do not speak with the face of a woman, with the face of a man, with the face of a precarious worker, with the face of people without a job or with undecent jobs.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Mr President, the multiannual financial framework will shape the future of the European Union and we consider it wrong, from the Commission's proposal, to continue the very neoliberal austerity policies which have led to the dissolution of the social state, the closure of thousands of small and medium-sized enterprises, the deindustrialization of the South, the creation of an army of the unemployed and the impoverishment of significant sections of the peoples. With amendments that we have tabled, we are calling for a boost to the real economy, for social and regional cohesion to be promoted, for vulnerable groups to be supported, for concrete measures to combat poverty and for the creation of quality new jobs with priority among young people. We consider the proposal to increase investment in defence and security and further militarisation of the Union to be particularly negative. As the European United Left, we insist that money should not be invested in the war industry and in the creation of a fortress Europe. Instead, the European Union should respect the declared principles. He must invest in peace. Develop a refugee policy of solidarity and ensure conditions of prosperity and quality of life for the peoples of Europe.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: — Mr President, I will have comments from a European, a European from the Europe of Nations, and also comments in support of President Trump. After the Second World War, the Havana Peace Charter meant that we should balance our external accounts, that the surpluses of some would make the deficits of others, as Mrs Lagarde says. And if some countries have too strong surpluses, they are, in a way, war against countries with strong deficits. Let us look at our figures, we have vis-à-vis the United States: Germany 68 billion surplus; we have a surplus of 150 billion compared to the United States while we have a deficit of 120 billion with China. So here's what you should do, if you were real Europeans: tax China for new revenue and do what it takes to ensure that we balance our trade with the United States. President Trump is right!

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, our position was very clear from an early age on the pressure exerted on cohesion policy. There could and should not be any reduction that would hurt cohesion policy. Commissioner, I understand the new challenges of a Union of 27, strengthening the gaze and priority given to security, border protection, research, support for young people with Erasmus+ and Interrail. But there are two negative notes: when we talk about support for businesses, small and medium-sized enterprises, the digital economy, we lack a line of funding for tourism which is not mentioned. And I could only regret this announced cut for cohesion policy. We are talking about a cut of about 5% for cohesion policy and the CAP and it is crucial to maintain the outermost regions in cohesion policy, because we are talking about solidarity with outermost regions that have increased costs in mobility, education, health, and we need this solidarity of the Union that is not poured into this document.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the forthcoming multiannual financial framework, as Mr Juncker has said, is of paramount importance for the future of the European Union. After a phase of stasis, it will serve to understand our real ambitions in relation to a dream which, if not advances, by virtue of things is destined to back. The current MFF has proved insufficient to meet the Union's real political needs, as a result of unforeseen crises and new challenges in the fields of investment, migration and refugees, youth employment, security, agriculture and the environment. Well, the prediction of new and more own resources, and I share the new availability identified for the issue of immigration, for security and defence, for innovation, for LIFE programmes and Erasmus+, but I struggle to understand the proposed cuts for cohesion policies and the CAP. True, Europe has so many challenges to face, but cuts to agriculture and cohesion policy are completely unacceptable.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen. We have listened with great interest to your arguments, priorities and also your criticism, and the fact that, in addition to our President Jean-Claude Juncker, our two colleagues, Mr Crețu and Hogan were consistently present as the representatives of the two largest budget programmes, is also a clear sign of our respect for your priorities and our willingness to: to further develop our proposal. This is a first serve, not less, no more. The proposal that has been presented to you has received 28 votes in the Commission. It was decided unanimously by all the Commissioners. I do not believe that unanimity would ever be attainable in this House. We have a wide range from disappointingly low to tremendously high. But the same group, where it was said 'tremendously high', called for no cuts in cohesion, and certainly not on Agrar. We're doing everything we can. But please, let's always see the whole thing, each for himself, let's look at the whole picture. There are friends of the CAP, friends of cohesion, maybe we should also start friends of Horizon for Mr. Ehler, there are friends of Donald Trump. I am a friend of Europe, and I know one thing: if the British, with 65 million inhabitants, go as the second strongest European economy — the second largest so-called net contributor — this is a change, and you cannot pretend that everything remains as it is. More specifically, cohesion: of course, Mrs Crețu has fought for an increase. But we will invest nominally for regions, municipalities and infrastructure over the next seven years — nominally — as in the current MFF, just not a euro in the UK, but for 27. With low inflation in the EU-27, we will use the same amount as in the EU-28. I would not have believed that this would be achievable. Cohesion continues to be a priority of 30% of a modernised budget, which also has new tasks. Agrar: My request: Let's see the whole thing. I am very close to rural areas and agriculture, but I tell you that I always have to defend from the media, in public, with taxpayers, and many others that there is agricultural support at all. Let us not fall ourselves: 5% is a very reasonable amount of reduction, if you know that the second largest net contributor goes. You can't expect a wealthy uncle to leave or die, and the gifts under the Christmas tree will remain the same number and the same size. Let's always look at the whole thing and stay realistic. The subject of digital tax has been mentioned several times. To be clear, our proposal is on the Council's table. We are discussing G20, OECD. Only: lending money now is not yet ready for budget, and as Commissioner for the Budget, I attach great importance to clarity, truth and budgetary maturity. Because if I were to set ten billion, times 77 billion, or even an ascending 100 billion, and the whole thing bursts or was just as much a vision that threatens to become an illusion as the financial transaction tax, then we would have a problem. We need revenue proposals based on legislation or on probability. That is why I say to you, Mr Bullmann and other Members: the sooner progress can be made in the Council and Parliament in the next few weeks — and my colleague Moscovici is fighting for this — the sooner would be for the European finance ministers — Olaf Scholz and colleagues — to agree to this and then to allow the money to be included in the European cash register is coming. Sufficient time will then be given until the beginning of next year for a supplementary proposal from the Commission to support digital taxable revenue to this draft budget. You will have me on board from the first day that the budget probability and maturity is enough. This is not a rejection, no neutrality. We want this, but first the communication of this proposal, then the progress in the Council, and then the amount will be set on top of our MFF proposal presented today. Defence: We do not want to spend more on defense, we want to invest better and thus save. If 27 Member States invest individually — as we know — it will be much more expensive than if you invest in the Procurement, industry and research invests together. That is why the amounts we want to set are not a contribution to the arms industry, but a contribution to taxpayers and efficiency. Because we know that for a dollar the Americans get a multiple of what a Greek, a German, a Maltese, a Spaniard, a Frenchman, an Irishman gets with his defence investments. We're saving money. It is the opposite of austerity to set European standards efficiently, make European tenders, and thus achieve discounts and economies of scale that are possible with other countries — the US and others. Turkey aid is largely frozen. What you pay for is human dignity for refugees in Turkey — shelter, cold, heat, food, clothing, education. We now need to adopt a further tranche of three billion — hopefully these days — so that teachers teaching 300 000 children can get a new employment contract for September and a perspective for children and basic education in these refugee camps. That's why your post is not displayed in truth. It is not about palaces in Ankara, not about an airport in Istanbul, it is about the human dignity of 1.2 million people fleeing — from Iraq, Afghanistan or Syria. And that is why I believe this is a Christian view of humanity that must also be important to us outside Europe. (Heckling) And whoever says “nonsense” — all right. Only “nonsense” is not an argument. (Heckling) Give my regards to Donald Trump. I think your contribution was pure nonsense. (Applause) We have been questioned by Mr Lewandowski. It is expected to be 10 to 12% of revenues over the course of the period. But since some own funds will only come over time — 2023 — the percentage amount is lower than it met your expectation. That is, my numbers have minted above the average of seven years. I note that you were not happy with the advance deadline. I am grateful for this flexibility. What is it about? The Commission held its meeting this morning on a regular basis, as always on Wednesday, and we wanted to inform the press. But I can't inform the press at 6 p.m. That would not do justice to the importance of our common theme. Perhaps we — the Commission, Parliament — should vote even more closely on important issues in the future, when we will meet directly to you, when you are ready to attend meetings, and when the press will still be our partner in a press conference before the press release. We have made the best of this today thanks to the willingness of the President and my President to bring the sitting forward to 1 p.m. There should not be a scubbous of colleagues who could not be present. All the more so thank you for the level of presence on your part at an unusual time. The budget is not ambitious enough. Let me tell you this: I need and have unanimity in the Commission. I do not need unanimity here, I am on a majority in this House. But I need unanimity — unanimity in the Council to which I am going tonight. And I can tell you that in recent days I have been identified by elected mandate holders in Member States from which you come, by parties to which you belong. That is why let us agree: I will speak to my German Chancellor, Mr Bullmann, Mr Olaf Scholz, Mrs Grossetête with the Republicans, that they support Mr Macron with an ambitious proposal in the Council. And then we come back. Then we'll see what realism means. I am well aware that although some countries do not call for a reduction in the CAP, it is unwilling and willing to make additional payments. The squaring of the circle rarely succeeds in politics. We should do everything we can to convince the Council now that at least our proposal is 1.114. If it gets more, we'll carry it with us. Let's fight cuts together. We would also have the best arguments in favour of our proposal, at least and perhaps for further investment and the reduction of cuts. In this sense, I am very grateful that Parliament sees this as a priority and — in the case of of all criticism — a broad majority sees our draft as the basis for fruitful, intensive, constructive consultation. If I have to leave now, apologies to colleagues in the CONT Committee, but I have to go to the press conference now. My colleague, Mrs Crețu, is ready today — thank you — to represent the PIF report, and therefore OLAF here in Parliament. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you again to Commissioner Oettinger for the answers given to the questions asked by Members. The discussion is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. — (PT) Yesterday the European Commission presented its proposal for a budget for the period 2021-2027. By pointing to a budget volume of 1.11% of European GNI, this proposal represents an increase compared with 1.03% of the previous document, but still far from the 1.3% proposed by the European Parliament. If, on the one hand, the Commission seeks to respond to needs arising from new phenomena that directly challenge the European Union's ability to act, whether in the area of economic competitiveness or in the area of citizens' security; on the other hand, Cohesion Policy is clearly sacrificed, with the as a result of the penalisation of the convergence effort between the richest and poorest regions. Placing the convergence objective in the background could lead to an accentuation of the two broad lines of geographical divide affecting Europe today: the North-South line and the West-East line. However, we are only at the beginning of a process which is predicted to be complex, prolonged and very controversial.

name: Ivo BELET
text: in writing. — (NL) We are at a crossroads with Europe: Brexit is coming and we have to choose which direction we want to go. The priorities in the new multiannual budget that the European Commission is putting on the table today are the right ones. Security, effective border control, innovation in sustainable energy connections and self-propelled cars, social protection: these are the areas where Europe can make a difference. People rightly expect Europe to protect them. The Commission wants to increase the EU Border and Coast Guard considerably, from 1 200 to 10 000 border guards. That's a good thing. These choices also require a clear budgetary translation. Explaining the need for additional resources and Eurosceptics are wrong when calling for less Europe is crucial for the future of this continent. That does not mean that we should not save money and keep a critical look at expenditure. It is good that there will be tighter control over the money that goes to the Member States. EU funds must become dependent on effective anti-corruption and respect for the rule of law. Member States remain obliged to fund programmes such as Erasmus+, but out of their own pocket. Countries that make a significant contribution to refugee reception will then receive additional support. These, too, are priorities that we support.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. — I would like to emphasise that we must focus on social affairs as much as possible in the new budget, because only in this way will we be able to contribute to tackling youth unemployment, fighting child poverty and income inequality as effectively as possible. The European Parliament is calling on the Commission and the Council to create a European Child Guarantee since 2014, which provides free health and childcare, education, decent accommodation and proper nutrition services for every child. The European Child Guarantee would be a means to ensure that all children have equal opportunities from an early age and no child would need often such vital things as safe homes, proper nutrition, guaranteed health and education. Europe and the Member States must realise that investing in children is the most important investment in the future of all of us. At the moment, we have different instruments, which, among other things, can also be used to reduce child poverty in the Member States, but they are not harmonised and mostly money from the funds is still allocated to other areas, and money for investments in children is simply no longer available. Thus, of course, the new budget must provide for funding to combat child poverty. Secondly, in order to effectively support young people who are looking for a job and want to gain a foothold in the labour market, the European Youth Guarantee budget (funding) needs to be increased from 2020. Only by implementing the Youth Guarantee in all Member States will we be able to ensure equal opportunities for all young people.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: in writing. — It will not be easy to achieve the balancing act between Brexit funding gaps and the need to fund new tasks. I welcome the plans for security, border management and the increase to 10 000 Frontex staff. The same applies to the increases in research and in Erasmus+. What is important to me is that the funds are used effectively and get there what they are intended for.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to share with you two comments on the multiannual financial perspective presented by the Commission today. In particular, I would like to draw the Commission's attention to paragraph 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, according to which the objective of cohesion policy is to reduce differences in development between regions and to alleviate economically underdeveloped regions. I would ask the Commission, as guardian of the treaties, not to lose sight of the clear objectives laid down by the treaty. The fundamental task of cohesion policy must be retained and not redirected resources to the most developed regions by introducing indicators independent of the level of development of the regions. Cohesion aid cannot be linked to conditionalities outside this policy. Furthermore, cohesion policy cannot have a criminal character. The rule of law, the threat of deprivation of resources, would be the Commission's instrument of pressure against national governments that do not agree with it. I welcome the Commission's proposal to increase the pre-accession funds, although I still do not consider it sufficient. If we take into account the diversity of reforms and their resources, especially in the case of the two leading candidates, Serbia and Montenegro, these figures cannot be considered sufficient. I believe that this is not in line with the objectives and targets set in the EU enlargement strategy. I would ask the Member States to take this into account in the negotiations and to increase the resources available to the candidate States. thanks

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing. - The European Commission has finally prepared its draft for EU funds after 2020. Once again, the key element of the position of the current Brussels governors has become clear: those who disagree with the Brussels migration plans do not, in the Commission's view, deserve to receive EU development funds. Our firm position is that the sources of catch-up are not charity, but are based on the development of EU Member States to those countries, including Hungarian citizens. There was also a sharp struggle in the negotiations on the last framework budget, and it will not be any different now. The Government of Hungary and the Hungarian MEPs of the People's Party must fight for the Hungarian citizens, and we will fight for these rights, and we will find enough allies to gain access to the EU's development resources. With Britain's exit, a 10 -15% gap has arisen in the EU budget. The European Commission's proposal seeks to fill this at the expense of regional development resources and the common agricultural policy. This is unacceptable, and we must protect the interests of Hungarian farmers and Hungarian businesses. The Hungarian government has repeatedly expressed its willingness to preserve the catch-up and agricultural resources for Hungary even at the cost of increasing its contributions. Under the Treaties of the Union, the framework budget requires unanimity, meaning that all Member States have equal votes, up to veto. The current Commission proposal ignored this fact.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — (PT) The Multiannual Financial Framework of the European Union assumes as strategic elements all the guidelines for deepening capitalist integration, responsible for the unequal, unfair and asymmetric development between the different countries in the European Union and which has accentuated the divergence of Portugal in this frame. Time and life have shown that European Union funds have never compensated (nor could they compensate for) the loss of sovereignty, the destruction of national production and the compromise of the country's development possibilities, which have resulted and result from the single market, the euro and the EU's common policies. This becomes more true at a time when a cut in funding is foreseen to be allocated to countries such as Portugal, which have been most affected by integration, in favour of increasing headings which, above all, benefit the largest beneficiaries of integration, the main powers of the EU and their groups. economic. Today's proposal for a Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027 presented by the European Commission thus creates the conditions for further accentuating the course of divergence that has characterised the EU, with the increase in inequalities and asymmetries between Member States and within each Member State. It also feeds the militaristic escalation and security drift into which the main European powers are launching.

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. – I see no ambition nor conviction in this MFF proposal, President Juncker. We need the European Commission to act with courage to make governments in the European Council live up to their responsibilities and find ways to substantially increase the Union’s own resources to finance all priorities and common policies, including new challenges in Security & Defence and, of course, Cohesion & Convergence policies, which are strategic for sustaining Euro and Union. Governments in Council must be urged to stop tax dumping and instead harmonise tax policies, so that they do not continue to enable tax evasion, money laundering and huge amounts syphoned into organised crime and even terrorist organisations - that is what’s happening with 50 billion euros per year lost in VAT fraud. VAT reform, as proposed by Commissioner Moscovici, can no longer be delayed by the Council and would increase own resources. The European Commission should forcefully push the Council to adopt CCCTB and a minimum corporate tax rate to ensure that corporations in the digital economy and polluting industries and financial transactions would PAY TAX to increase the Union’s own resources and national incomes. And so that SMEs and European citizens, who pay their taxes, will not be further overburdened.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. — President Juncker, the future of Europe after 2020 also depends on the future of EU finances. Yes, we need a more stable, stronger, more social Europe. The multiannual financial framework 2021-2029 presented today, unfortunately, has very many minuses which will affect European values: solidarity, cohesion, development of SMEs, agricultural policy, etc. Reducing the Cohesion Fund and the CAP Fund will increase regional disparities, fragility of SMEs and the disappearance of small agricultural businesses. The conditionality on the rule of law, which you want to introduce for granting European funds, in addition to violating the Treaty of Lisbon, will affect citizens and not political leaders, which is why I cannot agree with it. You have not presented us with a definition of the rule of law, but each state has its own constitution and democratic control institutions, so the introduction of this conditionality will feed Euroscepticism. I do not support the reduction of the Cohesion Fund and the Common Agricultural Policy, and I propose to increase the funds allocated to SMEs and the social pillar. We must ensure that the standard of living and access to education and health for all European citizens.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - We are at a very important moment in the parliamentary term. We will have to decide how much funding should be available from the EU budget for the period 2021 to 2027. On the one hand, our past decisions are highly decisive, since most of the cases are targeted across decades. On the other hand, because of the dynamic change in the environment, continuous revision is required: other aspects are heavier today than years before. I would like to speak in detail about one area, this is energy. I was pleased to see in the draft budget that the envelope for the development of energy infrastructure is not reduced. I welcome this, because in many Central and Eastern European countries the level of diversification is still low, competitive markets are not sufficiently developed and security of supply is insufficient. I believe it is important to have sufficient EU funds in the coming period to better address these regional problems.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: in writing. — The proposal by the European Commission for the multiannual financial framework is only the first step in the course of negotiations that will result in a new EU budget for 2021 to 2027. Part of the Commission's proposals, such as increasing funding for the period 2021 to 2027. initiatives dedicated to youth, infused with optimism. However, the planned reduction in cohesion policy funding and the Common Agricultural Policy is worrying. I therefore believe that these cuts should be corrected, inter alia, by increasing national contributions to 1.3 per cent of GNI. I also point out that, learned by the experience of the negotiations of the last MFF, we need to put special emphasis on the fact that the final version of the budget, on the one hand, allows us to effectively implement the priorities of the European Union and, on the other hand, come without unnecessary delays.

name: David McALLISTER
text: in writing. – In the interests of European citizens and businesses, the adoption and implementation of the European budget cannot suffer any delay. This means that the MFF should be finalised before the 2019 European elections. Commissioner Günther Oettinger can count on my support. Challenges such as security and migration require European leadership, which is reflected in the European budget with the creation of a European Defence Programme, additional backing for military mobility and the tripling of the funding allocated to border management and migration. The MFF must continue successful policies such as the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) and Cohesion Policy. Preparing for the future also means investing in our people and knowledge. I fully support the European Commission’s increased budget for Erasmus+, research and innovation. We need to give ourselves the means to realise our ambitions. It is not only about additional resources but using the ones we have more efficiently. ‘Brexit’ may impact the shape of the EU’s budget but it will not change its course nor its priorities. The MFF post-2020 will shape the next decade of our continent. It is our duty to make sure that each European benefits from it.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. — Mr President, Jean Claude Juncker presented his proposal for a budget for the European Union between 2021 and 2027. After full knowledge of this document, we will discuss its content in the European Parliament in detail and, of course, we will make suggestions for improving the draft. Mr Juncker claims that the presented budget gives a new boost to the European Union, which was reduced by Brexit to 27 Member States, focusing resources on the most important priorities and providing new tools to tackle Europe's challenges. I am sure that the European Parliament will be a partner in achieving the objectives set, and we believe that Member States can only succeed in a strong European Union. We will certainly have debates with the European Commissioner in many areas, but we can already know and welcome that the proposal would increase the budget of the European Union and the contribution of Member States in relation to their gross national incomes. More resources are needed to strengthen the European Union's engagement. It can also be assessed positively that the draft would simultaneously simplify and increase the system of own resources, involving new areas. Resources that are independent of the Member States clearly strengthen the independence of the Union. The European Commission's proposal would increase budget flexibility. In recent times, Europe has faced a number of challenges to which we have not been able to respond effectively with a budget set in stone, and we cannot afford to do so in the future.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. — The budget for 2021-2027 is the real request for ambitions for the future of the EU. Therefore, we must think ambitiously and act responsibly with taxpayers' funds. I welcome that the priorities and changes proposed today by the European Commission stand close to citizens - funding for youth programmes, employment, education, research. Increasing confidence in the EU institutions is linked to the strengthening of visible EU programmes - Erasmus+, the Youth Employment Initiative, SME funding programmes, the proposal for free Interrail travel for young people. The challenge is in how to achieve more with less after the exit of the second largest economy from the EU - the UK. I believe that we can optimise the means to achieve more in areas such as security and migration management, and yet maintain priorities such as cohesion policy. With regard to cohesion policy, it is important to view it not only as solidarity, but also as an investment in the future of the whole of Europe, as well as a guarantee of the proper functioning of the internal market. Let's not view this holistic policy as a dividing line between net donors and beneficiaries. We all know the painting is a lot more complex.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing. — The Commission presented the priorities for the next EU Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for 2021-2027. It is important to remember that the EU's role in ensuring security and stability in the world is growing and Brexit leaves a big hole in the budget. With this in mind, the next MFF provides for cost reduction and the creation of new revenue sources. The Commission proposes to set the 7-year MFF total of €1.1335 billion, equivalent to 1.11% of the total national income of the 27 EU member states. It is welcome that the next MFF foresees increased spending on EU security and defence issues, and also focuses more on supporting EU border security, which, thanks to increased funding, can manage the EU's external borders better and more efficiently. The EU budget for the future must be flexible enough to deal with unexpected issues, as was the refugee crisis during the previous programme period. Consequently, the Commission proposes to create a new EU reserve to deal with contingencies and increase flexibility between funding programmes.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. — The proposed Multiannual Budgetary Framework (MFF) for 2021-2027 takes into account the future of the EU with 27 Member States, covering a deficit of €12 to 14 billion euros per year due to UK exit, and the necessary increase in the expenditure side of the budget for other priority issues. Although an improved proposal has been presented in relation to the original projections, as a member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, I cannot be satisfied with the final proposal. Agriculture as an EU strategic policy should not have been affected by cuts. The EU agriculture sector today provides around 22 million permanent jobs, with food processing services and related retail securing around 44 million jobs together. Direct payments within the first pillar of the CAP support the revenues of around seven million EU farms. Nevertheless, the average income of farmers in the EU is lower than the average income in other economic sectors, making agriculture an unattractive interest. It is necessary to provide a sufficient budget for the Common Agricultural Policy, especially in the context of the increasing requirements placed before farmers in terms of environmental protection, climate targets and animal welfare. If we consider the benefits that farmers make for food production, biodiversity conservation, rural space survival, preservation of value and families, then it is clear that the CAP budget should not be reduced.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – There are contradictory factors within the Commission proposal for the Multiannual Financial Framework. Rightly, it features worries about the sizeable gap in EU budgetary resources that Brexit leaves behind. For this reason, the proposal diminishes crucial spending dedicated to cohesion, as well as agriculture. Nevertheless, proposals for new funding priorities appear. The Defence Fund features prominently here. Although defence is and should remain a national competence, this new fund could be soon eating from money other long established funding programmes. Moreover, bundling tax-based own resources in the form of a CCCTB within an agreement on the new MFF is dangerous. Many countries are clearly against an EU-level system in the field of corporate taxation. This proposal could lead either to conflict or stalemate. Concerning the criterion used when calculating the allocation of cohesion funds, unemployment, climate change and migration will now also be considered as relevant indicators. But the geographic position of regions, especially insularity, is not to be disregarded. Finally, agreeing on a final package by May 2019 will be difficult and democratically questionable. While preparatory work should now be finalised, MEPs elected in 2019 will, following the political campaign and elections, have the democratic mandate to vote the financial package.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. — The European Commission presented the draft Multiannual Financial Framework for the period 2021-2027 in the European Parliament. In the debates in the European Parliament, different views were expressed, some divergent, on this MFF. But there was a general consensus on the requirement that the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agree on the MFF until the European elections for the EP in May 2019. Only if this goal is respected, then the use of European funds can be prepared in good condition, from the first year of the new MFF, namely 2021. This will avoid the situation in the current MFF 2014-2020, when there have been great delays in preparing the legislation necessary for the implementation of the MFF.

name: Monika VANA
text: in writing. — We Greens are disappointed that the Commission's proposal has little focus on social issues and intends to tie only 25% of its expenditure to achieving climate targets. We Greens have demanded 50%, and the European Parliament at least 30%. At the same time, a massive expansion of 'Fortress Europe' is envisaged; for example, Frontex will be more than eightfold from the current 1 200 to 10 000 officials. I would like to see just as much commitment in other areas, such as the fight against wage dumping or tax fraud. On a positive note, the Commission's proposal is still more forward-looking than the ideas of the black-and-blue Federal Government in Austria. We also support the entry into an EU own resources system and more resources for Erasmus+.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — (PT) European citizens are now asking the following question: does the EU have the ability to propose a budget that reverses the trend of social and economic divergence that has prevailed in recent decades? Unfortunately, the answer is negative. We have a proposal for the multiannual framework of 2021-2027 with fewer resources for cohesion and the common agricultural policy, but which increases funding for security and defence and for arms policies. In addition, there is greater conditionality, with the link of the budget to the European Semester and the new instrument for democracy. In other words, we have a short budget, which will further force the neoliberal reforms that the EU seeks to impose on the Member States in the absentia of their peoples. This is therefore the picture of the EU, an EU increasingly disconnected from the real problems of the people and workers.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. — A period of tough negotiations follows, both in terms of drafting the EP's political opinion and, at the end of the year, drafting the budget report. The negotiations in the European Council will also be tough. The most important thing is that, at the end of this, we have a multiannual budget that strengthens EU-27 cohesion. We need more solidarity in the context of Brexit, and we must not allow budgetary negotiations to deepen the existing faulths between Member States. The Commission's proposal for the new MFF 2012-2027 comes with good news, but also with some worrying news. Under the Commission's proposal, presented today in the plenary of the European Parliament, we will have new chapters in the EU budget. One related to migration and border control and the other chapter on security and defence. This is important news for Romania, which participates in PESCO cooperation and which has long external borders of the EU. We have good news for young people. Youth programmes and Erasmus+ funding are doubled. But there is also some disturbing news for Romania. This is about budget cuts caused by Britain's exit from the EU, one of the biggest contributors. The cuts will reach the two major budget chapters, namely cohesion policy and the CAP.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. — Today, the proposal for the future long-term budget of the EU for 2021 to 2027, I consider it a good starting point for a pragmatic but economically strong Europe to discuss the next multiannual financial framework. With particular strength, I would like to emphasise the redundant aspect of the MFF as a key component of the Union's expenditure management, which ensures the effectiveness of its investment programmes, including key ones for me, as a member and longstanding budgetary rapporteur of the Committee on Culture and Education, programmes in the field of culture and education. I welcome the accent that the Commission has placed on the real European added value that investments in future MFF must represent. In this context, I consider it necessary to emphasise the continued support for programmes in the fields of culture, education, youth, research and civil society, which have clearly demonstrated their strong European added value and are also unabated among beneficiaries. I also welcome the doubling of Erasmus+'s budget and the significant increase in the budget of the successor Horizont2020 in the next financial term. However, I point out that I find the financial forecasts outlined for the next generation of Creative Europe and Europe for Citizens highly unsatisfying. In this context, I emphasise the key role of significantly and evenly increasing commitment and payment appropriations and long-term coordinated investments in order to ensure the successful implementation of the objectives of these programmes in the MFF after 2020.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. — (PT) The proposal for a Multiannual Financial Framework, adopted by the European Commission and presented today to the European Parliament, is insufficient quantitatively and qualitatively unbalanced. It is not acceptable that, in the face of a European Union in which development asymmetries are increasing, cohesion and convergence policies instead of being strengthened should be cut off in the financial allocation. Nor is a robust vision for completing Economic and Monetary Union implicit in the formulation of the proposal. The proposal presented reflects a management framework and not a framework of ambition. This is a starting point, not a point of arrival. The European Parliament must do its utmost to correct the imbalances of the proposal presented and make the most of the positive lines which include, inter alia, the increase in the appropriations allocated to Horizon Europe, the own resources proposals and the reform financing mechanism the financial stabilisation fund or the doubling of the Erasmus programme. As presented, the European Commission proposal is not up to what the EU needs and does not deserve a vote in favour of the European Parliament. I hope that the negotiation process can change this scenario.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Marco Vallego, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on the EIB's annual audit report for 2016 (2017/2190 (INI)) (A8-0139/2018).

name: Marco VALLI
text: rapporteur. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to first of all thank the shadow rapporteurs for their work together and for the text produced, as well as the EIB, the European Investment Bank , for making herself available to my work and colleagues. The EIB is the largest public bank in the world by volume and plays an important role, such as that played by the CONT commission, in readily highlighting — often with harsh but constructive criticism — aspects necessary for the improvement of institutions. In 2016 alone, the reference year of this report, the total amount of EIB Group loans amounted to €83.8 billion, with the mobilization of total investments in the same year of 280 billion euros. I would like to start with investment for small and medium-sized enterprises. SMEs play a key role in the European economy, generating jobs and wealth and promoting innovation: they account for more than 90% of EU businesses and employ two-thirds of the working population. Support for access to finance for SMEs and medium-cap enterprises must therefore remain a key priority for the European Investment Bank and the EIB needs to do more to support European small businesses. As far as the EFSI is concerned, I would first like to stress in this case the importance of the additionality criteria, which must be duly documented — something not happened in the framework of EFSI 1.0. This Parliament has fought so much on additionality and is a fundamental criterion. I therefore emphasise the importance of transparency with regard to the EFSI indicator framework and therefore welcome the fact that the indicator framework will be made public by regulation within the framework of FEIS 2.0. We want to have parameters regarding social, the environment, the real and effective economic interest in approving investments under this type of instrument. However, it is worrying that only 20% of EFSI funding has supported projects to help mitigate climate change and adapt to them, while the EIB standard portfolio reached the threshold of 25%. They are investments that have to go in the direction of emissions abatement. A number of specific projects are also mentioned in the report. One point I dear is the EIB's financing of the transadriatic pipeline project, which does not respect environmental and social standards to a different extent in transit countries (Albania, Greece and Italy) Minimum Equator Principles. I would also recall that the Dieselgate scandal raised several questions about the obtaining of EIB loans by Volkswagen through fraudulent and deceptive means, and it is good that the EIB carry out OLAF's recommendations on the adoption of concrete measures in the implementation of its anti-fraud policy. On transparency and accountability, I am pleased that the minutes of the EIB Management Board have been published and in this regard I urge you to publish the minutes of the meetings of the management committee. Stricter conflict of interest rules and clear, rigorous and transparent criteria must be laid down in order to avoid any form of corruption. I also welcome the proposals of the EIB Ethics and Conformity Committee on Corporate Governance and Transparency, such as the introduction of ethical aspects in its field of competence. I also stress the importance of strengthening integrity obligations following termination of employment and providing concrete penalties for potential cases of “revolving doors” among higher-ups EIB managers and the private sector. I call on the EIB to quickly apply relevant EU legislation and rules on tax avoidance, tax havens and other related aspects as well as to demand from its customers compliance with these rules and to prevent the risks of corruption and infiltration of organized crime more effectively. I leave the floor to my colleagues to open the discussion and I am also ready for other considerations in the follow up that will be closed.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to stress that the Commission greatly values the important role that this House plays in scrutinising the activities of the European Union institutions, including the EU Bank. We therefore welcome Marco Valli’s report. The importance that Parliament attaches to monitoring the European Investment Bank mirrors the key role that the Bank plays in the financial implementation and delivery of our political priorities. The European Investment Bank is an indispensable partner in financing infrastructures and in supporting small- and medium-sized enterprises, innovation, employment, climate change, sustainable transport and policies related to external actions.  I would like to focus on the Commission’s actions in two fields of particular relevance highlighted in your report. First, on compliance: we cannot – and must not – allow taxpayers’ money to be channelled through complex structures with high tax avoidance or risk or through tax jurisdictions which do not comply with international tax good governance standards. The European Union has achieved unprecedented progress in its efforts to counter tax avoidance.  Let me give you a few examples. We have swiftly adopted all the elements of the anti-tax avoidance package, dramatically increased tax transparency and adopted the first ever EU list of non-cooperative jurisdictions for tax purposes. All these collective actions have put the European Union at the forefront of international efforts to improve tax good governance. At the same time, we have been taking steps to improve consistency between our tax policy objective and the delivery of EU funds through international financial institutions. As a result, a number of regulations governing the use of EU funds now contain clauses intended to ensure that EU-funded projects do not contribute to tax avoidance.  All EU partners entrusted with the implementation of the European Union budget will need to meet these requirements. In order to ensure effective application of the new legal rules, the Commission adopted a communication on 24 March providing guidance on the new legal requirements. We have also asked our implementing partners to reflect this guidance as quickly as possible in their policies. However, the impact of the guidance depends on the Union’s ability to send a unified message. For this to happen, it is important that Member States’ representatives in governing bodies of international financial institutions, development financial institutions, and national promotion banks, along with other institutions supporting projects through the use of public funds, adopt a consistent approach that reflects our joint commitment to countering tax avoidance. Parliament’s continued support in this endeavour is most important, not least in order to reach out to the Member States as shareholders of the EIB.  Secondly, on the transparency and the addition of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), the first detailed reasoning for the decisions of the EFSI Investment Committee approving the use of the EU guarantee was recently published on the EIB website in line with the new requirements under the EFSI 2.0 Regulation. The first scoreboards related to those decisions have also been made publicly available. They give detailed information on the four-pillar assessment that each project has undergone before being submitted to the EFSI Investment Committee. This significantly increases the transparency in decision-making on EFSI support. Responding to the criticism in this House, I would say three things. Firstly, you have to bear in mind that EFSI was a revolution for the EIB in terms of expectations as regards the type of operation and risk. Secondly, today’s results are overwhelmingly positive, as all Member States are covered, smaller projects are being pooled through investment platforms and new instruments are being developed, including for the social sector. The top five users of the EFSI are currently Greece, Estonia, Bulgaria, Portugal and Spain.  Finally, I am convinced that collectively we have made a lot of improvements through the EFSI 2.0 Regulation, including on additionality, transparency and both sectorial and geographical balance. I would like to assure you that the Commission continues to be attentive to Parliament’s observations and is committed to ensuring that those observations are best informed. Thank you very much for your attention, and I look forward to the debate.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. — (NL) Mr President, if things are not going well in the European Union, we are critical. I think rightly. If things go well, we must also have the courage to acknowledge and recognise that. Frankly, the European Investment Bank is doing quite well, perhaps because it is an intergovernmental cooperation between Member States that has grown from below because they want to work together and not because they have to do so from above. I find it interesting, for example, to see that the European Investment Bank recognises that our Flemish Government is also doing serious work. We see this very concrete because a loan has been approved by the European Investment Bank for our Oosterweel plans of EUR 1 billion. This will enable us to do serious work. Work that is needed in the European Union, major infrastructure projects that are good for our viability and good for our economy and, as a whole, also for the European economy. Is there work on the shelf? Yes, and this is recognised in this good report. In particular, I would like to underline the work for our SMEs. They too must have access to smooth financing more than ever, and we call on the European Investment Bank to remove the obstacles and obstacles.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, at the beginning, I would like to congratulate Mr Valli for his hard work on this well-balanced report and especially for his openness to work with all of us, the shadow rapporteurs. This is the third year in a row I’ve been involved in a way in the consideration of the annual report of the activities of the European Investment Bank, and I can see improvement. I can see progress, especially, by the way, in the communication with the Parliament – this is something that we should all welcome. However, there is room for further improvement. For example, I think – especially now with the current proposal of next MFF, bearing in mind that probably the share of financial instruments will be even bigger – the European Investment Bank should guarantee a well-balanced (in geographical terms) distribution of these financial instruments. Moreover, I think not just geographical balance but the distribution of financial instruments towards the different sectors of our economy is crucial as well. I think this is achievable and I’m sure that the good communication between the bank and the Parliament will continue, and I’m looking forward to a fruitful discussion that we’ll have today.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the Valli report acquires added relevance in light of the post-2020 MFF perspective just announced by the Commission. One important aspect is the spending on social investments. The report highlights that EFSI investments in human capital, culture and health amounted to only 4%. Furthermore, it is regrettable that within the annual EIB portfolio social investments amount to less than 6%. The focus of the EU budget and new challenges such as migration, borders and defence underline the increased need for the EIB to promote investments in priorities set out in the Treaty, such as cohesion. Given that social cohesion is a key horizontal priority goal for the EIB, and while the bank is still struggling to achieve the mandatory 30% threshold, it is now evermore called upon to identify and include in its activities new forms of investments which are suitable and effective for the social sector and to implement them on a broader geographical scale, taking into consideration the need to implement the social pillar, as well as to counter inequalities, parities and disparities within the EU. Mr President, without adequate social investments, the very future of the European project will be severely jeopardised.  And by the way, Mr President, how come there is no representative of the Bank at this discussion? Is it possible that Parliament failed to invite any Bank representatives? President Hoyer always takes part in a very engaged way. I would be grateful if you would find out how this most unusual situation could have arisen.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Mr, I accept this query. We will try to explain how this unusual situation occurred.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Commissioner! Mr President! A year ago at the time of this debate we had a guy from Luxembourg, two years ago and three years ago too, and yes I can mention — I am a third term MP. Always the EIB president was. I don't know what happened, and it is strange. Please, sir! Unfortunately, the European Investment Bank, in my view, has a smaller, weaker role than it was even a few years ago. Why? Because he suddenly wanted to be a bank like that, because he cares more about the AAA ranking, on those ratings, on those expert assessments, but he does not understand his special role, also in the context of the countries of the new Union, the countries of our region. I think the EIB has at the moment shut down to investment in modern technology, it has cut back very much on those investments, which are a little more risky, but without such investments there will be no economic progress in our Europe. At the moment, the EIB is racing against commercial banks — it is meaningless, it is not this league, it is not what he was called for, among other things with our — the European Union — participation. I think that, in conclusion, Mr President, I think that the EIB is a special bank and should not pretend to be the same bank as others, a commercial bank. He should be taking more risks with projects and investments.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, first of all I’d like to congratulate Mr Valli on what I believe is an excellent report. Unfortunately, however, and as happens so often in these cases where one of their own isn’t the rapporteur, the EPP and its supporters have managed to dilute the report somewhat, forcing Mr Valli into the position of trying to introduce in plenary, via amendments to his own file, elements that were rejected in committee. I have a problem with the European Investment Bank in the manner in which it has funded what is meant to be a semi-state body in Ireland called Coillte but which is in fact run like its own little kingdom, dominating the timber supply market in Ireland. These loans are provided at interest rates that ordinary farmers who might like to get into agri-forestry, or even individuals who would like to get into the timber supply, can only dream of. Perhaps the EIB would like to revisit the issue and at least create a level playing field. Again, I congratulate Mr Valli and I wish him well with these amendments.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: We checked: last we hosted Mr Hoyer in Strasbourg on February 7, 2018, when we considered the Annual Report on the Financial Operations of the European Investment Bank. It was a debate.
