This is the first explanation that, for sure, President Hoyer and the EIB do not underestimate our institution. Why aren't there today? It's going to be a separate question.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, thank you also to the rapporteur, Mr Valli, and the shadow rapporteurs. I myself am now doing the European Investment Bank's annual report for CONT for the third time in a row, and I have to say that it has given me great pleasure, because this is how we get to know this bank better, and it is one of the real success stories; the EIB is the largest multilateral bank and the largest public bank Lenders of the World, the Bank of the EU and its Member States — that is, a real success story, and this should be said once again, it has been briefly mentioned today. The total financing has already been discussed: EUR 83.8 billion, and a total of EUR 280 billion has been mobilised. What is important is that a quarter of this was directly related to EFSI financing, which in turn is essential for closing the investment gap at European level, 1.1% GDP growth and creating 1.4 million additional jobs. In 2016, there were four policy areas in which the EIB invested: innovation and knowledge, SME and midcap financing, infrastructure, and the environment and climate change. Almost a third of the financing, or EUR 21.3 billion, went to small and medium-sized enterprises. A total of 385 000 SMEs have been financed by the EIB, which are also a priority, as SMEs play the crucial role and are the backbone of the European economy. It is therefore important that access to finance will be easier and more effective, and that SMEs working abroad also receive support from the Trade Finance Facility.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: — Mr President, I think that this debate should send a very clear message to Luxembourg that priorities are changing very quickly in a globalised world and the need for them effectively and react flexibly. For this, effective and flexible instruments such as fast loans are also needed, and it is these loans that the European Investment Bank must be able to provide with the priorities of the European Union and must be able to know is to focus on sectors that are so important to the European Union. I would like to say a few examples. One for all. Perhaps I think that investment in transport construction and infrastructure could be used precisely thanks to the European Investment Bank and could be put and directed into projects that can have added value or which may have leverage for the economy of a given state. Also, investments in start-up, new technologies, we can implement all this through these loans, which can have added value precisely to the beneficiary on the basis that European investment the bank is able to structure those projects perfectly and can appreciate the risk from these projects. And it may also actually reflect the commitments of the Paris Agreement. At the same time, it can also attract new investors and I think that the European Investment Bank is not able to use too much at the moment. I would also urge her to make any projects she supports more visible.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Madam President, welcome, Commissioner. I thank Mr Valli for his report, which is very interesting, although some local issues sometimes disdeserve. I will only raise two concerns. Firstly, with regard to the EIB, the dramatic lack of adaptation to microcredits, which are fundamental to development cooperation, must be denounced. In regions such as the Maghreb, or, in general, in Africa or Latin America, we find that there are many contracts signed but nothing implemented. Now that the EDF finally falls within the Community budget, it is more important than ever to ensure that this type of microcredit is represented. Secondly, its lack of adaptation to start-ups and the need to cover the risk necessary to move forward. That would be a great added value: that they do not have to go to the United States for funding. And finally, as Mr Hoyer is not here, maybe the commissioner can explain it to me. A curiosity: how have the European Investment Bank and its advisory hub of excellence — in any case as far as it costs us — have been integrated into the configuration of the new European Union financing instrument? If it is true that we have not worked together, how can we explain and why? Which entities is the European Commission thinking about?

name: Dennis de JONG
text: Mr President, I would like to echo the words of people who say that it has become important, the work of the EIB, including for the European Union's policy. But precisely because it is becoming an ever larger bank with more and more resources, it is also important that transparency and integrity are regulated perfectly, and there is still a lot to be done about that. As the rapporteur has already said, the minutes of the management committee must be made public. The European Ombudsman's proposal for a tightening up of the Code of Conduct against Conflicts of Interest should also be adopted, including in order to prevent people who have worked at the Bank from returning to work in the same sector or, conversely, from becoming a kind of revolving door. And finally — as far as I am concerned — the complaints mechanism. There is a reform for this, and I have put forward a number of proposals for this in the consultation. These are also reflected in this report. But the Bank is not responding! I would very much like — and that is why it is a pity that Mr Hoyer is not here — to clarify this very quickly. Complaints are very important for transparency and integrity. They need to be looked at independently, and this is not yet mentioned in the Bank's proposals.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: — Commissioner, in 2012, together with Philippe Maystadt, President of the European Investment Bank, I proposed the establishment of an investment agency to promote national synergies at European level, but also to develop new projects. This is the Europe of nations. The mistake of the Juncker Plan comes from project funding that would have been done anyway — the bargain effect — without new development dynamics in southern Europe, but also development and security in Africa. It is the combination, within such a European investment agency to be built on national bases, of a European development plan, the setting up of projects in countries in difficulty, capital financing and the mobilization of private actors that is essential. The current policy does not adequately address this need. It is therefore useless if we do not concurrently lead a European investment and development agency built on the basis of the synergies of the Europe of nations.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: — The European Investment Bank is an important tool for achieving our economic development goals in the EU. On one of the aspects of the operation, namely the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Overall, this fund has worked successfully, the initial three-year period has been extended, but I think that both the European Investment Bank as a whole and the Fund for Strategic Investments still need to focus more on cohesion policy objectives. What did we hear today discussing budget issues? Thus, the multiannual financial framework provides for a 7% reduction in cohesion objectives. Here, the European Investment Bank is the instrument that we can achieve these goals, but when we look at the whole loans for projects inside the European Union, then five countries — Spain, Italy, France, Germany and the UK — have received 55% interest, but for example, The funds provided for the Baltic States have even decreased slightly. Of course, we need very high quality infrastructure (I think this is one of the main objectives), as well as small and medium-sized enterprises, and in general we need to focus much more on technical assistance, which is especially important for micro and small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: — Madam Chairman, I would like to agree with everything my colleagues have said and stressed that the activities of the EIB are very important for economic growth and development and for maintaining a desirable level of investment in the European Union. However, they also stressed that the role of the European Investment Bank for the uniform development of all corners of the European Union and cohesion policy is very important, and exactly what was highlighted in this report, namely that 70% of all credit activities were directed to six Member States and none of these six Member States do not belong to the EU 13 new Member States, which are also the biggest beneficiaries of cohesion policy. This is what the European Investment Bank has to change. This is a 2016 report, now in 2018 we can see that more technical assistance activities for project preparation and for new investment instruments and financial instruments are directed to less developed Member States. I support that and I want the EIB to continue to work in this way even more vigorously.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: — Investing is art, and since it is real art, it should also take into account creative industries. Unfortunately it does not include. I want to point out not so much on behalf of the Committee on Culture, but from the Committee on Culture that we very often point out that creative industries do not fit in projects, do not fall within priorities, do not fit within those instruments and instrumentation that the Bank prefers under the EFSI. I draw attention to this because what surrounds us — design items, various start-ups — is very often based on this creativity. And in short, I demand that you broaden the goals of investing, pay attention to culture, and take into account the strength that is inherent in culture, as far as the financial effect is concerned.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate Mr Valli on his initial report on the European Investment Bank. I would certainly point out that at a time when Turkey is threatening Greece and Cyprus, at a time when Turkey is violating my country's sovereign rights, while holding our two military officers illegally, the European Investment Bank is giving Turkey a package of low-interest loans. It is seventh in the row of third countries in the money it receives. In 2014, Turkey received EUR 2.1 billion in loans; in 2016, EUR 2.3 billion. Therefore, there must be a complete suspension of the European Investment Bank's funds to Turkey in order to meet and to be forced to respect international law. And in relation to what Mr Oettinger, I have asked that there should be no funds in the budget for Turkey. The Commissioner said that we have frozen these funds. But there is no guarantee that in the future they will not thaw. Funds should not be transferred to Turkey as long as it violates international law and human rights.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, the EIB has come more into focus, especially in recent years with the development of EFSI. There is no doubt that this has been a huge success, which has been recognised internationally by many people who very dubious about it initially. So credit goes to the EIB, the Commission and particularly President Juncker. I myself have hosted four or five public events in my constituency on EFSI. There was a big attendance and the attendees were really appreciative, especially of the presence of Mr Murphy, who is the head of the EIB Office in Dublin. I think that all this is helping to bridge what was once a financial gap, create employment and give a good positive image of European institutions and especially of the EIB itself. One thing that speakers mentioned – and which I would reiterate – is that, if at all possible, we need to do more for SMEs so that thresholds can be lowered and SMEs can benefit from the great work of the EIB.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I would like first of all to thank you for this interesting debate which we have had today. We will surely have the opportunity to continue the discussions on the EIB’s role as a strategic implementing partner in the forthcoming months in the context of the Commission’s proposal for the next multiannual financial framework. As I said in my opening debate, this strategic investment fund was a revolution for the EIB, and we have worked together also on the omnibus to make some blendings between structural funds and strategic investment funds in order to maximise the impact, and we are working very well with the EIB. Also, regarding the request of Mrs Ines Ayala, I would like to say that the EIB has adapted and changed its business model with EFSI, taking on more risk, developing new products and benefiting smaller projects. You know that small and medium-sized enterprises incentivising start-ups are the biggest beneficiary so far of EFSI. We expect more than 611 000 SMEs to benefit from the EFSI fund. For start-ups, we just launched the so-called ‘Venture EU’, which will target specifically start-ups to help them grow in Europe, and also we expect to attract EUR 55 billion with this new initiative to support over 150 000 start-ups and scale-ups. As I said, we are continuing to pay attention to the valuable observations and suggestions of the European Parliament. I would like to thank once again the rapporteur for this important work and of course, it’s a pity that the representative of the EIB is not here, but hopefully we will have the opportunity to speak again. Thank you Madam President, thanks to the rapporteur and also the honourable Members who have the patience to say so much today.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: We thank you so much for your points.

name: Marco VALLI
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, thank you all for your congratulations, it was a good job that we have done together and I see a broad cross-party consensus, especially on some issues, including the need to increase investment for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the mainstay of the European economy, and especially innovative startups that can generate places of work, especially in innovative sectors, and which therefore can make a significant contribution to growth in the eurozone and the European Union in general. As far as the EFSI is concerned, Parliament has already spent a great deal to ask for additionality criteria which are specifically defined in Regulation 2.0. So we want these criteria to be applied, that the whole issue related to environmental, social impact is made transparent (because it is important that there is a social impact, with the creation of posts work) and economic (i.e. that there are the criteria for economic sustainability and that we do not go to finance works which are then a black hole for public coffers, because the guarantee of the Bank European investment is public). Tax transparency: I recommend that we all agree on this point, we must not have the European Investment Bank to encourage operations in tax havens and companies that prove incapable of Transparently manage its internal dimension relating to issues of tax transparency. Conflicts of interests and revolving doors: they are one of the main things that Parliament asks with this report, we must avoid these practices and find innovative solutions and to avant-garde As far as geographical redistribution is concerned, it is vital that there is more investment in some countries and it is vital that these countries have the facilities to be able to attract these countries investments, that is, promotion banks on the territory. If they implement these kinds of facilities, they will surely see more investment coming to the territory as well. I thank everyone again for the great job we've done.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 3 May 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — The European Investment Bank is the world's largest bank by volumes and plays a key role in socio-economic integration and cohesion within the European Union. I think the report overall is satisfactory, as it provides an exhaustive analytical picture of the critical points and weaknesses of the EIB's activities, especially as regards the need for improve conflict of interest prevention by defining stricter standards and stricter and more transparent criteria in order to avoid any form of corruption. I am pleased that the EIB has been invited to provide a more harmonised, comprehensive and detailed annual report on its investment activities and the expected impact. Specifically, I believe the request for the bank to improve the presentation of the information, including a detailed and reliable description of the investments very positive approved, signed and provided, as well as information on beneficiaries and the specification of committed funding sources and sectors supported, including the results of ex assessments post. With the hope that the assessments and recommendations arising from this report will have a specific follow-up and application, I congratulate my colleagues on their excellent work.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. — The official message from the European Commission is the transition to a low-carbon economy that reaches emission neutrality by 2050, but the reality is quite different. While Commissioner Cañete and Vice-President Šefčovič insist on the importance of reducing emissions, the EIB is dedicated to financing fossil fuels, earmarking billions of euros to the construction of infrastructure for fossil fuels. This embarrassing institutional financing sends a contradictory message to private investors in renewable energy, whose steadily declining prices put at risk of converting financed infrastructures into stranded assets in a few years. For the sake of diversification and security of supply, all the EU ensures is the fossil fuel business, and jeopardizes compliance with the Climate Agreement, by promoting the use of fossil fuels, such as natural gas, with worrying leakage rates and a powerful impact on comparable global warming to emissions from the burning of lignite, the most polluting coal. Financing investment in fossil fuels undermines the exceptional development of renewable energies and sows uncertainty in an energy market in transition.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the Presidential elections in Venezuela (2018/2695 (RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, Venezuela urgently needs a political solution to end the current crisis and, first and foremost, to deliver on its people’s needs. You know that many Venezuelans are also European citizens and you know how deep the ties are that link the country and the European Union. They are cultural, social and even family ties. Yet, the latest developments have pushed the possibility of a compromise even further away. Since we last discussed Venezuela in the plenary just a couple of months ago, the negotiations in Santo Domingo have been suspended indefinitely without an agreement between the Government and the opposition. In spite of this, the Government decided to go ahead with early presidential elections, to be held on 20 May. There was no agreement on the electoral calendar, and the current electoral process does not guarantee transparent and credible elections with the participation of all political parties in an equal manner and without obstacles. This non-inclusive decision will only exacerbate polarisation and tension and it will create more obstacles to a political solution. As these events unfolded, we reacted immediately over the bans and difficulties created to prevent the participation of opposition political parties and their leaders, including the exclusion of the opposition platform, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática. The National Electoral Council has also decided to prevent the participation in the regional elections of those parties that do not present candidates for the presidential election. This is a further blow to the credibility of the process. Back in February, as you know, we agreed with the European Union Member States’ Foreign Ministers that we would follow the electoral process in Venezuela very closely, together with our regional and international partners. On 19 April, we issued a declaration on behalf of the European Union calling for free, transparent and credible elections. We asked for an agreed electoral calendar and for guarantees in conformity with international standards. We will reassess the situation with Member States after the elections. We will consider the possibility of further appropriate measures to react to actions that would undermine democracy, the rule of law and human rights in the country.  In the meantime, I have been in close contact with several of our partners, first of all, inside Venezuela – I will come to that in a minute – but also in the region and in the international community, where we have coordinated positions and exchanged views on the best way to address this crisis. As regards our partners inside Venezuela, I met here in Brussels with both the Government of Venezuela and the opposition. Our goal has always been to support Venezuela and to help it hold inclusive and credible elections. On 11 April, I met the Foreign Minister and encouraged the Government to go back to the negotiating table and to show flexibility towards an agreement with all the opposition on the date and the electoral conditions. I also informed the Minister that the European Union could not accept the invitation from the Venezuelan authorities to monitor these elections because the current conditions of the electoral process do not allow a proper observation to take place. We have clear standards for monitoring and observing elections and obviously, in this case, these conditions are not in place. Last week I met with the President of the National Assembly and the representatives of the four main opposition parties. This was, first and foremost, to show our full support for the National Assembly. I also encouraged the opposition to continue working in a united manner towards a democratic and peaceful solution to the crisis. This is not only a political crisis: Venezuela is facing huge economic and social challenges. We hear this from so many Venezuelans. Inflation is expected to reach 13 000%. The population has to deal with shortages of food, medicines, water and electricity. Many Venezuelans have sought refuge in Colombia and Brazil, but also in Panama, in Chile and in the Caribbean. The European Union is stepping up its humanitarian support for the people of Venezuela, both inside and outside the country. The European Union will provide EUR 8 million in humanitarian assistance and we are mobilising other financial instruments in support of Venezuelan refugees and the host countries and communities. Against this background, it is time for all sides to engage seriously in working towards shared solutions. The Government has the responsibility to create the conditions for free and fair elections, based on a consensual calendar and with the participation of all political parties. We call for a revision of the electoral calendar, based on an agreed and credible timeline. As the European Union, we will continue to monitor any development, together with our partners, and we will calibrate future actions in the light of the development of the situation.  Let me conclude by saying explicitly that the European Union does not interfere in domestic politics. We never do. We do not impose solutions. We simply do everything we can to accompany and to help the Venezuelan parties and Venezuelan people to find their own solution, which the country and the citizens deserve to achieve. This crisis is not a natural disaster. This crisis is a man-made crisis. There is nothing inevitable about it and this means that a political solution is possible and so is a better future for the people of Venezuela. We care about Venezuela because we care about the people of that country, as friends and as family. We hope for the best for those we care about: a peaceful, democratic, shared political solution for Venezuela.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, just five months ago this Parliament, standing up, applauded the democratic opposition and Venezuelan political prisoners. None of them can be present in the elections on May 20, because some are in jail, others are in exile and others are disabled. If we are consistent, we cannot accept, we cannot recognize an electoral process in which those whom we have recognized with the Sakharov Prize cannot be present. In Venezuela, 90 per cent of democratic parties have been declared illegal. In Venezuela there are more than 600 political prisoners, not counting how many disappeared there are also. In Venezuela, over the past year, 6,300 people died from clashes with the authority. Just yesterday we learned that Daniel Queliz's mother killed in the 17th protests because he couldn't bear to live without his son. And that political crisis has already become a humanitarian crisis. In Venezuela he is starving again and dying from common diseases again. Caritas tells us that almost every day a baby dies in Venezuela. And the New York Times has made a very painful report on children who die from lack of food in this beloved country. It tells the case of Nerianyelis Torres, seven months old, who died precisely because his parents could not find powdered milk with which to feed it. We cannot accept elections in which there are political prisoners. We cannot accept elections in which all parties cannot take place on an equal footing. We cannot accept elections in which the electoral authority is not neutral — the president of the Venezuelan electoral authority is precisely sanctioned by the European Union. We cannot accept elections in which there is no neutral international observation, a decent international observation. That is why, as the European Parliament, we should demand Maduro to suspend the election call for May and call for other elections, with the participation of all political forces on an equal footing. We should say clearly that we cannot recognize the outcome of those elections on 20 May and that they follow the aftermath. We must also clarify that we are not going to send observers either the Commission or Parliament - and whoever will observe is going to be a personal guest of Maduro, and that we will continue to pursue the heritage of those who have become rich at the cost of impoverishing and making the Venezuelan people suffer. In Venezuela, the situation has reached such an extreme that it is already just a matter of being or with those who make them suffer or with those who suffer. And the European Union, without ever meddling in what is autonomy, in the sovereignty of the noble people, the brave Venezuelan people, must always be — as you are doing, Mrs Mogherini — with those who suffer, not those who make them suffer.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, I agree with you, Mrs Mogherini, with your tone of prudence and political intelligence on this serious problem we have in Venezuela. On Thursday last week, a representation of the Venezuelan Parliament came to visit the various political groups: eight representatives of the Venezuelan opposition, two of them presidents of the Assembly — one who was and one who is — from four very important political parties representing approximately 80% of the vote that was produced in the month of December 2015. They expressly asked us for a statement from the European Parliament calling for the suspension of the elections. I know it's testimonial, but they insisted on us to make that request, and that is why we urgently summoned you. I thank you for your presence, Mrs. Mogherini. Why did they ask us for the postponement? Because, as has been said, the electoral call is advantageous; it is not the same, because there are illegal political parties, because there are political leaders who are disabled, because the electoral system is not fair, because there was no agreement between the opposition and the government. That is why the problem we have now, ladies and gentlemen, is that we can continue to reiterate our condemnation of the Maduro regime, but I would like to express to you with a little balance that solidarity with the request for suspension which I share. We have to ask that elections be postpened, because they are going to create a larger gap, a more serious turning point of even internal rupture. But I would also like to say on behalf of the S&D Group that we call on the Government and the opposition to resume dialogue if they postpone the elections; that it is possible to find a framework of agreement again for a clean electoral call and that, at the same time, they are able to find a compromise to get Venezuelans out of the crisis humanitarian aid in which they live; to commit themselves to socio - economic solution. And let the European Union help Venezuela humanitarily. That is the position of the S&D Group.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Madam High Representative, the elections to be held in Venezuela on 20 May represent nothing less than the final act by President Maduro in his construction of a de facto one-party state, characterised by repression and holding of political prisoners. The legitimate National Assembly and subsequently the Supreme Court having been neutered, 20 May is merely a coronation in a race devoid of any legitimate opposition. The collapse of the Santo Domingo talks made clear Maduro’s intentions to avoid any real challenge to his power now, as was also demonstrated by the banning of virtually all opposition parties from these elections. I welcome the targeted EU sanctions brought in by the Council against some Venezuelan officials. However, these remain limited, and we must now look to widen their scope. As the energy sector, which accounts for around 90% of Venezuela’s exports, begins to shrink, we see food shortages continuing and domestic dissatisfaction growing. Reports that the Government is looking to open up commercial opportunities for the military are also a worrying sign for the future, suggesting that Maduro intends to follow what was in the past an all too common Latin American authoritarian tactic for holding on to power via the army. I fear that these elections may be the first in a long line of staged elections made all the easier by the 2009 constitutional amendments to abolish term limits. I am pleased that at least we will be on record today in this House as having made our condemnatory position very clear to everybody.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, thank you for being here and for your sensitivity. Elections are much more than ballot boxes and ballots, and I tell you with the experience of those who lived under the Franco regime, who also had ballots and ballots. But there was nothing essential, that was freedom, the freedom that the brother Venezuelan people lacks. And as a Spaniard I am, I am also Venezuelan, and I feel it in my heart and I feel it in my soul. I, to those who feel sympathetic to certain regimes that under the name of antimperialists are capable of making the revolution until the last Cuban or the last Venezuelan, would recommend that they live five days in Venezuela as a Venezuelan, like a foot Venezuelan, with all the miseries created by a corrupt regime. to the core, which has been unable to manage with elementary decency the billions of euros of an uninterrupted flow of oil. That Venezuela lacks everything today is a scandal in a rich country, it's something like Qatar was in misery. Therefore, my solidarity and solidarity I require is not with the abject Venezuelan Madurist regime, but with the true Venezuelan people. And the Venezuelan people are each and every one of those who comply with that phrase that said that exile is a referendum that is voted with their feet. And the hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans who have to leave their land for misery are the consequence of that abject regime; a liberticidal regime that has castrated by the National Assembly; a liberticidal regime that has dominated the judiciary, because everything is actually the executive power, that is, the most disgusting oligarchy. In the face of that we have, first, to require the supposedly electoral process to cease. Secondly, that the International Court expedite its investigation into human rights violations and that the very short list of seven persons who were reprisal for human rights crimes should be supplemented, because there were not only seven, there were many more.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, we are discussing Venezuela again. And there are already eleven times between resolutions, pronouncements, etc., and so on, thanks to the fact that the EPP Group and the President of this Parliament have violated this House's Rules of Procedure for their political benefit. They violate Rule 156: we needed at least 24 hours before the vote. It's not urgent: they already knew it since the CNE announced them in March 2018; we would have had the March and April Plenary. We are therefore facing an irregular debate introduced with a conscious ignorance of the rules that we have all and all of us set for the functioning of this Parliament. Nothing new coming from the PPE Group and from a president not of everyone but of the People's Party. Something we know well in Spain: broken rules to avoid corruption of Europe's most corrupt party. Those who drive this resolution use Venezuela for everything. That someone from his party takes money, Venezuela; that they give a master's degree to one of their own, Venezuela; that there are cuts, Venezuela; that other political forces must be attacked, Venezuela. A wild card worn out and full of lies. His obsession with Venezuela contrasts with his oblivion in Latin America. Do you know, Mr. Pons? Sixteen children killed by malnutrition in Colombia. The Ombudsman says it, but the People's Party doesn't care about those dead. These elections will be made despite their jacks, even though their puppets do not show up. There are four candidates, there are freedom to campaign, there are audits and, above all, the willingness to vote of millions of Venezuelans and Venezuelans, as has been done twenty-four times, even if they don't like it because their own people do not show up. Venezuela will vote.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam High Representative (whom I thank for your promptness), it is truly incredible and grotesque that we are still looking for defend a regime that has transformed a country full of natural wealth, starting with oil and above all the wealth of hundreds of thousands of emigrants: emigrated from Europe, emigrated from Italy, people who went to work and made this country great, because Venezuela is a great country and has a great people who created wealth. Only the regime of those people turned it into a poor country, where there is no freedom. One should only be ashamed and at least shut up, rather than criticising the European Parliament, which if anything should be invited to do more, to open the doors of this Europe which often opens its doors to the whole of the world, and still today hesitates to say that there must be the doors open to refugees of Venezuela. These are people who have the same blood as our colleague remembered well, who must be recognized a priority. It is a country that needs to be helped, it's about people on the run that we have to open our doors to. There is a seat at the table for anyone who comes from Venezuela running away from misery, running away from dictatorship. Elections postponed: they are ashamed to rig democracy so, they don't even have the right to talk about democracy.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: — Madam President, we are discussing Venezuela and I see that Mr Couso Permuy has a problem with the EPP, not with Maduro. Mr. Couso Permuy, you are defending a dictatorship. It is in a dictatorship that opposition parties are prohibited from participating. Mr Couso Permuy, this is an electoral farce what will happen on May 20 in Venezuela. The Chavist regime banned the opposition from participating. We will not have transparent and inclusive elections at all. And for that, Mr Couso Permuy, our European response must be very clear: we will neither observe these elections nor recognise the outcome of these elections. And if you may, — since the government is trying to block all the ways out of the crisis — I believe that the sanctions that the Union has adopted against Venezuela must be maintained and be accompanied by even greater pressure until your friend Maduro releases political prisoners, dear colleague, until they cease daily violations of human rights and until opposition parties can express themselves. We must not hesitate to adopt new sanctions after these elections in order to show Maduro, Mr Couso Permuy, that impunity is not an option.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: — Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, I would like to express my full support to the initial considerations you have made. Clearly there are no conditions to guarantee a clean and free democratic process in Venezuela. There is no possibility of democratic elections in a country where people are in jail for political reasons. There are no conditions for free and democratic elections when very important sectors of society and imminent personalities are not in a position to present themselves to those same elections. There is no possibility of free and democratic elections when there is a set of procedural rules that are not guaranteed at all, as is the case today in Venezuela. That is why this call by the European Parliament for a postponement of these elections is an appeal that goes in the right direction. Venezuela is not just going through a very serious political crisis. It is also going through a serious economic and social crisis and a profound humanitarian crisis. We think that the only possible solution is dialogue, there is no other. We continue to invest in dialogue between the various political forces with expression in Venezuela, both those currently in power and those in opposition. That is why we call on the current Venezuelan regime to understand that insisting on these elections not only does not contribute to solving the problem of Venezuela but will sharply sharpen the problem. On the contrary, a postponement of elections, creating the conditions for the participation of all those who wish to participate in these presidential elections, elections held in a free and democratic manner, under observation and scrutiny of various international bodies, including the European Union and this Parliament This, yes, is the way that could help resolve the very serious problems that continue to affect Venezuela. I therefore reiterate what I said at the outset: I fully agree with the sensible, fair and balanced position you announced at the beginning of this debate.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Madam President, Commissioner. We are looking to Venezuela with great concern. The situation of human rights, democracy and the rule of law is deteriorating significantly. Venezuela is experiencing a political, social, economic and humanitarian crisis that is accompanied by tragic events and deaths. It cannot and must not continue like this. A solution needs to be found urgently. This solution cannot, however, be in the planned elections on 20 May, because fair and free elections require certain conditions, such as the participation of all political parties. However, I do not see these conditions fulfilled. Before elections can take place in Venezuela, the government and the opposition must enter into an agreement that sets the electoral process, in any case — as I said — with the participation of all political parties. The elections must be fair, free and transparent, and the worrying situation must end as soon as possible. The people of Venezuela should no longer suffer from this serious crisis.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Madam President, of course, today the EPP Group has shown itself. It has been shown because the democratic rules of this Parliament have been skipped within 24 hours. Is this really democratic? I don't think it. I don't think it and I look for you, yeah. Because, if you were more concerned about the things that happen in the Spanish State than about things that happen in Venezuela, we would talk clearer. If you were more concerned about cuts, rapes, court judgments, political prisoners also in Spain, we would be calmer. But coming here to judge a State that has called for democratic elections is unethical and we must therefore take on any means of dialogue to settle differences, of course. The Venezuelan Government itself — the Government of the Venezuelan Bolivarian Republic, which is so called — would be willing to do so. Everyone is willing to do that, including I think the High Representative, everyone. But what they are not worth is ideological traps or traps to become the protagonists in a House which needs to hold democratic debates and not deal with issues affecting third countries which are calling for fair and laudable elections.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, the people of Venezuela cannot continue to hold a second longer. People go hungry, they don't have medicines, they are persecuted, harassed and imprisoned. And all that cannot be masked with a fraudulent call for elections that are neither democratic nor free. Opposition parties are declared illegal and adversaries are locked up and disabled. Electoral observation is not allowed and there is not a single guarantee of democratic legitimacy, because those who have to guarantee it — the CNE — is neither independent nor is it democratic. With this background, we can't do the post-facto analysis. The European Union cannot accept the holding of fraudulent elections, let alone the outcome of elections rigged in advance. It is not time for political prudence, it is time for decisive action in defense of the Venezuelan people. I have said this many times: the European Union cannot abandon Venezuela.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: Madam President, thank you Mrs Mogherini for reminding us once again that being fair is different from being neutral. And Europe is not neutral with regard to Venezuela. That is why what we are doing here is to remember that in February we adopted a very comprehensive resolution in which we were moving forward that we would not know any fraudulent electoral process, any electoral process that was not credible, transparent and inclusive. You remembered it. He made a statement recently, on 19 April. And what I am asking you here is — as you rightly said — that, when the next Foreign Affairs Council meets this month, we urged you to take the steps we proposed to you, we urged you to take in that February resolution. We urge you to have elections of this nature, that they are fully acceptable, that the entire opposition can participate, that the humanitarian channel be opened so that we can carry out all the action we are proposing and, above all, that Venezuela can truly return to the democratic path from which it has been set aside. Because what we are clear here is that asking that fraudulent elections be suspended, asking to suspend a fraud, is not to accept that fraud, is to give a chance to that government that has taken that suicide path of destruction of its country to correct and accept the opportunity to accompany them and solve together what Venezuela needs and that Venezuela deserves.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: Madam President, another unheard discussion on Venezuela with a resolution that violates Parliament's own Rules of Procedure in order to pursue the intentions of interference and interference over a sovereign country. Admit it, your strategy has failed. The same strategy that has fuelled the assault and destabilization throughout the region, which legitimized the coup in Brazil and the fraudulent elections in Honduras. They are now seeking to discredit the presidential elections, the same ones that part of the opposition, divided, now chooses to boycott, the same opposition that you have promoted, responsible for the most ignoble acts of violence and economic, social and political disturbance in that country. From here we welcome and sympathize with the certain Venezuelan people who have been able to resist the imperialist offensive, the crisis imposed on them from outside, the criminal and brutal economic and financial sanctions, and which will once again give you the best response on the 20th, and will once again give you the best response, sovereignly asserting the choice of their future.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I think we share the same objective here, even with the differences that I recognise and are not new in this chamber on the situation in Venezuela, but I think we share two things. One is the sincere feeling of friendship and support for the country and the people of Venezuela. I think that unites us and that is behind all our efforts to support and accompany the country out of a crisis that has different aspects. The second thing that I believe unites us as our common aim, goal and objective is guaranteeing that Venezuelan citizens have the opportunity, the right and even the duty to express through a democratic, transparent process their political will and determine themselves the future of their country. We are all hoping for a peaceful, constitutional outcome through dialogue, bringing the regime and the opposition together in a credible way and ensuring that democracy, the rule of law and human rights are guaranteed. This is the objective that we share. We will continue to use all our instruments and means to try to accompany the country in this way, but it’s a difficult way, however, I can guarantee you that the channels for dialogue from our side are always open. I think it is the right thing to do at the moment, and I’m glad to have the support of the European Union Member States in our dialogue not only with the Government in Caracas but also with the opposition and with the National Assembly, the legitimate institution of the country. That needs to be recognised. I was glad to meet the President myself, together with the opposition parties, last week. We met here, in this Parliament, by the way. We will continue to coordinate positions with our regional and international partners, from Latin American and Caribbean partners to the United Nations, to the Holy See and others that can help to bring the different parties inside Venezuela back to the negotiating table. We will continue to support and even step up our assistance to a population that needs it. For their generosity in welcoming and supporting Venezuelan people who are crossing the borders at the moment, the neighbouring countries and communities also need to be supported. I mentioned in my opening remarks that we called for a revision of the electoral calendar, but I want to be clear here. For us, a revision of the electoral calendar would also mean the elections being held in different conditions. It’s not just a matter of dates; it’s a matter of how an electoral process is prepared and, for the European Union, it would involve an electoral observation mission. You know that very well because you have lead them across the world. It’s never a matter of one day, the day of the election; it’s about the preparation of the electoral campaign, the participation in elections, the transparency, the open access opportunities for all, the day of the elections and the follow—up of the electoral results. In order to serve the democratic aspirations of the peoples all over the world, all of these processes are subject to some international standards that have recognised criteria and that we, the European Union, follow inside our borders and promote outside of our borders. Again, as most of you have said, we are making no attempt – and even have no desire – to interfere in the domestic politics of a third country. We have enough to worry about in our own domestic politics in the European Union, particularly you, elected Members of the European Parliament. What we care about is that the processes of the democracy in the world are solid, credible and transparent. This is the only purpose we have in our partnership with our Venezuelan friends. As many of you mentioned, there is a strong feeling of friendship between Europeans and Venezuelans. There are close ties, we know each other very well. I myself come from a country, as one of my compatriots has mentioned, that has many Venezuelans – Italy. The situation is the same for Spanish and Portuguese colleagues. We know what we are talking about. There is no antagonism, there is no polarisation, there is a true sense of friendship and communality of purpose here, and it is in this spirit that the European Union offers all its support for a truly democratic, transparent, credible process in Venezuela that I hope can take place inside the country.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: Motions for resolutions to be tabled under Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure will be published later. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 3 May 2018.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on Gilles Pargneaux, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on the Annual Report 2016 on the protection of the European Union's financial interests - combating fraud (2017/2216 (INI)) (A8-0135/2018).

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: rapporteur. — Madam Commissioner, Madam President, as rapporteur on the protection of the European Union's financial interests for 2016, my primary objective is to ensure that public money from taxpayers is used correctly within the European Union. The proper management of public expenditure and the protection of the Union's financial interests must be our priority. For 2016, the results achieved in terms of protecting financial interests and combating fraud are generally positive. The adoption of the directive on the protection of financial interests and the forthcoming creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office are two successes which deserve to be highlighted. These advances will enable us to better protect the money and interests of European taxpayers and facilitate the recovery of fraudulently used Union funds. I regret, however, that all Member States did not wish to participate in the establishment of this European Public Prosecutor's Office (20 out of 28 Member States). In terms of the results itself, I would like to welcome the 15% reduction in fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities and the decrease in their value by 8% compared to 2015. Unfortunately, I am deeply concerned about the still very large number of irregularities in the areas of rural development, cohesion policy and fisheries. I sincerely hope that the simplification of administrative rules announced will reduce the number of non-fraudulent irregularities, detect fraudulent cases and improve beneficiaries' access to Union funds. Secondly, I would like to return to some specific aspects of my report. Firstly, I consider that the undervaluation of customs duties on Chinese products is the major political issue of this report. As you know, between 2013 and 2016, Chinese imports of clothing and footwear destined for the black market were dumped upon entry into the United Kingdom. Pants were declared with a ridiculous value of 91 euro cents per kilo, instead of 26 euros per kilo usually. On 8 March 2018, the European Commission opened infringement proceedings against the United Kingdom in order to recover the €2 billion that would normally have benefited from the EU budget. Commissioner, I would like to welcome the launch of this procedure. In my view, the recovery of this shortfall must be addressed in the context of the Brexit budget negotiations. The Socialist and Democratic Group will pay particular attention to this. Secondly, I call on the European Commission to forward as soon as possible a legislative proposal on the protection of whistleblowers, as requested by the European Parliament's report of 24 October 2017 on this crucial issue. I also encourage the European Commission and the Member States to adopt measures to protect the confidentiality of sources of information in order to prevent any discriminatory action or threat against whistleblowers. Thirdly and recently, I would like to return more fully to our fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products. As chairman of the working group against tobacco industry interference in the European Parliament, I would like to recall that 12% of the 6 trillion cigarettes marketed every year in the world are illicit traded. The consequences are of course health, and as Vice-Chairman of the Committee on the Environment, Health and Food Safety, I would like to point out that counterfeit or smuggling cigarettes are cheaper, more easily accessible for young people and more dangerous. The eradication of the illicit tobacco trade would lead to a 2% reduction in consumption. Faced with this challenge of combating this illicit trade, we must implement a comprehensive strategy to effectively combat this illicit tobacco trade. These are, Commissioner, the various observations or observations I wanted to make to you in my opening remarks on this report on the protection of the Union's financial interests for 2016.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, you know very well that the fight against corruption and fraud is higher on the agenda for the Commission than it is for Parliament. Several hours ago, the Commission President, Jean-Claude Juncker, and the Commissioner for the budget presented the Commission proposal on the post-2020 multi-annual framework. The EU budget is, of course, a means to achieve our joint political goals and to have the resources needed to turn political priorities into tangible results for Europe and for European citizens in order to have a truly positive impact on their lives. To make that happen, however, we must fight fraud and corruption. The financial interests of the Union should be protected through effective measures both on the expenditure and on the revenue side. This includes prevention, detection and investigation of fraud, the recovery of funds and the imposition of penalties. I therefore thank the rapporteur for the Committee on Budgetary Control, Mr Pargneaux, for the good work done on Parliament’s annual report on the protection of financial interests and in particular for taking a holistic approach to the fight against fraud. The result of your work is a comprehensive report, and there is indeed a continuing need for such a holistic and comprehensive approach to combating fraud affecting the EU’s financial interests in all budget areas.  Take the example of regional policy, for which I am responsible. The Union’s main policy to reduce disparities among regions and Member States is a major driver of job creation, sustainable growth and innovation in Europe. According to the Commission’s 2016 report on the protection of the EU’s financial interests, 45% of reported irregularities concerned the area of cohesion policy and fisheries, 2.10% being related to fraud. That is why OLAF has included the protection of cohesion expenditure among its investigation policy priorities and has recommended the recovery of hundreds of millions of euros spent fraudulently in this area.  Only an effective and also a trustworthy and comprehensive system, including, as I have said, prevention, detection, investigations, penalties and recovery, will persuade Member States to support a strong cohesion policy in the future MFF.  Over the last six or seven years, we have progressed significantly in the anti- fraud area at Member State level. The Commission has developed new and innovative concepts. The basis of the Commission anti-fraud strategy and the idea behind the national anti-fraud strategies is that the Commission helps Member States to develop. The Commission fosters the sharing of knowledge and best practice and enables a network to be created among competent authorities of the Member States. We finance dedicated programme projects and put anti-fraud tools guidance at the disposal of Member States. These initiatives have boosted cooperation with and among Member States, but, again, we will do more.  That is why the Commission is currently in the process of reviewing its anti- fraud strategy in the context of the new multi-annual financial framework, taking into account recent changes in the fraud landscape. This new Commission anti-fraud strategy, an update of the strategy dating from 2011, will respond to the major risks affecting new financial interests, for example organised crime. The new strategy might inccorporate oversight of the anti-fraud measures in Commission departments and agencies and strengthen the role of analyses. Let me now turn to the legislative domain. Over the past few years we have together reinforced the legal framework for protection of the Union’s financial interests, achieving significant results. 2017 was a year of great achievement in that respect, with the adoption of two major legislative acts: the regulation establishing the European Public Prosecutor’s Office and the directive on the fight against fraud to the Union’s financial interests by means of criminal law.  Continuing in the same vein, the Commission will later this month adopt a proposal to amend the OLAF Regulation (Regulation (EU, Euratom No 883/2013) to ensure close cooperation with the EPPO and the effectiveness of OLAF’s investigations. The creation of the EPPO is a fundamental advance in the EU approach to fraud affecting its budget. Once European Prosecutor investigation has been set up, we will have two EU bodies with distinct but complementary mandates to investigate in this area. European Prosecutor investigation will increase the effectiveness of the criminal law response to fraud, and it will be in line with European criminal prosecution policy proper, whereas OLAF will complement the Prosecutor’s activities through its administrative investigations. The Commission is currently taking the necessary steps to set up the European Prosecutor’s Office. Our aim is to ensure that it will start operations in late 2020, thus contributing to successful implementation of the new multi-annual financial framework. In order to ensure that all available means are used to counter fraud and other illegal activities affecting the EU budget, the European Prosecutor and OLAF will work in close partnership and be mutually reinforcing, each acting within its own mandate. This is one of the main drivers of the proposal to amend Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 883/2013. The Commission wants OLAF to remain strong and fully functioning so as to complement the European Prosecutor’s criminal law approach with administrative investigation. OLAF’s role will remain essential in several respects. Firstly, OLAF will keep its mandate in all Member States in the area of non-fraudulent irregularities concerning the Union’s financial interests. The EPPO will have no competence for these purely administrative irregularities. Let me give you concrete numbers from the reports that we have been discussing today, which show the impact that non-fraudulent irregularities have on the Union’s financial interests. In 2016, for instance, a total of 19 080 fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities were reported to the Commission, involving a total of approximately EUR 2.97  billion. Out of that figure, 17 700 irregularities were reported as non-fraudulent, with  a financial impact of approximately EUR 2.5 billion. This means that 93% of all irregularities reported in 2016 were not of a criminal nature and thus do not fall within the mandate of the European Prosecutor. Secondly, OLAF will continue its investigations on the same basis as now in Member States not participating in the European Prosecutor’s Office. In those Member States, the national authorities, as well as OLAF, should create the conditions to ensure an effective and equivalent level of protection of the Union’s financial interests throughout the EU. Thirdly, in the Member States participating in the European Prosecutor’s Office, OLAF’s operations will be adjusted. Today, when OLAF encounters possible criminal offences, it can only address a recommendation to national judicial authorities, but with no guarantees as to whether a criminal investigation will be opened. In the future, OLAF will report such suspected offences to the European Prosecutor’s Office and collaborate with it in its investigations in order to complement EPPO operations to the greatest possible degree. OLAF investigations in participating Member States will lay particular emphasis on facilitating recovery and preventing further harm to the new financial legislative measures, thus supplementing the EPPO’s criminal law approach. In coordination with the EPPO, it may need to carry out action to complement an EPPO investigation, for instance in cases where there is a risk related to time or where the amounts at rsik are very high. OLAF must therefore become a close and a dependable partner for the EPPO in the Member States participating in the enhanced cooperation. carry on its work concerning irregularities of a non-criminal nature in all Member States and continue to fulfil its mandate as it does today in non-participating Member States. We will need the strong support of the European Parliament and the European Council to ensure that by the time the EPPO becomes operational, the OLAF Regulation is amended in order to allow full cooperation and the smoothest coexistence with the EPPO. As I have said, we must keep on stimulating, encouraging and also – when necessary – criticising the Commission and the Member States in our efforts, when dealing with fraud and irregularities, to protect Europeans’ financial interests effectively.

name: Barbara KUDRYCKA
text: author of a draft opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. — Madam President! There is no doubt that the responsibility of the EU and national institutions is primarily to take care of taxpayers' money. According to the Commission's 2016 report, the amount of irregularities reported as malfeasance reaches EUR 391 million per year. However, it should be noted that in 2015 this amount was much higher at EUR 640 million. Concern, however, is raised by a rise in VAT fraud. Effective protection of the financial interests of the Union will certainly be provided by the Anti-Fraud Directive in the European Union by Criminal Law (PIF Directive) and the EPPO Regulation, as they grant law enforcement agencies resources that they have not hitherto in the fight against corruption. In turn, the introduction of whistleblower institutions and the call on the Commission and the Member States to give them proper protection should also contribute to a more effective fight against embezzlement of EU funds. The publication by the Commission of annual anti-corruption reports will also allow better monitoring of the situation in the Community. However, in order to avoid transnational fraud, it is necessary to establish closer cooperation between Member States in the area of Eurofisc, OLAF and Eurojust. The creation of an effectively functioning system for the exchange of information within the framework of the cooperation network of Member States will certainly help to further reduce transnational fraud.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President, thank the rapporteur for the report. It is true that efforts have been made to protect the Union's financial interests. It is very good that fraud is being detected and the damage needs to be recovered and, in this respect, there must be very important cooperation between the European Court of Auditors, OLAF and, of course, the future European Public Prosecutor's Office. I hope that all Member States will be part of this office, because it is important for protecting the Union's financial interests. However, I believe that prevention work is also important, because it is more important to prevent and that there is no fraud, and in this respect, I would ask - and there is also this request in the European Parliament's report - to insist heavily on online procedures for the whole chain of bidding, application, tracking projects with European money. I believe that this would help a great deal in prevention and, at the same time, I believe that simplifying procedures, regulations would again be beneficial in this respect.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, from the report on the protection of the financial interests of the Union, as Mr Pargneaux has already pointed out, it is indeed clear that decrease in the total number of reports of fraudulent irregularities. However, it cannot be hidden that the level of fraud on Union funds still remains high and so too are cases of corruption. In this scenario, the PIF Directive and the establishment of the European Prosecutor's Office represent fundamental instruments in combating offences to the detriment of the Union's financial interests and consequently also in contrast to organised crime and terrorism, which often fund themselves through such offences. While waiting for their final entry into force, however, we must continue to strengthen the coordination capacities between the national control structures and ensure that the new OLAF Regulation gives Clear and precise answers on the new system of anti-fraud at administrative level and future relations with the new criminal dimension introduced by the European Prosecutor's Office. In this regard, it cannot fail to underline that the enhanced cooperation with which the European Prosecutor's Office has been set up poses significant challenges on the correct repairs of competences between the criminal dimension and administrative, particularly with respect to non-member countries. The delicate objective that we must also pursue through the European Prosecutor's Office is to improve the system of recovery of illicitly defrauded funds so that this money is returned to the budget of the Union and can be used for the needs of our citizens and I think above all for job creation and for increasing investment by companies. Finally, in this debate, too, it should be stressed that the role that whistleblowers can play should not be underestimated in the fight against fraud. Due to the importance of their contribution and the delicacy of their role, we need a firm commitment from the Commission through a legislative proposal that clearly defines rights and obligations.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President! Commissioner! In fact, you need to better coordinate what you can do today without bringing in additional institutions or bodies. No European prosecutor's office is a panacea in the fight against corruption at EU level. First of all, there is a point, and I say this based on... I will say very bluntly: in preparation for this debate, I spoke to the head of Poland's anti-corruption services. He pointed out two things to me: firstly, the issue of banking secrecy stretched against European Union directives to fight money laundering. Here you need to give more opportunity to access the accounts of various suspicious individuals and structures, then you need to rip and coordinate. Often such stretched banking secrecy is implemented in defiance of EU directives. And the second point is to coordinate data on tax systems across Member States in the European Union. That needs to be very improved, too, because there's no coordination here.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, corruption and fraud are systematically endangering the spending of EU resources in several Member States. In some countries it is affected by organised crime groups, such as in Slovakia. In some others, such as my own country, Hungary, governmental corruption distorts the proper use of EU funds. With all due respect, the Commission, OLAF and the new EPPO have limited resources and capacity to properly control the use of EU funds. Not only the Hungarian or the Slovakian case, but also LuxLeaks, the Panama Papers, the Paradise Papers, taught us how much investigative journalists can do for the protection of the financial interests of the EU. Therefore, it is of direct interest to the EU to invest in media freedom, both legally and financially. The press can perfectly complement the work of other investigative bodies of the EU and the Member States. And we already called for these steps in previous PIF reports as well. So we need, as was mentioned, good protection for whistle-blowers, also anti-SLAPP measures from the Commission, and we need a commitment from the Commission for a fixed budget line in the next MFF after 2020.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (PT) Madam President, I would only like to raise two points: the first relates to VAT, and I would like to express my regret that the European Union, which is ruthless in the face of countries which deviate from the deficit by a few tenths, the same European Union is so permissive towards VAT and will not be able to combat this phenomenon, which represents a loss of EUR 150 billion a year. The second point I wanted to raise is the irregularities that are not fraudulent, as the report says, which are detected in the CAP and which are naturally related to the latest reform of the CAP, which has brought enormous red tape to farmers and which is the cause of a series of irregularities. From this point of view, the conclusions of this report should point to the need to simplify the CAP, because this will be a decisive step in solving part of the problem.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (NL) Mr President, when I saw the subject of this debate, I was somewhat surprised, because I thought that two weeks ago in Strasbourg we discussed the great fight against fraud. We talked about the Selmayr case. And that was the perfect time to do something against clear fraud. Only then did the majority remain silent in this House. And that, Mr President, demonstrates the hypocrisy. Lots of words about fraud, lots of tough words about fraud. But when it really comes down to it and if we can really do something, it stays quiet. But you won't hear me complaining, of course. I'd say keep this up, hold this, keep going. You have already passed the shame here, push it a little further, and then next year at the elections the people in the Netherlands and in the other Member States will know what to vote, and that is against this failed experiment.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: — Madam President, the first and foremost thing to consider is the fact that we are not talking here today about protecting the financial interests of the Union but, above all, about defending the financial interests of European citizens. Money which is directly or indirectly managed by the Union and this maximises the responsibility we all have for the use of this money. I fully agree that much stricter controls should be imposed on the allocation and use of European funds, while at the same time the framework for their use should be made much simpler and clearer in order to avoid cases of mismanagement where there is no deceit but simply ignorance of the regulations. In any event, immediate and much more effective measures must be taken in customs controls to combat the smuggling of tobacco and petroleum products and the trade in illegal and counterfeit products. These types of smuggling cost Europeans many millions of euros every year. They are affecting legal trade and, unfortunately, they have not been sufficiently combated to date. However, I would like to point out that pressure cannot be exerted for proper use of European funds when the institutions of the Union themselves are very often mismanaged and wasted funds.

name: Emil RADEV
text: — Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the annual assessment of the spending of European funds in the form of the report under discussion is extremely important because it contributes to the analysis of the effectiveness of European funding. I am therefore very pleased that there has been a decline in errors and fraud with European funds in general - this means that more money is reaching those who really need it, namely European citizens. At the same time, we must not stop being demanding — every euro cent spent not on purpose is to the detriment of the citizens. In this context, I welcome the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, the adoption of the directive on combating fraud by European funds, as well as the more general anti-money laundering directive, because all these measures will give Member States additional tools to combat all kinds of financial fraud. Effective implementation of the legislation in practice is key in this respect and I hope it will be transposed as soon as possible!

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Madam President, I thank my colleague Gilles Pargneaux for his excellent document and I also appreciate the participation of the Commission, OLAF and the various bodies precisely in combating this fraud which has an sometimes immense impact, as was the case with customs VAT fraud in 2015, which reached 159,5 billion, i.e. almost half more of what Commissioner Oettinger has just told us that we are going to have by the next Horizon 2020. Not to mention border or carousel fraud, or also what Mr Pargneaux has commented on the customs fraud with China that has just been discovered and also the losses caused by tobacco smuggling, which amount to around 10 billion. I mean, we are really talking about very important figures that have to do with something that must definitely be avoided. It therefore welcomes, in the anti-corruption strategy, that it is a reliable system not only at European Union level but also within the Member States, and that the monitoring and traceability of tobacco products are really effective. And, of course, we are committed to the efficiency and capacity of the EPPO, which the sooner it gets started better. And, of course, I thank Mr Pargneaux for his approach to the protection of informants and also investigative journalists, which are absolutely essential for many of these frauds and many of these news to reach the public and, in this way, it is easier to fight them. And, finally, I just want to express a certain concern. In the new commitment to change in the Union's revenue, I see that there is an interest in partly dismantling VAT and other revenues. I'd prefer that we don't dismantle it in any way until we're clear about the new revenue.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Madam President, Jean-Claude Juncker presented to the Commission a few hours ago a draft EU budget for the next seven years. We are now discussing the anti-fraud report on the Union's financial protection. The two are related. Unfortunately, the Cohesion Funds will be reduced by 7%. This means that these funds must be spent even more efficiently and appropriately. The report shows a staggering figure: from 2015 to 2016 irregularities on the cohesion funds increased by 73%. So it is an elementary interest to confront corruption. I propose to those countries which feel themselves involved in these matters to join the European Public Prosecutor's Office, the twenty countries that have voluntarily undertaken this clear, clean form of control.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: — We actually have three areas of such important potential activity. The first ones are scams. And in this area we have seen some success, this amount has fallen from 600 million to 400 million of various commitments that should go to the European Union budget de facto. The second problem is a variety of gaps. Loopholes in the law, loopholes just in the customs area, and that's where all those things go, which are primarily related to tobacco trade, Chinese goods trade, etc. There is still a third area — legislative area — and here, thankfully, we are seeing success, though we would all like to make this success faster, more efficient. If we are talking about different bonuses, different kinds of discounts, then it would be good to reduce them as soon as there are signals about possible abuses. And that's what I want to particularly point out.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that what the Commission presented to us earlier, the MFF, has a great deal to do with the report we are looking at right now. In fact, the minus we found in the Cohesion Fund, the common agricultural policy, the support of SMEs and the other elements of the financial framework presented can be solved, behold, by combating fraud. And the rapporteur also presented well all the colleagues who spoke: what are the leakage and where? Public procurement, the use of European funds, the undervaluation of products, not only from China, of non-European products entering the internal market of the European Union, besides making unfair competition. I would like to point out two things from the report. Firstly, I think that we should focus heavily on prevention, ensure that transparency, but also assistance to staff working in the institutions that manage these funds. Then I think I should - and I support the rapporteur's proposal to have an annual report from the Commission on the use of European funds and bank transfers from the EIB and the EBRD. And I also regret that we no longer have that public report on combating corruption. This is the rapporteur's proposal and I support it.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Madam President, tackling fraud at European Union and Member State level must be our priority. Mrs Crețu, I have repeatedly referred, in this Chamber, to the way NGOs manage European Union funds which go to support refugees in Greece. More than EUR 500 million are available. Yet the funds are managed by the NGOs with complete opacity. NGOs literally throw parties, don't account to anyone, and it's time to check them out. Where does this money go? How are they exploited? Let me also give you an example: Today in Samos, an island 180 miles away from Piraeus, ten hours away from Piraeus, 3,133 portions of food were distributed. These rations came from Piraeus. They have been thawed and warmed in Samos, to be distributed to refugees. This happens every day. Do you think it's right?
