It is possible to send ready-made food catering from Athens to the island of Samos, which refugees do not even eat; they throw it away! This is the reality! We need to make a check. We have to get OLAF in.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Thank you, Mr. Marias. I hope that you will be able to prove what you just said, too, because these are already serious accusations. You should be very careful about that.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, the explicit reference by name to tobacco smuggling and the differentiation between fraudulent and non-irregularities in any errors committed is correct. However, irrespective of its targeting, any suggestion in procedural procedures of investigating cases under national jurisdiction is unfounded. The recommendations of the institutions of the Union as prosecution or other judicial action shall be left to the competent national authorities and shall not constitute an obligation under the current regime and legal order. Finally, the planned link between the rule of law and the management of the funds appropriately paid is abusive and the intended cessation is a discriminatory attitude towards the Member States concerned. In short, despite some positive reports, the report in its present form is a data gathering and a lobbying vehicle for purposes not related to the subject of the report, despite the fact that it is a requirement and necessity to combat all fraud, illegality and a source of dispute over the proper functioning of a state.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Madam President, this morning we started the debate with the Commission on the multiannual financial framework, in a context where the cohesion and solidarity items that matter so much to your regional policy portfolio are decreasing. Although the incorporation of own resources is clear, however, the disappearance of the VAT resource, which has resulted in the fight against fraud, which imports millions of euros at a time of scarce resources to meet the Union's essential needs and cohesive policies, is being discussed. OLAF, Eurojust and Europol must coordinate their efforts in the fight against fraud, but, above all, they must underpin, with their experience, the implementation of the EPPO as soon as possible and with the incorporation of the largest number of States. And, of course, we should also see, as soon as possible, the fulfilment of the Commission's commitment, which has long been called for in each of the committees of inquiry which we have held in this European Parliament, the establishment of a comprehensive procedural, criminal procedure, protection of the complainant, the perpetrator, the informant, the wistleblower, which underlines the importance of fraud and combating it at European level.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. — Madam President, I believe that in our debate today it has become clear that the protection of the European Union's financial interests is of paramount importance, both for the Commission and for you as co-legislators, and I hope that we will continue to we are working together to improve this mechanism that is already working. There have been a lot of numbers. Here, I can tell you that in the framework of cohesion policy, for three years since I have been Commissioner, we have seen decreases, but indeed we have greatly increased the number of projects that we are trying to verify. But for the first time, the error rate was below 5%, of which only 0.5% means fraud. So in the rest there are irregularities, which represent public procurement, and I believe that this new multiannual financial framework presented by President Juncker and the Commissioner for the Budget today will also bring about an improvement, a strengthening of the protection of financial interests, which is already very top on the agenda of the European Commission. Because for us what matters is the final result of spending European taxpayers' money. I am convinced and I know that the Commission is not alone in this battle, and we count on the support of the European Parliament to continue this fight. I am convinced that on 29 May, when the Commission presents the new sectoral rules, we will come up with more transparency, which has been called for here, a simplification of the rules and, already in the Omnibus procedure, we have introduced some issues relating to transparency and the fight against corruption, the need to have machines that we can rely on in the States, because it has unfortunately been proven that 70% of irregularities could have been detected at national level and have not been reported. So, from this point of view, I would like to respond to Mrs Grappini and to those who have raised this subject before on the report: you know very well that the integrity and the fight against corruption are revealed in the European Semester for each country; and Mr Marias: I invite you to address the European Commission, to address the Commissioner for Budget, Mr Günther Oettinger, I also call on you to address OLAF with exact data because, as the President of hearing, I think what you have signaled, would be very serious, if that were true. So thank you very much and, as I said, you can count on the European Commission to encourage us, stimulate us, give us ideas on how we could better protect the European interest and money of citizens and their impact on the ground. Thank you very much, because I think that's what the trust and the connection between Europeans and what we do. Perhaps we are not saying enough and I think it is a mistake to concentrate, there are indeed many irregularities, but on the other hand, on the whole, if we see what cohesion policy has done, agriculture policy and how much they have contributed to the growth of gross domestic product, I am convinced that we must we see the big picture, and not everything in black. As regards the fight against corruption, we are doing everything we can and working with the Member States, with OLAF, now, more recently, with the European Public Prosecutor's Office, so we have every confidence that we can detect any irregularities in time to protect the European money.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Thank you, Commissioner. In fact, less than 5% fraud means more than 95% no fraud. This must also be emphasized.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, Commissioner, a big thank you to all colleagues for the positive remarks and comments on my report. Commissioner, in the remaining minute I wanted to tell you that many of our colleagues have addressed this necessary fight against the illicit tobacco trade and thus, as I said in my report, simply draw your attention to a few points. First, not to renew the European Union's cooperation agreements with British American Tobacco, Japan Tobacco International and Imperial Tobacco Limited, as we did in relation to Philip Morris on 9 July 2016. Secondly, to encourage nine remaining Member States — Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Greece, Ireland, the Netherlands, Slovenia, Sweden and the United Kingdom — to ratify the Protocol of the World Health Organisation to eliminate illicit trade in tobacco products very quickly, and to bring the tax levels closer to the level of taxation of the tobacco products in Europe. Those are the remarks I wanted to make to conclude our debate.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday, 3 May 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. — The Commission's seriousness with regard to financial corruption can be doubted, given its lack of zeal in the fight against tax havens. Similarly, the tragedy of the assassination of two investigative journalists were not the subject of the attention that the gravity of the facts demanded. Certain fraud, such as the VAT carousel system, are made possible only by the abolition of controls at the internal borders of the European Union. However, given the size of the amounts at stake, as VAT fraud caused a shortfall of around €50 billion (2015), there is an urgent need to increase the police and judicial response. However, I cannot associate myself with the proposal for a European Public Prosecutor's Office, which would violate the national sovereignty of the Member States in judicial matters. Similarly, I challenge OLAF's legitimacy in carrying out any investigation, a fortiori in order to condemn certain Member States to monetary penalties. This body does not adhere to conflicting trial rules, and clarifications must also be made on its investigative methods.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. — I am pleased that after four years of negotiations, we reached agreement in November 2016 on a proposal for a directive to combat the fraud of the Union's financial interests through criminal law. Moreover, recent analyses show that the total number of non-fraud and non-fraud irregularities reported in 2016 decreased by 15% from 2015 and the value of these irregularities decreased by 8% (from EUR 3.21 billion in 2015 to EUR 2.97 billion in 2016). It is worth remembering that not all irregularities constitute fraud and that it should be clearly distinguished from mistakes made. In this context, it will be necessary to strengthen the cooperation of the European Commission with Member States in detecting fraud. An additional problem is that, until now, not all Member States have adopted national strategies for combating such abuses, so it will be necessary to support the EC in this area too. In conclusion, preventive measures carried out by the European Commission and OLAF have a significant impact on reducing the level of abuse in EU spending are essential. Such activities include better implementation of EDES systems and the anti-fraud information system (AFIS), as well as implementing national anti-fraud strategies.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - This report also contains extremely important warnings about the damage caused by corruption and fraud that jeopardises the financial interests of the Union and thus the democratic functioning of the Member States and the trust of citizens. Today, the risk of fraud at European level has entered a quality. Corruption targeting our community resources has emerged from the sphere of criminality and appears as a systemic fraud organised at least in one Member State — from government level, with the help of key players in the local judiciary. This is one of the most urgent legal and now serious political challenges for the EU institutions and Member States today. This challenge currently manifests itself in the most obvious form in the corruption network built by the Hungarian Orbán Government, which ensures the maintenance of the regime by almost complete expropriation of EU funds and public procurement. The recognition of the problem, although delayed, is evidenced by OLAF reports, a series of infringement procedures, and more recently by the proposal of Article 7 procedure, but the current instruments of EU law have failed to prevent both political and personal governmental corruption. Both the interests of the European taxpayer and the Hungarian population urge the EU to take decisive political action at the highest level against Orban and its possible followers. The establishment of the Office of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and its coordinated operation with OLAF and other EU institutions, as well as encouraged by the report, and encouraging the remaining Member States to join as soon as possible.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Andrey Novakov, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on the implementation of cohesion policy and the thematic objective 'Promoting transport sustainability and eliminating bottlenecks in key network infrastructures' (Article 9 Paragraph 7 of the Common Provisions Regulation (2017/2285 (INI) (A8-0136/2018).

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: rapporteur. — Dear Madam President, Commissioner, from the beginning, I would like to thank everyone who took part in the writing of this report and helped to achieve, I believe, a good result. I would also like to thank the coordinator, Mr Nistelrooy, for also devoting some of his efforts to completing this report in time. When the European Union starts building roads that save potentially hundreds of casualties, when the European Union starts connecting villages, towns and families with its motorways, when the Union, thanks to the roads and railways it builds, starts saving tens of hours on travelers, then we begin to speak in a language understandable to people. Then the European Union is not a distant, imaginary being to people, but starts to be something they understand and believe in and feel empathetic. The title of my report is quite long and complicated, although the aim behind it is very simple: to show that in the last ten years, the European Union has never achieved more in investment in transport infrastructure. Moreover, I am pleased that this report comes so on time, just two hours after the draft of the next Multiannual Financial Framework was presented. We had a very simple goal. Firstly, to assess how useful and effective the investments were in 2007-2013, see at half-time how we are doing in the current programming period and make recommendations for the next one. I think we did well. However, it is obvious that we have a place to improve the way in which the Union operates. Last but not least, each of you, I am sure, knows that to complete the Ten-T network in the European Union, we need half a trillion euros. I am not sure that we are close to finding these funds, but we are obliged to say: if we succeed in doing so, and we are obliged to, the European Union will provide almost 10 million new jobs and will provide an additional 2% on an annual basis to the economic growth of The union. This is not about neglect. Moreover, if we have to put aside the kilometres, ports, motorways, railways, we have one main objective when we talk about transport in the Union, and that is that Eastern and Western Europe, Northern and Southern Europe remain only geographical concepts. So good to have connected the regions between them that we can overcome distances within hours that we can really say: we have free movement of people, goods and capital without having to wait at the borders or having to, despite the beautifully constructed roads, some country say: for me it is not a priority, and having to have so-called “Botonex”. It's not permissible. I believe that it is quite possible to take a step forward, and I am sure that in the framework of this debate we will all unite around the view that the grant from the European Union's cohesion policy has no alternative, especially when we talk about transport, especially in regions that do not can afford to attract private investment for this purpose. I thank everyone once more for joining this debate and I look forward to the opinion of all of you with interest.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, first and foremost of course I would like to congratulate Mr Novakov, the rapporteur, for this comprehensive and very balanced report. As you rightly underlined, there are many success stories brought by EU transport investments over the last decade. You mentioned the completion of the motorway linking Sofia to the Black Sea, but this section of the Orient/East-Med corridor is indeed very strategic. Coupled with ongoing works along the Rhine-Danube corridor, it has contributed to improving the connectivity between the Western Balkans/Greece and Central Europe. I also have in mind the significant improvements, for instance, brought to the high-speed rail network in Spain, the metro extension in Warsaw, and the line recently inaugurated between Munich and Berlin. Of course we need to continue to be ambitious about our transport policy, and this message was very strongly sent and widely conveyed during the TEN-T days in Ljubljana last week. I was there, Commissioner Bulc was there, also Vice-President Šefčovič, and also Commissioner for the budget Mr Ottinger. I am please to confirm that the Commission proposal of the new multiannual financial framework reflects our high ambitions in the transport field, also within the future cohesion policy. If we want to make our transport fit for the future, we must solve, as we said, once and for all the persisting bottlenecks and missing links, especially across borders. Beyond infrastructure, transport must become cleaner and more efficient by promoting multimodality and by driving forwards the digitisation and decarbonisation of the sector. I hear your call for the promotion of alternative and innovative mobility, and I think that we can do it thanks to the cohesion policy. Its long-term, cross-cutting and cross-border development strategies offer the right frame both for action and for reform. So ladies and gentlemen, I can assure you that cohesion policy will remain a decisive catalyst for sustainable transport investments. Of course, we need to take into account new ways of supporting such investments, and financial instruments can play an important role in this regard for certain bankable  projects, but I agree with you: I think in most cases, grants remain the most effective. We will ensure better coordination between cohesion policy and the Connecting European Facility in the next financial framework, and of course I would like to thank the rapporteur for this high-quality project. I am looking forward to hearing your views, because it is a very important debate for me and for all of us.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. — Madam President! Commissioner! It is not for nothing that the most excitement about the future budget is stirring up spending on cohesion policy The needs in this area are and will still be huge, and many key infrastructure projects, including the most important one, which is the TEN-T network, are still in the implementation phase. We need an integrated European transport network: not only motorways or high-speed rail, but also modern infrastructure with local and regional coverage, where capacity, traffic jams or safety problems are greatest. Funding for the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund must be maintained at a high level primarily because the cohesion policy objectives are still not met and the differences between the state of infrastructure in the eastern and western parts of the Union are still very visible.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (NL) Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur, we can indeed learn a lot from what has now been outlined on expenditure on transport. We also see that different funds can work together very well. It has also been said a moment ago: part of it is about Ten-T, but there is much more than it is in terms of modalities, mobility and, on the other hand, the underlying road network, which is supported in a very good way in the INTERREG programmes, for example. That is also important. What we have learned is that there is a different way to put pressure on the Member States. Look, in the period 2007-2014, we had the experience that, of course, the Cohesion Fund provided billions in support, but that Member States often looked at their own problems around cities, improved road or rail, or built airports without looking at the other. And what has been said now: the billions we have taken out of the Cohesion Fund and put into that CEF give you the opportunity to reach commitments quickly. If you don't do that, central management is over it. Surely this has the noses that were directed down to the self of the Member State's own self, more towards the other. It's got the noses pointing at each other. It contains an important learning point which we will certainly use for the next period — Mr Novakov was also looking for. The bringing together of studies, of Member States and within them — as the CEF actually does — the designation of tractors, of leaders on various issues of ports and transport has worked. So my conclusion is in particular: the method has worked. Let us continue this way in the new period.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: on behalf of the S&D Club. — Madam Chairman, I thank the rapporteur for their cooperation and accepted proposals. We agree, of course, that adequate transport connectivity is a prerequisite for the full potential of the single market and that all parts of the Union deserve to be adequately linked. Regardless of insufficiency, if it concerns islands, or inaccessible terrain, if it is mountainous and sparsely populated areas. Estimates indicate that economic losses due to insufficient transport connectivity amount to up to 1% of the Union's annual gross social product. Thus, the benefit of developing an adequate transport network is multifaceted. But when discussing the future development of transport infrastructure and optimal connectivity, we also need to think about what kind of infrastructure we develop. The aim of today's debate is to promote sustainable traffic and eliminate bottlenecks. It looks forward that the report contains proposals that further shift the sustainability of transport solutions, smart mobility, multi-day and clean transport and urban mobility, as well as, of course, the safety of passengers in traffic. A particular challenge is the further development of rail infrastructure; it notes a significantly lower utilisation rate of available funds. In the existing financial framework of 7,000 km of railway lines planned for reconstruction, a decision was made for only 980 km, and of the planned 628 km of new railway lines, the procedure was confirmed for only 16 km. Cohesion policy should therefore continue to have a thematic emphasis, while allowing some degree of flexibility to take into account the specific needs of each region. Not the same circumstances are in decidedly urban or rural areas, so-called lagging regions, as well as regions with permanent natural or geographic constraints. Only in this way can we achieve the fundamental objective - improving and uniformity of the functioning of the Single European Market, facilitating the free flow of people, goods and services throughout the European Union. All citizens of the Union deserve equal access to transport infrastructure, and those living in geographically deprived areas deserve a better chance of sustainable development.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. — Madam Chairman, quality transport infrastructure is a prerequisite for stable economic growth and development. In addition to facilitating the transport of goods and making products and services more accessible and affordable, it acts as a stimulating effect on labour mobility and hence employment. Investments in transport infrastructure are one of the best ways to achieve cohesion goals. In this context, I must welcome the elimination of the last obstacles to the construction of the Peljesac Bridge in Croatia. Although we have witnessed various attempts to blackmail from certain structures in neighbouring Bosnia and Herzegovina, the political and financial support provided by the European Union to this project has shown that the Union knows its priorities and will not yield to obstruction behind which other people's geopolitical interests hide. The same position should be taken with other infrastructure projects that strengthen the Union at its external borders. Our priority must always be the security of our borders and a stable and supportive environment for the development of the Member States of the Union.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (NL) Mr President, investments in transport infrastructure under cohesion policy produce concrete and visible results. Transport projects contribute to reducing the delays in development in parts of Europe. We were able to see this with a delegation from the Committee on Regional Development itself, for example in Sofia, where the European Union invests in the metro. But investment in infrastructure — I would like to emphasise — also strengthen the internal market. We often say in the Netherlands: without transport everything stands still. Mr Novakov's report quite rightly outlines the challenges facing transport infrastructure after 2020: the completion of the trans-European transport network, the sustainability of transport and the application of innovations. These are all very important challenges. To this end, after 2020, we must all use complementary resources from the Connecting Europe Facility, the Cohesion Fund, the European Regional Development Fund, as well as funding from the European Investment Bank. I would also like to call for more resources from the European Regional Development Fund, particularly for cross-border investment projects in sustainable transport infrastructure in Europe. The INTERREG programmes can be used perfectly for this. In this way, with the resources of the European Regional Development Fund, we can invest in missing links in the infrastructure in our border regions, and then, Mr President, we can actually connect citizens of Europe.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, the truth is that it is a shame that we missed the opportunity to take advantage of this report to deal with the socio-economic model, globalisation, competitiveness, the single market, the need for a steady increase in infrastructure and its capabilities. Before we assume that we need more and better infrastructure, it would be necessary to propose changes in the model to make it more balanced, more decentralized, thus avoiding the enormous transport of goods and workers, the gap between cities and rural areas and tensions between overpopulation in some areas and depopulation of others. Nor do I agree with the approach given to public/private partnerships by offering public guarantees, i.e. citizens' money, to private investments. Spain is using more than two billion euros of public money to rescue several private investment highways. Moreover, there has not been enough emphasis on public passenger transport, especially rail, for both goods and passengers, which is the most sustainable and at the same time cleaner means. Nor has the necessary attention been paid to abandoned conventional railway lines, which have great potential in terms of maintaining social and territorial cohesion, as well as in the fight against depopulation.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, the major European transport routes serve in particular to transport the production obtained by undoubted social dumping to the four corners of the continent. Mr rapporteur, you claim that your aim is to 'build a solid single market for a competitive Europe'. True, but at what price? Making slaves manufactured to sell to the unemployed is in fact the real currency of the European Union and essential transport infrastructure is one of the tools. You want to fight bottlenecks by facilitating the passage of more and more trucks. What matters are human or ecological consequences, since this will allow the most important: to increase the profits of opportunistic companies. As to respect for the environment, I note that while the sustainability of transport is once again branched like a standard, there is nothing in this report on the essential role that rail and river transport could play in combating these bottlenecks.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: — Madam President, we have a strong European transport policy, represented by the European Networks Regulation. Important investment is needed, both at national and European level. At European level these investments are made through the Regional Development Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the CEF. Unfortunately, from what I saw in today's proposal, all three of these funds are falling in the post-2020 proposal. On the other hand, Member States were obliged to present a transport strategy by 2030. I think it would be useful to have in Parliament, from the Commission, a map of what the Member States are proposing to complement the networks, the basic network, in particular, transport networks. I think there is a need for better coordination between DG MOVE and DG REGIO, because the money is mostly at DG REGIO, only it is for transport and DG MOVE should have a much more important say in terms of the investments being made to complement these corridors extraordinarily important transport for the European economy. So, in my opinion, in the following regulations we should see some cooperation procedures between the two Directorates-General so that we can discuss in the near future the completion of transport corridors.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Dear Commissioner, this is a particular moment for the future of the European Union, this, with the presentation of the next multiannual financial framework, and therefore it is important to discuss the line we would like to give to the European Union over the next few years. As you can imagine, we have some concern about cohesion policy, because, as my colleagues said, we need adequate resources that can cover all the European regions, all the policies that are needed. are within cohesion policy. We know that in the years ahead there will be a dizzying increase in both freight and passenger transport, in the various forms available. We cannot let this process go on its own: it's about steering it much more towards collective infrastructure — fast trains, but also better local transport, because otherwise not there is interconnectedness — which require heavy investment, and it is a field in which the EFSI and the Structural Funds can probably work synergistically. It is therefore very important that these investments are allowed and that the financial framework is adequate.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: — We are discussing the report on communication routes in the European Union and their financing. Approximately one-third of the European Structural and Investment Funds allocated to the development of transport networks is positively adopted by citizens of the Union. As noted in the report, congestion in Europe costs around 1% of the annual GDP of Union countries. The report in point F lists explicit modernization of the Kraków—Rzeszów railway road. It would be good to continue this policy direction on the eastern wall of the European Union and support the expansion of multimodal transport networks, namely rail, road and water. Point 8 refers to cross-border waterways, so I am already paying attention to reserve appropriate funds for the E40 waterway, which is to connect the Baltic Sea to the Black Sea, and part of which is to run through my district of Lubelszczyń.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, Commissioner, today more than ever it is particularly timely to discuss sustainable transport, as it seems that Cohesion Fund money is decreasing but at the same time the challenges for both sustainable transport and tackling climate change are increasing. It is therefore necessary more than ever for the Member States to mobilise all available tools, whether it be the Cohesion Fund, the EFSI of the Juncker project, the Connecting Europe Facilities or the private sector together. Sustainable transport must place the emphasis on railways, something that we often omit here, but the Member States also fail. But we must also take into account the energy mix of transport at the same time. Certainly infrastructures that talk about electrification of cars, infrastructures that refer to dry power supply of docked ships but also the broadening of the use of LNG, the facilitation of access to renewable energy sources and especially biofuels facilitate end-users and make transport more sustainable. It is therefore necessary, in addition to infrastructure planning, to look at the parameter of the sustainability of the energy mix and tackling climate change, which are also included in the new spirit of the budget from 2020-2027.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: — Madam President, transport infrastructure is an important driver of regional development. An efficient transport network is essential for sustainable economic growth as well as for territorial balance. The lagging regions face problems of economic development, which are partly due to inappropriate and insufficient transport systems and poor connections with other regions in the countries or other regions within the EU. This applies to all modes of transport. Without efficient transport networks, residents of more remote regions or geographically isolated cities threaten to be cut off from services and jobs. It follows that it is investment in better connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure that also fosters the development of the most backward regions, thereby wiping away regional disparities. It is therefore extremely important that, even after 2020, investment in transport infrastructure is a priority in any budget of the European Union.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, despite all our efforts, we still have populations and regions in this Union with few transport alternatives, which has negative implications for its sustainable economic development. A good transport network is also essential for the reversal of depopulation trends in certain regions and for strengthening the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the European Union. In the particular case of the outermost regions, given their excessive dependence on air transport, there is an urgent need to increase investment in the security of their airports, such as Madeira airport, which requires increased attention, much as a result of climate change. I would also like to point out, in connection with this report, that de facto grants must remain the main source of funding. On the other hand, I am not opposed to private investment, but we must avoid any contracts that are abusive and detrimental to the public interest in public-private partnerships. Therefore, we must also prevent the establishment of monopolies that distort the market and healthy competitive practice.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank Mr Novakov for an important and useful report. If the numbers in the next MFF are anything like those in the first debate today – and I very much hope that they can be improved upon – then cohesion policy is going to need to be smarter. The transport projects in which we invest are going to need to deliver results, and the bottlenecks approach is the right way to go in terms of leveraging spend in the network, but in taking effective decisions, it is best that we can use the right sort of information, the right sort of evidence. There is a strong case for the directorates-general investing in effective modelling technologies that enable us to demonstrate economic return, added value, modal shift and wider network impact. Also, as we work towards the goals of the Paris climate targets, the bottlenecks to sustainable transport may prove to be bottlenecks in the power networks that we need to power that transport. We need to bear that in mind.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: We now come to the procedure for spontaneous speeches. Since a great many speakers have spent their time, I will only allow one person from each of the groups that have come forward to speak to save some time. Spontaneous Speaking

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: — Madam President, the Union's transport policy does indeed have the way to be a real success in the Union. Member States access specific funds to develop their transport systems, to develop transport support infrastructures, to be more efficient, more developed and better responsive to various situations. The outermost regions have specific and increased particularities and therefore the Union's transport policy must look at these regions with their special features. I would remind you that both port and airport infrastructure need support from the Union. That is why I have already addressed a question to the Commission, I have presented a pilot project so that airport infrastructure in the outermost regions will pay special attention to cases of increasingly occurring climate constraints and changes.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: — Madam President, the report presented underlines the importance of developing interconnection platforms. It combines this plan with the need for Europe to focus on sustainability, integrating global warming mitigation into cohesion policy. The transition to sustainable transport is therefore a need that will contribute to the achievement of the European Union's CO2 reduction targets. The Azores, where I come from, as the western border of Europe, situated between continental Europe and North America, have been positioning themselves to respond to these challenges. They want to do so by creating a supply station for vessels with liquefied natural gas based on a logistics hub located in the oceanic port of Praia da Vitória. These are projects like this that intensify cohesion, combining new economic opportunities, environmental objectives and greater efficiency in the use of infrastructure, which should deserve unconditional support in the post-2020 strategy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, sustainable transport is particularly important for the islands, especially for the islands in Greece, which, because of their distance from the mainland, have a competitive disadvantage. This, Mrs Crețu, applies in particular to the Aegean islands, which are affected by huge migratory flows. Thus, the problem of distance can be tackled by introducing the equivalent of transport, that is to say, the harmonization of the tariff burden on the user of sea transport with inland transport, which is called Road Equivalent Tariff. This can be financed as a process by the European Regional Development Fund. I ask you, Mrs Crețu, whether you agree to use funds from the European Regional Development Fund to finance the transport equivalent for the Aegean islands, and I ask you whether the Greek Government has raised this issue with you, whether it has requested your cooperation, in order to institutionalise the transport equivalent for the Aegean islands.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, our Union makes sense, gains followers and is better understood, and is closer to people, when it is useful. The impetus from the Community institutions to investment in infrastructure, which add European value to state plans, is useful. It helps to connect us better, eliminates bottlenecks between Member States, reduces emissions, combats saturation, improves the combination between modes of transport and encourages cross-border cooperation. That is, it builds Europe, assists economic and social development and creates jobs. In my country we have an example with the Basque “Y”, a priority project since the 1990s. I therefore support the strengthening of Community capacity to boost this type of investment, raising levels of investment support, and the application of the principle of use or losing, in order to clearly identify priorities and encourage their implementation within the deadlines to complete the trans-European networks provided for in the TTENs. To analyse from this perspective the debate on infrastructure in Europe is the best way to collaborate with European construction and to preserve it from populism and false news.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. — Madam President, in light of your interventions, I think we share the same view. Firstly, that in our policy, in cohesion policy, transport must remain the main engine for sustainable and sustainable investment in transport. Some of you have also given concrete examples showing us, as I said, that we have achieved a great deal over the years with the help of European funds to improve the European transport network. Of course, I understand that some of you would like more funding for transport. Today, in relative terms, 20% of cohesion policy funding goes in the field of transport and mobility. In my experience, cohesion policy has been particularly important by establishing these ex-ante conditionalities, which have helped or sometimes forced Member States to develop a long-term strategy and to strike a balance between territorial development and development transport. To be honest, I think that what is crucial in the years to come, it is important, first of all, to have reserves of mature, quality projects, especially in the less developed regions of the Member States. Because, frankly, for many Member States, we have allocations waiting to be consumed here in Brussels and we do not have complete projects submitted, I am talking about feasibility studies, cost-benefit analyses, environmental agreements. So, from my point of view, I think that very often administrative capacity is much more important than the allocations, than the money that exists. We will continue to do our work in each Member State and with the same dedication we will provide technical assistance and consultancy services. As regards the issue, raised specifically, relating to the outermost regions, Madeira and the Azores, you know very well that we in the Commission have already adopted a Communication granting specific status to these outermost regions, but allocations are in the hands of the national authorities. As for the Greek islands, you also know very well that I visited them. It is a matter that I have discussed many times with governments. I think I have said several times that what you have asked for is a decision which is again for the Greek Government to introduce this issue into the operational programmes for the post-2020 period.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: rapporteur. — Dear Madam President, I would like to thank everyone who took part in the debate. Commissioner, there are 28 flags from 28 Member States behind you. Thank you for being in every one of these countries and for showing the human face of cohesion policy, promoting so many projects in each of them. It is also this report, a business card of what we can achieve. I believe there are success stories from Derry to Nicosia and from Madeira all the way to Helsinki and that is the direction we need to go. I am a little disappointed that in the proposal for the next Multiannual Financial Framework there has been a slight increase in the money under the 'Agenda for a Connected Europe'. If we do not provide sufficient funding for these projects, third countries will be found to do so, and then we would risk our European standards and objectives that we have set ourselves. I believe that from now on, we must also pay attention to new criteria. Gross domestic product per capita doesn't give us the whole picture. Before investing in roads, let's see what the state of road infrastructure is and concentrate our efforts and our investments where it is most needed. Then our success is more visible, then we become more understandable to people. I believe we are on the right track. The mere fact that this report is one of the first to talk about the assessment of the past programming period and an interim review of the current one in relation to transport is encouraging. I also think it is very timely and will have an impact on how we continue to spend money on transport in the future. I also believe that from now on, whatever we have done for transport infrastructure will be upgraded and we will use it as an example of how the European Union can work in cooperation with individual Member States, individual municipalities. I'm sure we'll be successful and people will appreciate it. For the next 12 months, this will be our job.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Thank you, rapporteur. You are also one of the few who has always kept to the speaking times. Thanks for that too. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday, 3 May 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — Only a more integrated approach to investment in transport infrastructure and stronger cross-border cooperation can remove bottlenecks. The importance of EU cohesion policy has been recognised particularly at regional and local levels, while investment in EU transport infrastructure is one of the policies that deliver the highest added value of the EU. I strongly support the elimination of transport infrastructure deficiencies associated with the Western Balkans, particularly with regard to integration processes through the Commission's communication on the European perspective of the Western Balkans, and in this context I emphasize the importance of European territorial cooperation and macro-regional strategies for integrated projects in the field of transport. The Connecting Europe Facility (CEF), KF and EFRR and in the next programming period should be the EU's core sources for investment in transport infrastructure. In this context, smart traffic and digitisation enable more efficient use of existing infrastructures and redirect traffic to periods of reduced load

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: in writing. — The situation in the European Union in terms of transport capacity is, unfortunately, worse year after year. This is due to the increasingly frequent free movement of citizens inside the European Union and to the increase in the scale of transport of goods. This reflects the annual increase in production, noticeable especially in the last three years, and the expansion of co-operating associations. The only effective way to solve communication problems is to introduce an efficient and integrated European transport area. Extending rail services and inland navigation would be particularly important. The true common European market for rail services requires its opening up to competition, integrated management of freight transport corridors and non-discriminatory access to rail infrastructure. An underrated still type of transport is inland navigation. There are still very large reserves in its development, the release of which would require the elimination of numerous technical, organizational and legal barriers. For it is the most economically and socially efficient mode of transport, the added value of which is a beneficial effect on environmental protection.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on stalking offence and victim protection in the EU (2018/2665 (RSP)).

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, we are grateful to have the opportunity to address this important issue today. Let me start by stressing that stalking is harmful behaviour of a complex nature and most often a form of serious psychological gender-based violence that as such can go against our fundamental rights and values such as human dignity and equality.  Stalking is a matter of great concern and may result in serious emotional suffering and distress. It is most frequently of women, who are threatened by former or current partners and often subject to repeated victimisation. Therefore, it requires appropriate attention at all levels from the European Union and its Member States.  Our challenge in this respect is both to ensure prevention and repressive measures and to guarantee appropriate protection for the victims of stalking anywhere in the European Union. We should place their rights at the centre of all relevant initiatives and actions in our countries and across the Union.  The Council shares the concerns expressed by the European Parliament in its report of 14 March 2018 on the implementation of the European Protection Order Directive, in particular as regards cross-border cases, where victims, having obtained protection measures in one Member State, move to another Member State. There are differences in Member States’ legal systems as regards the criminalisation – or not – of stalking and in respect of the protection measures guaranteed. The Council believes that, despite these differences, we should pursue the common objective of ensuring adequate and equivalent protection of victims throughout the Union.  The Council has played a significant role both as a co-legislator and within other initiatives in respect of this sensitive issue. The European Union legal framework that we have established contains a comprehensive set of rules that, if fully implemented, can contribute to broad and effective protection of victims across the European Union.  The European Protection Order may not be applicable to all cases of stalking, as it is not currently recognised as a criminal offence in all Member States, but the Council shares the view that the expected EU accession to the Istanbul Convention – and possibly its ratification by Member States whih have not yet done so – should contribute to a more effective and coherent response to this form of violence.  The European Protection Order Directive has to be considered in conjunction with the Victims’ Rights Directive. That instrument provides for additional protection measures and for procedural rights for victims of crime. However, there are also other EU legal instruments that strengthen the position of victims, namely the Compensation Directive and the Regulation on mutual recognition of protection measures in civil matters. Stalking was explicitly mentioned by the Council in its conclusions from 2014 on the need to prevent and eliminate all forms of violence against women. Since then, the Council has – on several occasions – recalled this commitment and invited Member States to sign and ratify the Istanbul Convention.  The Council has also taken non-legislative initiatives for victim protection, in particular, the establishment of the European Network on Victims’ Rights aimed at enhancing cooperation between the competent authorities of the Member States and the access of victims to their rights. As of January this year, ENVR has a permanent organisation. It held its kick-off meeting on 23-24 April 2018 in Budapest.  The Presidency devotes particular attention to combatting all forms of gender-based violence. As a matter of fact, draft Council Conclusions on improving police co-operation in combating domestic violence and violence against women are currently being discussed, with particular focus on the protection of vulnerable victims within a multidisciplinary approach. The text of the conclusions draws on replies to a questionnaire which also covered stalking and will be submitted to the Justice and Home Affairs Council for adoption on 5 June.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for putting this point on the agenda of the plenary today. The definition of stalking included in the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence, in its Article 34, is that it is the intentional conduct of seriously impairing a person’s psychological integrity through coercion or threats. Stalking can lead to subsequent assault. In all cases, it leaves its victims extremely vulnerable. The Istanbul Convention obliges Member States to criminalise this behaviour, and 19 Member States have done so in the process of their ratification of the Istanbul Convention. All of us here should continue to push for the ratification of the Convention by the rest of the Member States. I thank all of you who have been active on this issue. I am planning to visit those Member States that have not yet ratified the Convention. I stand ready to discuss the proposal both with citizens and with political representatives, and I will explain and try to dismantle many myths surrounding it. Two of the Member States which have not ratified the Convention have, however, criminalised stalking. These are the United Kingdom and Ireland. The Commission is aware of the differences in the legal systems of the Member States and of the fact that their national protection measures differ in scope, duration and nature. Where stalking is classified as a crime under national law, its victims can rely on all rights under the 2012 Victims’ Rights Directive. This means that such victims have a right to access to information, support and protection according to their individual needs. It is therefore crucial that Member States treat stalking as a crime. Let me underline that the right to have access to victim support services is not dependent on a formal complaint with regard to a criminal offence. This means that, even in the Member States that do not criminalise stalking, the victims should receive assistance from those services. For example, they could be guided on how to deal with their situation by other measures, like applying for an injunction order or damages for anxiety and harassment. In addition, under the rules of the European Protection Order, any victim of stalking who has been granted protection in one EU Member State should benefit from protection when she or he travels or moves to another Member State. The Commission is aware of the fact that the European Protection Order is rarely used in practice, and this needs to be addressed. National practitioners, law enforcement and judicial authorities should recommit to combating all forms of violence, including stalking. This could, for instance, be achieved by informing or offering the victim the possibility of a European Protection Order each time the domestic protection measure is adopted. I look forward to hearing your views on this matter.

name: Lara COMI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the Commission and thank the Council for the words you have expressed in the facts and also in what are your intentions. I would especially like to thank the colleagues and colleagues who supported this proposal of mine, who I naturally live firsthand, along with many other women. You see, the plague of gender-based violence has been the focus of international attention for several decades now. It is a problem that is late in stopping. Certainly, there are many progress that has been made, especially at European Union level, through the adoption of legislative provisions to prevent this dangerous conduct: perpetrators and protect victims and persons at risk by providing them with adequate services. I refer, for example, as you have already expressed, to the European Protection Order, the so-called Victims Directive and the Istanbul Convention. The Istanbul Convention is the first instrument in Europe with which legally binding rules have been set to prevent, protect and punish this criminal conduct, but it is also the first instrument to intervene and include among the various offences that of stalking, defined as “persecutory acts”. Stalking is an offence often still legally underestimated and, alas, recognised in Europe in only 21 of the European countries. This is a problem, because we must make it as homogeneous as possible and we must as much as possible harmonise this aspect which, alas, does not find uniformity, harmonisation in all 28 Member States. The behaviours we see about stalking, as the daily chronicle unfortunately teaches us, even degenerate into further and more serious crimes, such as personal injury and murder. And then, in the light of this — and I am going towards conclusions — I would like to ask you questions and intentions to the Commission. First: intervene with a specific legislative proposal; second: proceed towards an awareness activity and at the same time, on the experience of a concrete analysis of the data you have verified, whether to use the mandate of European shutdown.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the physical and psychological violence to which victims of stalking in the European Union are subjected is aberrant. Persecutions can take on countless modes of manifestation, but they always have in common an obsessive imprint that leads the victim to fear above all for their own safety, a sense of fear that characterizes daily life, a real limitation on personal freedom. As many forms are, so are the needles. Statistics show that the numbers of stalking cases within the home walls or after the end of a relationship are high. The control that a spouse, a cohabitant, can exercise is enormous and leaves the victim lacking any place to feel safe. And for this reason it also takes more attention to migrant women. Measures such as protection orders, removal from the family home or the prescription of non-approach to places usually frequented are instruments of protection that can make a difference and greatly improve the daily lives of the victims, but they cannot be the only passable routes. We need to provide a better legislative guarantee for the protection of victims of persecution, take the good practices that exist in Europe — I speak, for example, of my country, Italy. It also serves a strong investment from an educational point of view, because the best long-term measure is more effective education and active cultural engagement. We can't wait any longer. We cannot let such an important issue have uneven regulation within the EU. I close by saying that there are still too many countries in the European Union that have not yet ratified the Istanbul Convention.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, protection of victims of violence is a sensitive area where a cold bureaucratic approach is certainly not enough. At first contact, it is necessary to ensure access to all information in the simplest possible language, translation and interpretation in terms of interrogation and continuous information, and sufficient legal and psychological support. The theme of stalking, that is, dangerous persecution or harassment by persecution, is very serious. However, I want to point out the thin ice on which we move. There is a danger that innocent people's reputation may be ruined by crooked accusations. According to a report by the United States Department of Justice, 43% of male stalking victims said the perpetrator was a woman. I want to call on my colleagues to a fair debate that will not demonise only one sex, especially men. Let us protect women from any form of violence, but let us not make men and women irreconcilable rivals. Our differences are a gift from the Creator, through which we are to complement ourselves and live in harmony. But I regret that Commissioner Jouro has once again used the expression that we will press the Member States to ratify the Istanbul Convention. I do not understand what kind of approach this is that we are going to push ourselves, is there the European Union to push, is there for enforcement, manipulation? Many states have legitimate reservations about this, and it is much more reasonable to use another document to repeal the misformulated Istanbul Convention and to create a different and better one.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, as the LIBE co-rapporteur for the Victims Rights Directive, I would like to remind everyone that the Istanbul Convention to combat gender violence has been signed but not yet ratified by the EU and all Member States. In fact, I'm very sorry to say so, but the Bulgarian Presidency which is present here tonight has not yet done so. I thank the Presidency for being present here and I would like to call upon it to do this as soon as possible. The Convention stipulates that all of its provisions, in particular, measures to protect the rights of victims, shall be secured without discrimination on any ground and it explicitly ensures that its signatories to recognise stalking as a criminal offense. Stalking is a serious crime that deserves serious consequences and it must be defined as such. A legal definition of stalking is needed in order to protect the victims’ personal safety and to enforce her or his right to safe determination. The safety of victims of stalking relies upon criminal justice professionals’ ability to recognise this damaging pattern of behaviour and to take appropriate action to stop it. We must ensure that police officers and prosecutors across the European Union take stalking seriously and treat every allegation with serious concern.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Madam President, harassment is indeed one of the most widespread, very important forms of violence against women. And you have to fight it by all means. It is true — she said in the House, the Commissioner said — that there are still seven Member States of the European Union which do not consider harassment within their penal codes. And this situation needs to be changed, because we must put into practice measures such as training for prosecutors, training for police officers, have a non-exhaustive list in our legal systems of what harassment means. All these things must be in our legal systems, and it is very important that institutions act. Therefore, I think we have to do two things fundamentally. First, as has been said, to urge all Member States to ratify the Istanbul Convention, which clearly states that Member States should introduce harassment into their criminal codes. And from that point of view, I join the voices that call on the Bulgarian Presidency to please ratify the Istanbul Convention at once, because the Presidency has not done so does not undermine much legitimacy from many of the things it is coming to us. Secondly, the missing seven Member States should be asked to address the issue of harassment in their penal code.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we are talking about a stalking phenomenon, which suffered 3.5 million European women in 2016 alone. We know that the Istanbul Convention, specifically in Article 34, requires legislative or other measures to be taken with regard to repeated psychological violence behaviour, of stalking. We know that 9 countries have not yet ratified the Istanbul Convention. But let us also ask ourselves what happens in countries such as Italy, which also ratified the Convention. It happens, for example, that decriminalisation takes place in fact on the crime of non-aggravated stalking, decriminalization, considering the conduct extinguishable through compensation to the victim. We believe this is shameful, as the Italian feminist movement also said, as she said “Not one less.” We know that violence against women is not primarily opposed in court but through political, social and cultural intervention.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission finally plans to implement concrete actions to combat the crime of stalking, which affects millions every year of European citizens, especially women. The figures are impressive: 18% of women, i.e. 9 million European citizens, were victims of persecutory behaviour. One in ten women suffered such acts by a former partner who did not accept the end of the relationship. As we know, we have said, not all Member States recognise in their legislation the crime of stalking, and even in those states where there is legislation in this regard, it is difficult to apply law. It is for this reason that we need to do more: by legislating, first of all, in a homogeneous way for all states. It often happens, in fact, that those who report such offences find themselves fighting not only against those who stain this crime, but at the same time against the slowness of justice. There are several cases of chronicle, which took place in Italy, for example, where, despite the many complaints of stalking by victims to the competent bodies, they were disfigured and beatings at the hands of their partners, former partners and in some cases, alas, killed. You have to say enough! So the Commission's action comes well, because Europe has a duty to protect its citizens.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: Madam President, people will wonder what stalking is. It is what is known as persistent harassment in which one person imposes unwanted communications on another, dangerously cutting their freedom and safety. At least 10% of the European population has been harassed; in most cases they are women. Every day there are more victims who report cyberbullying. Also children, who suffer bullying, even come to suicide. I think the consequences for the victims of the events can be dramatic. That is why, as legislators, we have an obligation to legislate and not minimize what harassment really means, which can destroy the lives of victims, so that this crime is punished accordingly. In the European Victim Protection Order, of which I have been a co-ponent, we already introduced harassment as a crime in 2012 and now in implementation. But there are seven countries that have not yet done so, so there are countries where victims will not be protected as in other countries. Therefore, it is discrimination. We must therefore try to get those countries to ratify the Istanbul Agreement and, moreover, to make harassment and stalking a crime. We therefore need a clear definition and regulation to protect victims and persecute aggressors. We cannot have twenty-one legal definitions, because that makes European judicial cooperation and harmonisation difficult.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Madam President, Commissioner Jourová, seven Member States of the European Union have not yet criminalized harassment, as required by Article 34 of the Istanbul Convention against Violence against Women. And that has very relevant practical consequences in a context of deterioration of mutual recognition and mutual trust in the area of freedom, justice and security, because, where there is no adequate definition, the problem of double criminality can arise which prevents the enforcement and enforcement of a European protection order of cross-border victims, which is exactly what we have approved in this House. In addition, seventeen Member States have not yet ratified the Istanbul Convention itself, and it is urgent that they do so. Notoriously Bulgaria and the Czech Republic, which have already announced that they will not even ratify it, which is very painful in the case of Bulgaria, whose Presidency is currently tarnished by an act of embarrassingly sexist connotations in the Bulgarian Presidency which took place at a youth event a few days ago. It is therefore intolerable that this lack of commitment to compliance with the Istanbul Convention in the protection of victims of harassment may result in situations of lack of protection contrary to the European Victim Protection Order. But, in addition to criminal rules, there is a need for a judicial system that protects and incorporates, not only in the training of judges but also in judgements, the gender variable, which affirms an unequivocal and resounding commitment by the whole European Union against all forms of violence against women's freedom and sexual indemnity.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Madam Chairman, victims of violence must feel safe in every corner of the Union after suffering trauma and all rights to protection exercised in their home country should also be secured in other Member States. Of course our focus should always be on violence prevention, but it is equally important to help victims get through a difficult period without additional trauma in the form of fear of recurrence of violence or even fear for their own lives. In this regard, I unreservedly support the Regulation on Mutual Recognition of Safeguards in Civil Matters and the Directive on the European Protection Order. Reducing red tape and simplifying procedures to ensure that victims are protected when travelling to other Member States are important steps in the right direction. What has long been enabled for all people in the European Union will be especially guaranteed to victims of violence through the new legislative framework. He will be able to safely navigate the continent and without fear seek new opportunities for education, work or rest.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Thank you, Mr President. Thank you also for the contributions from the Council and the Commission. I would also like to thank Mr Lara Comi for putting this important debate on the agenda, because it is important. In my country alone, the Netherlands, we have several thousand cases of stalking every year. When we talk about the combination of stalking and threat, it is even tens of thousands of cases a year. The question we have to ask ourselves today is whether the European instruments we have are sufficiently equipped to make a real difference in the approach, particularly in relation to cross-border situations. Commissioner Jourová, you rightly said that victims have rights throughout the European Union that they should be able to exercise. But what about the approach of the perpetrators? Stalking is not on the list of offences for which a European arrest warrant can be issued. At the same time, this means that, if we suspect that an offender may be repeated, we cannot include a warning in the Schengen Information System in case he leaves to another country. The question is whether we should change something about that. And my appeal is to the European Commission and to the Member States: work with us to find a solution to these problems specifically. It must not be the case in Europe that someone capable of doing this kind of act can simply escape the field of vision of the police and the justice system by crossing a border. That is unacceptable!

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: Madam President, more than nine million women and girls over the age of 15 have been persecuted or harassed. About 10 per cent of the population in Europe, the majority of women and girls, have been affected by harassment in all its forms. And today there are several states in the European Union that do not have a regulation of such crimes, which, therefore, cannot be prosecuted. Also, part of the Union's countries has not ratified the Istanbul Convention as the most effective international treaty against violence against women. When we talk about harassment, we talk about many types of harassment: stalking crime means an uninterrupted, constant, intrusive pursuit of a subject against his will. It can be bullying. Today we celebrate the International Day against Bullying, since 2013, against bullying, an abuse of power in schools that sometimes has dramatic results. It can be workplace harassment, it can be sexual harassment, it can be cyberbullying. In any case, the consequences are dramatic and we cannot from Europe close our eyes, so that no case goes unpunished. Therefore, all together for this to be regulated, so that there is a definition and for it to be pursued.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Madam President, I think that from the debate there is complete agreement on all sides here in this House, that concrete measures must obviously be taken to tackle this scourge, to enable any actions and acts — illegal acts — to be reproached and punished. which are related to sexual harassment, violence against women. The most effective action, first of all, is the implementation of the famous Istanbul Convention. We have said this in this House many times: this treaty must finally be implemented, after that implementation measures should be instituted at European Union level and, above all, at national state level and effectively punish those who actually commit crimes and violence against women.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Madam President, dear Commissioner Jurová, allow me to inform you that Hungary is one of the countries which, although not ratified the Istanbul Convention on Violence against Women, criminalised and ordered punishment in the Criminal Code many years ago, offense of harassment. There is nothing more typical of the European Union and the European Commission than making revelations so unknowingly, in such a lack of information and, for example, under Article 7, such a lack of information is being abused by my country, so to speak, for breach of the rule of law. Brackets closed. Precisely because we criminalise stalking, harassment, and we have very serious jurisprudence, I, as a criminal lawyer and MEP, as a member of the Women's Rights Committee, am conducting quite serious research on how to differentiate offences of harassment, especially on the basis of what criteria can be quasi-predicted the danger of harassment, when it is not enough, dear Mrs Jurová and dear specialists, restraining is not enough, in which case a pre-trial detention is required. I am happy to share with you the results of my research, so that if it is not a problem, that I am a Hungarian professional.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I think that we have the solution in our hands. We have important pieces of European legislation and a lot of national laws – for instance, as was just mentioned, the criminal law in Hungary – which must be properly enforced. That’s the point: that we need legislation plus enforcement. I think that we still have a lot of work to do on a European Protection Order. I mentioned before that we have to increase awareness among the professionals and also among the victims that this instrument exists and that they can use it in a situation when it is needed. A lot has been said here about the Istanbul Convention, so I want to come back to this briefly. I want to inform you that, on the EU accession to the Istanbul Convention, the Commission is working closely with the Bulgarian Presidency to make progress on the conclusion of the EU’s accession to the Convention. We are now working on the Code of Conduct and the specification of all the legal circumstances, so I think we are on the right track. Regarding ratification in the Member States, on Monday I was in Bulgaria and had a very fruitful – although quite heated – debate with people who are for and people who are against the ratification of the Istanbul Convention, and I realised that we have to do much better in explaining to our citizens what the Istanbul Convention is about: that it is not, for instance, introducing the third gender into the national legal order, nor is it pushing the Member States to legalise gay marriage. This is the Convention whose main purpose is to fight against violence against women and children; to fight against domestic violence and all very brutal forms of violence, including female genital mutilation, forced sterilisation, forced marriages, and all kinds of violence, including stalking, rape and so on. We need to do be much better at explaining and also in looking into the translation of the text of the Convention in different Member States, because in the Bulgarian language – and also in the Czech language by the way – we do not differentiate between the words gender and sex, and this creates a lot of misunderstanding and misconceptions. So we have to work more on this. I confirmed in Bulgaria that I am not pushing any Member State to ratify, but I am honestly trying to convince the Member States, because from the bottom of my heart I am convinced that this is the way to achieve the proper harmonisation of the criminal offences of violence against women and children, and this is simply a very useful piece of legislation which we are obliged to have in order to help the victims of such violence. Finally, concerning the Victims’ Rights Directive: you all know that the directive was adopted in 2012 and entered into force in November 2015. The level of transposition was not satisfactory so, in January 2016, the Commission started infringement proceedings against 16 Member States for non—notification of national measures transposing the directive. Some of the infringements are still ongoing. This is again a very practical piece of legislation which needs proper implementation in the Member States and the introduction of all the measures, which should serve the better treatment of victims and give better assistance to victims, which requires this to be brought into practical life in the Member States.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to conclude by stressing that we share the view that stalking and the protection of its victims is an issue of common concern that touches upon the core values of the European Union, and therefore need to be addressed with a high level of commitment by both the European Union institutions and the Member States. Concerning the calls upon Bulgaria made by the honourable Members of the European Parliament Lenaers, Urtasun and López Aguilar, the Convention is part of an internal debate in my country and I would like to underline that I am here today in the capacity of Presidency of the Council, representing all EU Member States. Therefore, I am not in a position to enter into details of the current situation in Bulgaria. Nevertheless, I would like to underline that it is beyond any doubt that Bulgarian society is firmly opposed to any form of violence against women. The fact that the Convention was included as a priority file in our presidency programme is a clear demonstration that the Bulgarian Government is convinced of its importance, and we have taken the decision to do so in permanent consultation with the European Parliament, and in particular with the Chair of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality. Unfortunately, there is still a high level of polarisation in the Bulgarian political elite and society. Society is not ready and the government has to act within these limits. We would like to broaden the debate to have our whole parliament and our society on board so that the Convention can be implemented effectively.  At present, we are waiting for clarification from the constitutional court concerning certain aspects of the Convention in relation to the Bulgarian constitution, and I am convinced that this will contribute to reassuring public opinion. It will also clarify many legal issues and will contribute to a more constructive debate on the topic. We will assess the situation in the light of the court’s ruling. As a presidency, we are doing our best to finalise the discussions on the code of conduct so that the Council is in a position afterwards to adopt the decision on the conclusions of the Istanbul Convention by the European Union. The Council is also committed to proceed further on the subject. During the forthcoming Justice and Home Affairs Council in June, the Council is expected to call for a comprehensive approach and for a wide range of actions to be taken by the Commission, the Member States and the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Training (CEPOL) in order to enhance the prevention and detection of, investigation into and protection against all acts of gender-based violence, including those that cause or are likely to cause psychological harm or suffering to women, for example, stalking.
