name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. — Of course, protecting women from violence is important and all those persecuted in one Member State must receive assistance in all others. But here we must be careful: we must not demonise one sex at the expense of the other, so you all talk about equality. I do not understand Mrs Jourova's wish, supported by the Council, to resume the conversation on the Istanbul Convention. Women's rights are protected by a number of other international instruments, and we do not need to raise issues again which we have recently concluded. Bulgaria does not agree with this Convention and we will not support its adoption. Mrs Jourova, your own Czech Republic does not want to hear about this convention, and you are trying through the European institutions to push its ratification. I think that it is clear the sovereign right of any country and that it cannot be forced to which convention or not to join. I believe that the debate on its ratification should be put to an end, as the pressure placed on member states will not do anything good, but, on the contrary, will further shake the already unstable EU.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. — The crime of stalking, or harassing others, may take drastic forms. It can lead to legitimate concerns about life and health, it can give a sense of violating the personal sphere. It can occur at work as well as in private situations. Today it is punished in the legislation of most Member States of the European Union. My country introduced a proper provision into the criminal code a few years ago. At the same time, allegations of committing this offence should be approached with some caution. If they were to radically interpret the concept of “harassment,” it could be punishable any attempt to make contact that would not be desired by the other person. Such an interpretation would risk dehumanizing contacts between people, because we would be afraid to establish any kind of extra-national relationship because of the risk of harassment. I therefore hope that the interpretation of this law, however it makes sense in quite numerous cases, will not be extended beyond common sense. It should be noted that this crime occurs most often in two situations: harassment by former partners (here most often women fall victim) and in an online environment (mainly social media). These cases, however, can be thankfully, as a rule, relatively easily proven. However, there is no awareness that such behaviour is punishable. For this reason, victims often do not report crimes to the police and raise the level of awareness about the possibility of taking legal steps, appropriate institutions should work well.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is statements by the Council and the Commission on the application of international standards on the definition of sexual violence in Spain following the recent so-called “ After the wolf pack incident (2018/2696 (RSP))

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, the facts which we are debating this evening have sent shockwaves through Spain and Europe as a whole. There can be no rest in the efforts to combat violence against women. The Council, on whose behalf I’m speaking today, has always strongly condemned all kinds of violence against women. The debate we just had on stalking and victim protection shows that work is ongoing to prevent such violence, to punish perpetrators and to protect victims. The Council shares the view that the European Union’s accession to the Istanbul Convention will be an important step towards establishing a more coherent new legal framework to better prevent and combat violence against women. Honourable Members, you will understand that it wouldn’t be appropriate for the Council to comment on a criminal law case, adjudicated by a national court. This was underlined in this room at the opening of our session today and I share this view. The justice systems of Member States have their own control mechanisms and the victim and the perpetrators have the right to appeal the judgment. It is not the role of the Council to interfere in the process. To conclude, there is no doubt that in our societies, there must be zero tolerance of all forms of violence against women. Our joint efforts and the message of unity are also needed to ensure the protection of all women and girls in Europe.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, allow me to personally wish to the victim of the La Manada case a recovery of both body and soul that were abused two years ago by the most violent act. Sexual violence is a pervasive form of gender-based violence with serious consequences on an individual and societal level, including emotional, psychological and physical harm to survivors that can potentially last a lifetime. More than one in 10 women in the EU have suffered some form of sexual violence by a partner or by someone else. One woman in 20 in the EU has been raped. The Commission is fully committed to tackling all forms of gender-based violence, including sexual violence. This is one of the five priorities of our strategic engagement for gender equality. The Victims’ Rights Directive is the main EU instrument on the rights of victims of gender-based violence. By implementing the Victims’ Rights Directive properly, Member States ensure that all victims, including victims of sexual violence, are heard, effectively supported, and protected. Allow me to recall that the EU is also in the process of acceding to the Council of Europe Convention on combating violence against women – the Istanbul Convention – which it signed in June 2017. The Convention criminalises sexual violence, including rape. The Convention’s definition is in Article 36 and clearly states that consent must be given voluntarily as a result of the person’s free will, and that such consent should be assessed in the context of the surrounding circumstances. Honourable Members, allow me to conclude that, while Spain is among the 19 Member States that have ratified the Istanbul Convention, we still have Member States which have not done so yet. I understand that the La Manada case is subject to appeal, so I cannot comment further on that ongoing process. But I trust that the Spanish justice system will deliver a swift and fair outcome.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President, violence against women is a heinous violation of human rights. As long as it continues, we will never be able to affirm that we are moving towards equality, towards development and towards peace. We have the right to live without fear, without violence, without guilt, without burdens, without anguish and without uncertainties, and we are here to fight for a right that belongs to us. It is a threat to democracy, it is an obstacle to peace. The facts, undoubtedly, show the utmost contempt for women's dignity. The aggressors, miserable ones who deserve all our contempt for the violation of a person's most basic right, sexual freedom and dignity. We all share that violence, along the lines of the Istanbul Convention and the United Nations, is to violate will. Being a woman is a risk factor, it is not random violence, but only nine out of thirty-three countries in the European Union recognize this simple truth: that sex without consent is rape. The rest of the countries, including Spain, define rape in terms of violence and intimidation, and that is what the legislator wanted in 1995 in Spain; and that is what the courts of justice have applied; that is what is the legal framework in Spain. There are two appeals, there will be appeals before the Supreme Court, which would undoubtedly enlighten future jurisprudence. Such archaic regulation and stereotyped regulation lead to the absurdity that women herself must be responsible for protecting herself from rape. That has to change, but for that we need a serene reflection, a calm reflection. There is also an urgent need to train all, and especially legal operators, on gender perspectives in order to banish stereotypes and harm forever. Criticizing judges is not the way. It is not understanding anything about the valuable gift of living in a rule of law. If the we criticize, we truly compromise the trust our justice system deserves of citizens. The road is another. The path is that of unity, reflection, common sense, human rights and dignity. When I come home, I want to be free, I don't want to be brave.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, the Istanbul Convention against Violence against Women obliges signatory countries to criminalize any sexual act carried out without consent, but there are only nine European countries explicitly recognizing that sex without consent is rape. From my utmost respect for justice in Spain, they will recognize that it is difficult for me to accept and understand a sentence in which the account of the facts shows how an eighteen-year-old girl, frightened, crouched in a cubicle of less than three square meters, dead end, is penetrated by five men and recorded on video, and that victim — such as recognizes the sentence—he is only the victim of abuse and not rape. We do not intend with this debate to interfere with judicial decisions, but it is urgent and necessary to demand greater commitment in the fight against violence against women, just as thousands and thousands of women and men have done in the streets of Spain showing their outrage. How can we explain that this young woman has not been raped because she simply did not face them because, possibly, fear paralyzed her and because those men just decided to penetrate her and not break her head. Can we explain this? In a report on the Istanbul Convention, Parliament declared on the need to train professionals in the judicial system and, in that regard, this claim is not new. But, unfortunately, the Government of Spain is deaf. Because the Government of Spain has failed to comply with the State pact against gender-based violence, cutting by 120 million euros the recognized budget item for this matter, and it is essential, as recognized by that pact, to deepen the training of judicial professionals. And that is why we are holding this debate, because we cannot allow an attack in the twenty-first century. against women's freedoms, dignity and integrity. Because we're here today to tell La Manada's victim and other victims that they might be in that situation that they're not alone, that we do believe them. (She agreed to answer a question under the blue card procedure (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: “blue card” question. — I just want to say to my good colleague Iratxe García that the issue is important enough not to throw a weapon against each other and use the turn to critique the Government of Spain. I did not do this in my speech, even though the 1995 Criminal Code was made by Mr Belloch as minister. I think women deserve a debate with a high view, not a dumping debate against each other. I would ask, please, who has been chairman of the Committee on Women's Rights to take the path of unity, reflection and common sense.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: answer from “blue card”. — I reaffirm myself in each and every one of the words I have said. Democrats' unity will be committed to the fight against gender-based violence. And that also means budgets. And that means not cutting back on policies that are aimed at respecting women's dignity and integrity. Therefore, as long as there are cuts in this area, the Socialist Party will continue to denounce it.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Madam President, Mrs Jourová, I would first like to express, as this Parliament has done on several occasions, my deepest respect for Spanish justice and its courts. Spain is a top-notch democracy, founded on the rule of law and the values of Europe. Today we are not questioning that fact. What brings us together is our mandate as European legislators, and it is our obligation to question Member States when they do not comply with the international conventions they sign and promote the harmonisation of our European standards. The Istanbul Convention, the most comprehensive legally binding tool to combat gender-based violence, has already been ratified by most Member States. Thanks to the commitment and effort of this House and with Commissioner Jourová's invaluable impetus, the Council decided a year ago to begin the European Union's accession process to this Convention. The requirement of the Istanbul Convention for criminalizing crimes against sexual freedom is the absence of express consent. When a country ratifies the Convention, it is obliged to amend its laws to ensure its proper implementation. But four years after the entry into force of the Convention, only six of the twenty-eight Member States criminalize any unconsensual sexual intercourse without having to be grinded or threatened with a knife in your throat. The problem is not the courts, ladies and gentlemen. The problem comes when governments don't do their homework. And our mandate here today is for the twenty-two Member States that have not yet done their right to do so.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Madam President, La Manada's judgment scandalises us all: five men in front of an eighteen-year-old girl on a portal and there is no violence, no intimidation. That is simply fostering the culture of rape and violence against women. And if not, follow what many girls in Spain have reported on the hashtag “Cuéntalo”, which is what many girls live in Europe daily. It's a real scandal. And there is a legal problem, of course, that the lack of legal recognition that sexual relations without consent involve rape. It translates to women the need to simply have to defend themselves against a situation of rape; it takes responsibility to her, which is genuinely scandalous. Therefore, ask the Spanish justice system to rectify this judgment. And, yes, court decisions can be criticized, because, like every public servant, a judge is subject to scrutiny. And secondly, change the Penal Code. And I do not know who made the 1995 Criminal Code, but I know who ratified the Istanbul Convention and who has to amend the current Spanish Penal Code to bring it into line with article 36. And that must be done by the Spanish Government, and the European Commission must do so with all Member States which at this time in its penal code have not yet criminalized violation simply because of lack of consent.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, we have just learned that the United Nations considers that the La Manada judgment underestimates the seriousness of the violation. A sentence that makes us feel more unprotected and leads us to a dead end. If you don't resist, it's not rape, and if you resist, they kill you, as happened to Nagore in the 2008 Sanfermines. Ladies and gentlemen, it's only yes. If there is no valid and explicit consent, it is violation. This is the definition of violation of the Istanbul Convention, which only six European countries have adopted. There can be no room for interpretations. In the face of lack of protection, uncertainty and social alarm, the European Union must provide certainty to women. This is a specific case, but a case that, unfortunately, multiplies. That's a lot more. And in Spain, with law in hand, a rape victim is not recognized as a victim of gender-based violence and is not entitled to any of the comprehensive protection mechanisms they would have in that case. We were talking about the fact that the European Union must be certain. And that involves urging all Member States to implement the Istanbul Convention in its entirety, and not only in part, to implement CEDAW conventions, such as Recommendation No 35, which calls for the development of comprehensive protection mechanisms; and to assume the large outstanding account: a Directive with a comprehensive approach to sexual freedom and sexual freedom and against sexist violence, to establish a new sexual contract between men and women in terms of equality, respect and consensual relations. But all laws, ladies and gentlemen, require funding, and especially laws that defend women. March 8 was a before and after in our country. There's no turning back. It's women's time. It's our time.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this House should not have to comment on the decisions taken by the judicial institutions of the Member States, which are supposed to be independent. That is why my group today opposed, as a matter of principle, to the addition of this debate on the agenda. However, in front of the pathetic spectacle of moral decadence and the general sinking of our societies, I must also share a little bit of my deep discomfort with you. This unsustainable case of collective rape in Spain echoes many other cases before him that have not had the honor of your indignation. I am thinking, for example, of this child in France whose rape has been reclassified as sexual assault, but also and above all the thousands of young English girls who have been prey for more than 30 years of organized networks of paedophiles and rapists in Pakistani in Britain. Thousands for 30 years. Local authorities, knowingly, did not dare to react in order to avoid any accusations of racism. And here I have heard no echo from you since the revelation of this case, and the only answer I hear in every debate on these cases is your desire and strength to absolutely want to have the Istanbul Convention ratified.

name: Anna HEDH
text: Madam President! I just want to say that I'm horrified, disgusted and cursed. How can anything like this happen in the EU? We already know, and research has clearly shown, that people who are in a very exposed situation sometimes fail to put it in words. It's called a frozen fright and is a survival mechanism that causes one to be paralyzed. I'm sure that's what happened when the vile so-called wolf pack molested itself on the 18-year-old woman. Cases of paralyzation like this must take into account a legal assessment. Something else is unthinkable. It is vitally important that people who become vulnerable to crimes feel that they can trust the courts and the judiciary, that their experiences of what they have been exposed to are taken seriously. Unfortunately, it rarely happens to rape victims. In the EU, gender violence is a very big problem. Every third woman in the EU has been the victim of physical or sexual violence. Violence against women is a brutal form of discrimination and a violation of human rights. It is not only harmful to the women who are exposed and affected, but to the whole of society — the whole of Europe at large. Therefore, the issue must be taken very seriously. All the men — you men who are here in the hall and you other men listening — have to take responsibility, and we need to start working on the man role. It should be a foregone conclusion to everyone, both women and men, that sex is based on consent. Anything but a “yes” is a “no” and everything else is illegal. It's supposed to sit in the spine of every single one of us. That is why I feel extra proud that my home country, Sweden, should now pass strengthened sex crimes legislation, a consent law. It should be a matter of course in all EU Member States. Here now comes a serious call to the governments of all Member States. Protections for those who face rape and sexual violence must increase. We cannot, under any conditions, accept anything else. That is why I recall once again that all Member States of the EU completely must implement and endorse the Istanbul Convention. It would be particularly desirable for the Presidency Bulgaria to take the lead and show the other countries, which have not yet ratified, the importance of the Istanbul Convention. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (“blue card”) in accordance with Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: question of 'blue card'. — Mr, I would like to ask you whether, in addition to the ratification of the Convention, there is — we say — a fundamental element, which is the training of professionals who have to interpret laws, not just legislators, who, too, and in fact this Parliament is also considering training in matters of gender. But once the law is made and interpretable, is training for those who have to interpret those laws in your country, that is, judges, magistrates and prosecutors?

name: Anna HEDH
text: answer (“blue card”). — Even today, there are training sessions for the people who are going to work on this issue, such as courts, police officers and social workers, but this new consent legislation will be even clearer. It is incredibly important that even politicians get this information and knowledge. It should be for everyone across Europe — a matter of course.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, 'I do believe you. Nik sinisten zaitut.” I want to tell you, victim of La Manada, we believe you. Like Navarre and Basque society. Like the European Parliament, which applauded you during the trial. That we must work to turn this terrible mistake into an opportunity, into much more than just continuing to cry out injustice. Each of us must tell our children that harassing women, that treating them as objects is despicable, and that we will never support them if they do. So we'll move further than if we keep asking our daughters to be careful just because they're women. Because they live in a world that considers it logical that we are afraid. Our freedom and dignity need that change. Accompanying it also requires harmonization throughout the Union the criminal regulation on gender-based violence and adapting it to the criteria of the Istanbul Convention. To that end, I tabled several amendments which have incorporated the report on the European Protection Order. It is ridiculous that women are required to prove a level of resistance to rape that they would never ask the heist to certify that their wallet was removed against their will. Nagore Laffage, also in Pamplona, in 2008, was killed for resisting. Finally let us assume, and the judges the first, and with all humility, that they must improve their training. Too many international reports indicate that in the area of gender-based crimes, and in Spain also in Community law, or in the area of fundamental freedoms, we suffer a major deficit. Let us not bannalize the length of a prison sentence, especially if we believe that its goal is reintegration. Let's not legislate at a demonstration. Let's bet on ensuring... (the Chairman withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: Mr President, court judgments must be able to be criticized, more would be lacking. And this one in particular is very criticable. In fact, it has caused a justified wave of outrage and has just been criticized even by the United Nations. Five men cowardly cornered an eighteen-year-old girl and raped her wildly. However, the justice system considers that it was not rape, but sexual abuse, as the magistrates do not appreciate violence or intimidation in this savagery. What society do we live in? Only a society that resigns from its responsibilities would accept without rejecting that such a detestable act is not considered an act of violence. This sentence can also establish dangerous jurisprudence: if a woman resists sexual assault, this resistance can lead to her fatal consequences. If it does not resist, there will be judges who consider that she was not intimidated and, therefore, rape becomes only sexual abuse. Let us not deceive ourselves: the problem is not in the Penal Code. The problem lies in the interpretation that is made of laws.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, (inaudible) ... where there are abuses any here across the European Union, we should discuss them here in Parliament, and I welcome this debate. Also we learn from Rosa and others than only six Member States have ratified the Istanbul Convention. It is really appalling in the European Union, which is founded on equality, that this has occurred, and I think it is time for either the Council or the Commission to give each Member State a deadline by which it has to be ratified, but also then say how it was to be interpreted equally in terms of consent, sexual violence, rape, etc. I think that’s a very important issue. Then there’s another part missing: the educational aspect. Young boys have to be educated that it is not manly or macho to be treating girls in a disrespectful manner. They need to grow up as gentlemen who respect women, not macho thugs who abuse them.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Mr President, the blunt speech by the spokesman for the Spanish socialists, Iratxe García, has clearly explained why this issue has come to the European Parliament: because Europeans are the unrest and indignation caused by the case of La Manada and European is the answer, the necessary harmonisation of the definition criteria of sexual violence, which, in accordance with the Istanbul Convention, clearly states that it is yes and sex without consent is rape. But European is also the judicial training response that we have called for and demanded so many times in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, because judicial training in a gender perspective would have prevented the need to appeal before the Supreme Court to correct a criticised and criticable judgment. But judicial training would also have made it impossible for the aberrant private vote, which introduces offensive expressions for the victim and therefore directly engages in what Spanish law debuts as the judge's responsibility: the prohibition of introducing objectively injurious and offensive expressions for the victim, mocking a victim who has rendered a service to... (The Chairman withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: Mr President, sex without consent is rape. The street calls for La Manada and the Istanbul Convention on Violence against Women, signed by the European Union, by most of its countries, including Spain. However, only six European Union states have legislated recognizing that all unconsensual sex is rape. This means that 22 Member States — 22, including Spain — still do not. So we have archaic, unfair, macho penal codes; they're patriarchal. It is time to change and modernize our judicial system with a more ambitious and egalitarian one. The legal definition of violation should be based on the victim's lack of consent, as set out in the Istanbul Convention. Judges need gender-specific training, more budget and fewer cuts. I therefore call on the Commission and the Council for a European directive against gender-based violence to enable this change. Women in Spain and across Europe need to know that justice is on their part.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, what is the point of the Member States signing the Istanbul Convention? Spain did it in 2014. They don't apply it. They don't train judges. I wonder how many judges in Spain will have read this Convention. They do not train anyone on the part of governments. It's pure theatre, pure political correctness, but nothing else. And women are fed up. It is said that judgements cannot be criticized, nor can judges be criticized. Man, please! They are civil servants, paid also with women's money. Also with our money. There has been a very large gap between the judicial world and women that will not break until women receive equal and non-patriarchal treatment like the one we are receiving. This judgment — you know this — is in breach of the Istanbul Convention and the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. You have to take action. If not, what is this Union worth? From what? If he's not even able to protect women. There is an urgent need for training... (The Chairman withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, we need a change of mindset for a fair perception of rape crimes. Imagine the following scene: a businessman goes home after a business meeting on the street in the evening, wearing a nice watch. Five of them catch him, drag him into a doorway, and say, “Give me your watch, man.” He takes off his watch in horror, handing it over, and then, for years, he has to prove to him in a court trial or criminal proceedings that he did not give the watch in a good mood, and not because these lads were so sympathetic that he thought he would give them a gift. And no one would think that there is a presumption of consensus and that it is necessary to prove the opposite, and no one would think of a legal solution that is, in fact, an invalid sale or an invalid gift contract, or even a simple theft. Everyone can clearly see that this is violence, and it should be taken into account with regard to women.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for this very useful, serious and – rightly – emotional debate about the La Manada case. I want to recall once again that we need the laws and they must be properly implemented and applied in the Member States. At EU level, we have the Victims’ Rights Directive, which must be properly applied. This Directive provides specifically that victims of this kind of criminal offence must be treated well. I can imagine the victim of this horrible case – and many other victims – have to repeat again and again what has happened to them and the torture is prolonged. That’s why in the Victims’ Rights Directive, we want the law enforcement authorities to handle these cases with full sensitivity and full professionalism. We also have the European Protection Order, which needs to be used better, and you are right that more enlightenment, more information and more training of professionals is needed. We desperately need to have the Istanbul Convention ratified in all the Member States because it specifically addresses cases like that. As I said, we seriously need the laws to be in place, and full and good implementation, including the application and interpretation by the European courts is seriously necessary. I am not here to criticise the decisions of the Spanish court or any other courts; I just want to say that I do hope that the court of appeal in Spain will decide this specific case swiftly and fairly.  I want to say one more thing. If the courts do not interpret the law in the proper way so that they interpret rape as rape – and I don’t mean this specific case; I speak in general terms because I really don’t want to criticise the Spanish court – if the law is not interpreted properly then the perpetrators will see impunity in these cases. They will see that this is authorised by the State, this is allowed, this is cheap, this is easy. I think that this is not only a legal problem, this is also a hazard. In our society, many people still have a very strong conviction that if a woman is raped or has been raped, she provoked it, she deserved it, she caused it through her own behaviour, and we need to stop this. We need to properly and continuously influence public opinion so that there is lower or zero tolerance in society with regard to these cases. In that regard, the functioning and decision-making of the courts is absolutely essential. Again, I hope that the victim of this case receives a fair decision soon and is able to forget the case as soon as possible, if possible. (Applause)

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the La Manada case is today in the hands of the Spanish courts. As I said at the beginning, the Council would not deem it appropriate to comment or interfere in the case, which might still be reviewed by a higher-instance court. I would like to conclude, however, by stressing again that we share the view that violence against women and girls and the protection of its victims is an issue of common concerns that touches upon the core values of the European Union. These crimes have no place in the Union and should be punished.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I would like to thank everyone who has participated in the debate. I was chairing only a part of it, but I think it is quite a rare occasion when we have such a consensual basis, not just between the institutions but also between the relevant political groups. This just highlights the absolutely unacceptable behaviour that this case is about, with all the consequences that will, of course, have to be dealt with. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — The Istanbul Convention against Violence against Women obliges signatory countries to criminalize any act of a sexual nature carried out without consent. But only nine States explicitly recognize that sex without consent is rape. Although I respect the decisions of the Spanish justice system, I find it very hard to accept and understand a sentence in which the account of the facts shows how an 18-year-old girl, frightened, crouched in a cubicle of less than 3 m2, dead end, is penetrated by five men and recorded on video, and yet the sentence states that she is only the victim of a abuse and not of rape. How can we explain that this young woman didn't get raped because she didn't face them? Because, possibly, fear paralyzed her and because those men just decided to penetrate her and they didn't hit her. We do not intend to interfere with judicial decisions, but it is urgent and necessary to demand greater commitment to the fight against violence against women and to train justice professionals in this area as this Parliament has claimed. We cannot allow any further attacks on women's freedom, dignity and integrity. #YOSÍTECREO

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission, pursuant to Rule 128, on protection of children in migration by:  Anna Maria Corazza Bildt, Roberta Metsola, on behalf of the PPE Group; Birgit Sippel, Caterina Chinnici, Sylvie Guillaume, Dietmar Köster, Cécile Kashetu Kyenge, Juan Fernando López Aguilar, Tanja Fajon, Josef Weidenholzer, Soraya Post, Miltiadis Kyrkos, Kati Piri, Vilija Blinkevičiūtė, Christine Revault d'Allonnes Bonnefoy, Emilian Pavel, Elly Schlein, Enrique Guerrero Salom, on behalf of the S&D Group; Nathalie Griesbeck, Cecilia Wikström, Hilde Vautmans, Sophia in 't Veld, on behalf of the ALDE Group; Cornelia Ernst, Dennis de Jong, Marie-Christine Vergiat, Kostas Chrysogonos, Martina Anderson, Malin Björk, Barbara Spinelli, Marina Albiol Guzmán, Patrick Le Hyaric, Dimitrios Papadimoulis, Stelios Kouloglou, Sofia Sakorafa, Paloma López Bermejo, Lola Sánchez Caldentey, Miguel Urbán Crespo, Tania González Peñas, Xabier Benito Ziluaga, Eleonora Forenza, Miguel Viegas, João Pimenta Lopes, João Ferreira, Curzio Maltese, Estefanía Torres Martínez, Kostadinka Kuneva, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group; Judith Sargentini, Jean Lambert, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group (O-000031/2018 – B8-0016/2018) (2018/2666(RSP)).

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: author. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation in drafting the resolution. It was a great teamwork, indicating the sensitivity of all groups on the subject. There are more than 30 000 children who arrived in Europe in 2017 and among them there are very many unaccompanied ones, who by themselves are the most vulnerable because they are most exposed to the risk of abuse, exploitation and violence. Since the start of the migration crisis, much has been done at European level to address the needs of children and their families, but unfortunately even today some Member States do not implement the recommendations contained in the Commission Communication on the Protection of Migrant Minors, presented more than a year ago. It is alarming, for example, to see that, in some countries of the Union, migrant minors are still being held solely because of their condition as migrants and we hope that this is the Council wishes to share and support Parliament's position, which has long called for the abolition of this practice and the preparation by national authorities of reception systems based on suitable communities and facilities, separate from those for adults, to accommodate minors, especially unaccompanied ones, and families with children. With the resolution to be adopted tomorrow, I hope unanimously, this Parliament intends to reiterate once again the need to ensure these children the necessary safeguards from the moment of arrival on European territory, guaranteeing them the appointment of a guardian, adequate housing and access to education, health care and all social services. These safeguards should also be accompanied by procedures for registering migrant minors, including those for the collection of biometric data, conducted for the exclusive purpose of their protection, thus excluding the recourse to measures coercive, in full compliance with the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. However, it is essential for the dismantling of trafficking in human beings and to prevent the disappearance of children, that the Union should work to create legal and safe immigration channels with sharing, on the part of all Member States, the principle of solidarity and responsibility, at least towards children.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: author. – Mr President, I am proud that today we stand united across the political groups for children’s rights. A child is first a child, regardless of the migration status. Migrant children are vulnerable: exposed to trafficking, abuse and exploitation during the journey and even in Europe. Our resolution is a call for action from the Member States to do more, better and faster, to protect children on the move. They must implement the asylum rules and build capacity, providing access to health care and psychological support, in particular for girls sexually exploited; accommodation and safe areas; school, to restore a sort of normal life and avoid a lost generation; appointing a guardian to unaccompanied minors within five days; and all children from the age of six arriving in Europe must be registered with fingerprints, in full respect of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, without using force. Registration is crucial to ensure that children enter and remain in the protection system. It can help authorities find missing children. Children should not be detained just because they are migrants. In case of crime, they should be treated as EU nationals. Children’s dignity must be respected when doing medical examinations for age assessment. And we have a responsibility to ensure that refugee children go from fear to hope for the future. When given a real chance to integrate, they can become an asset to our societies in Europe, and education is key for integration and to prevent crime and radicalisation. It should include learning about our European values and languages, and respect for women and the rule of law. We also need to tackle the root causes of migration. Let’s not forget all those kids who didn’t make it to Europe, in the desert, in the Mediterranean. I was just in Niger, in Agadez, Africa’s trafficking hub in the Sahara Desert. It was heart-breaking to meet so many children victims of violence. But these tragic stories are the same that are heard from migrant children whom I met in refugee camps in Turkey, in Greece, in hotspots in Sicily, and even in reception centres in Sweden. The EU is doing a lot in Africa, but much more needs to be done, in particular for the Investing in Children programme. As co-chair of the Intergroup on Children’s Rights, I want to pay tribute to all the workers for their commitment to protect children. I will continue to join forces to ensure that Europe truly means safety for children.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Author. — (NL) Commissioner, I would like to begin by allowing one of the refugee children to speak here. I'd like to start with Nimo, who was 6 years old when she fled Somalia. “We stayed in the Sahara for a long time, more than 3 months. We slept outside on the ground. We used our shoes as a pillow. The men who took us were mean. Whoever ran away was beaten with a stick. Because you had to pay first, otherwise you couldn't leave. The smugglers once told Grandma that they would release her if she gave me to the men. Fortunately, she didn't do that.” So little Nimo. This story shows very clearly to me that this debate and this resolution on children in migration are essential. Ladies and gentlemen, two years ago, Europol came out with a report which clearly stated that 10 000 unaccompanied minor asylum seekers have disappeared in Europe. The children would have ended up in prostitution, child labour, killed for their organs or living with their families in another European country, without our knowledge. I proposed a book last week called “Where are they?” Where are they? And I must tell you that I have been able to quote staggering figures about Belgium. In 2017, 124 missing children were reported to Child Focus in Belgium. And do you know how much in custody service? 618! How can that be? How is it that we in Belgium do not even have the right figures on disappearances? But, ladies and gentlemen, it is not only the case in Belgium. I also called around to other countries. It is estimated that 5700 in Italy, 700 in Austria, 318 in Sweden and 290 in the Netherlands, but there is no one, nobody in Europe, who can give the exact figure, and that in itself is a pure disgrace. That is why we are actually delighted that this resolution sets out the points. Let us start with numbers, so that we have the data. data, photos, fingerprints and of course taken in a child-friendly way and only to protect them. 2. No more prisons! Identifying guardians, psychological counselling and education. 3. Faster family reunion within Europe. That, too, sometimes takes months. The Commissioner has said that, in her book, if a child disappears it is a 'ticket to hell'. Let us create awareness; let us find them; let us just do it.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Author. — Mr President. When we were able to visit the Balkan route 2015/16, many migrants told us that children disappeared. One of them reappeared in other places, the others disappeared forever. They were slaughtered for organ trafficking, enslaved as workers, abused for sexual services or somehow and somewhere died. The EU has been aware of the fact that children on the run are most at risk for a long time, but it does nothing! Although the protection of children is the first duty of a society. Incidentally, it does not matter where the children come from. The EU and the Member States are doing nothing because it is more important to them to seal borders than to protect children's lives. No matter how the Commission and the Member States — no matter what you say today, Mrs Jourová — is the fate of these children, also shows the fact that no single consistent, genuinely vigorous action has actually been taken to address child trafficking and child abuse. And the fact that you do not care about the children in your heart is shown by the fact that to this day, migrant children can be put in an asylum prison in any Member State of our European Union — if a Member State wants it. We consider it a violation of human rights when children are interned. We demand that families be brought together as soon as possible and that children be given what they are entitled to: family and security, not barbed wire! Ladies and gentlemen, we as GUE/NGL are calling for easier and faster asylum procedures for all minor asylum seekers. We condemn the fact that children are getting fingerprints taken. Ask specialists what they say — they're laughing sick about it because it's nonsensical and kids are criminalized apart from that. We want the integration of migrant children to finally become normal in all Member States, in schools, health care, living, care, anywhere! I urge you to finally do something and not just talk.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: author. – Mr President, I want to add my voice to what has just been said by my colleagues. We know that the response across the European Union in terms of children in the asylum system and children in migration is still very fragmented. There is still much work to be done in terms of joining the dots to give a holistic response, and with a focus on durable solutions, and that includes children who are undocumented or stateless. We still do not have all Member States having a statelessness procedure that really works. So progress is slow, there is a lack of resources going to the local and regional level, certainly from EU money, and I think we need to reconsider how we are spending and directing that to really get the increase that we need in training and indeed in a much, much better system. We also need to concentrate on implementing the legislation that we have because that is pretty poorly implemented in many of our Member States. In terms of protection and the basics of life – shelter, food, safety – no child in the European Union should be having to sell themselves to get any of those things and there are many today who do. When the legal guardian system works, it works really well. In the European Parliament, we heard only last week about a young man, Julien Makalu, who had been thrown into jail on his arrival in the European Union, but had been helped by a legal adviser and is now an engineering student at a Greek university. He spoke about the enormous difference to his life that having the support of that legal guardian had made. I also want to say a last word about family reunion and how poorly that is implemented in our Member States. Many of our systems still do not have a real operational basis on which to cooperate across borders to make sure that children are reunited with their families.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, last April the Commission identified a series of actions to be urgently taken or better implemented by the EU and its Member States to strengthen the protection of the high number of migrant children arriving in Europe, many of them unaccompanied. The Commission and the EU agencies fully support Member States in implementing these actions. In the meantime, large numbers of children continue to arrive to Europe. According to the latest data published by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in March this year, between January and September 2017, 25 379 children arrived in Greece, Italy, Spain and Bulgaria. Of those, 58% were unaccompanied or separated children. The arrival of unaccompanied and separated children has actually increased by 25% compared to the first half of 2016. The challenges identified in our communication and its recommendations are therefore still very relevant and very important. It is time to ask what has been achieved by the Member States so far in terms of implementing the communication and the recommendations of the Commission. Over the past year, the Commission and the EU agencies stepped up the work to support Member States to reinforce the protection of migrant children. However, child protection for migrant children is still fragmented – as you rightly pointed out – across Member States. A number of challenges still need to be addressed, following also our recommendations, in order to make the policy on the protection of children in migration tangible and consistent. Overall, I cannot agree with the opinion that we have done nothing, but I also fully admit that we must do much better. We still need to take a big step forward to improve cross-border cooperation as well as communication on aspects concerning migrant children. We monitor progress achieved in the implementation of the communication also through bi-annual joint meetings with the representatives from the Member States. The next meeting is scheduled to take place in early June this year, and we will pass the same messages there too.  More generally, we need to find the right balance between the effective EU migration management policy and ensuring adequate protection for the most vulnerable. In order to meet these challenges the Commission will continue to prioritise the protection needs of migrant children in EU funding. Our financial support should also reach the regional and local authorities, which have a key role with respect to integration and social inclusion measures including access to formal, inclusive education and non—discriminatory access to other services.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the situation we are facing with the migrant children is heart-breaking and horrifying in equal measure. Last year, some 15 000 unaccompanied children arrived on our shores, lost and alone. Many of these children were put in a boat by their parents, who knew the risks and who did it anyway because a choice between fire and water and between certainty and some hope is no choice at all. This issue is the litmus test of the strength of our European way. It is being put to the test and we have two choices. Do we double down on our values or do we turn our backs? The populists would turn and then manipulate the issue to try to get elected. I say that the time to pander to them must end. I am a proud Maltese Christian Democrat. I am also unashamedly a pro-life politician – probably one of the few – but it would be utterly hypocritical of me, or of anyone like me, to speak out for the unborn, but then turn our backs on children fleeing Syria, starvation or hopelessness just because they were born elsewhere.  By all means let’s have all the necessary security verification procedures in place, let’s close all the loopholes and let’s ensure identification, but let’s also counter the thinking that leads so many people to believe that these children are somehow so different from our own that we allow them to become scapegoats and cheap electoral punch bags. As has been said, unaccompanied children need guardianship, not prison guards, playpens and not barbed wire. They need child rights protection officers, respect, books and access to education. We have the resources to do this. States have a legal obligation to do this, and we must ensure that they do.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President, access to school is a fundamental right for all children, but that right is not being protected for the hundreds of thousands of refugee children fleeing Syria and arriving on the European coast or Turkey. According to European legislation, after seeking asylum they should join school within three months, but a Global Progressive Forum study of seven EU countries and Turkey shows that it takes even more than two years to join the education system — children who have already lost another two and a half years escaping the war in Syria. It also shows that these children do not have psychological support for someone who is escaping trauma, nor did they have pedagogical support for someone who has to join a culture that is not their own. Our battle is to guarantee them that right.

name: Marek JUREK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! Commissioner! I will not repeat the Europol data, because in fact everything our colleagues have already said here, and best told by our colleagues. Hilde Vautmans talked about what was going on. These are the terrible things: sexual exploitation, modern slavery not to talk about things worst, and Roberta Metsol talked about good remedia to be undertaken. But all this, particularly against the helplessness of the government (for example specifically the Swedish government, which was being alerted by its own ombudsman), does not absolve us from asking the question: who led it all, who these children encouraged, for the most part — I will repeat what the Commissioner said — without parents' care, to throw yourself into this dangerous road. I'm not just talking about illegal people smuggling — it's what we have to fight first of all — but we will not avoid responsibility the politicians who encouraged it and these children have exposed this fate.

name: Margot PARKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, no one can disagree that the protection of children in migration is one of the biggest issues facing Europe today. Europol estimate that there are at least 10 000 missing children in the European Union. How many have been spirited across borders by traffickers and lost to a life of slavery? How many of these could have been protected if there were not open borders across this continent? The European Union preaches solidarity, burden sharing and responsibility, yet it blindly refuses to acknowledge that its own policies and ideology, namely the Schengen area, facilitate crimes against children. Unless the EU has a serious rethink on internal and external migration it cannot say in good faith that the EU can better protect children in Europe.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, it is a hypocrisy that the European Union should attempt to appear sensitive to the child refugees whom it and its allies are bombing and uprooting from their home country either with their parents or unaccompanied or by making them live through the torment of waiting for many months. family reunion. In recent times, flows have been increasing, apart from the Greek islands and in Evros, so a myth is that the EU-Turkey agreement is stopping them. Trafficking, widespread prostitution and child trafficking are inherent in the system of exploitation defended by the European Union. Its policy and its governments, such as the Syriza-ANEL government, condemn children to live trapped in terrible conditions, exposed to fascist murderous attacks, such as the one recently in Lesvos. We must now intensify the fight against imperialist interventions. Now all refugees and migrants should be evacuated by transporting them to centres of mainland Greece, to the country they want. Full measures to support refugee and migrant children!

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: Mr President, the UNHCR figures provided by the Commissioner represent an urgent commitment for the European Union. In the Commission Communication of April 2017 Avramopoulos stated that the priorities should be to improve the identification of minors, train responsible personnel and expedite relocations, but also the rapid location of their families in the countries of origin. Yes, yes, I say, but without coercion. For me, identification is an elementary protection procedure. The best interests of the child must be paramount. Special protection for the unaccompanied, those most exposed to falling into criminal hands. The existing or pending European instruments must be further developed and used. Development of the European search portal, entry/exit, hotspots, Europol or Frontex, but which are compassionate and humanitarian. More capabilities and means for operational and rapid legislation and budget for the planned ones. More cooperation with countries of origin and transit. And an urgent conclusion of the operational agreements between Europol and the countries of North Africa and the Middle East. Nothing else.

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Mr President, recently in Niger our delegation saw the shocking situation where nearly a third of those who are being evacuated from Libya are unaccompanied and separated children. The terror that they must be feeling is something extraordinary that we should all think about. Member States need to step up pledges to resettle unaccompanied and separated children who have been evacuated from Libya through the emergency transfer mechanism. The pledges of EU Member States are too low, but when you think of the separated children I think they should think again.  NGOs such as RRC point to the importance also for continued cooperation and support from the Commission, as the Commissioner said to Greece and other front line Member States, to ensure existing shelters and alternative care arrangements remain open and operational, that no further funding gaps emerge or delays in funding flows disrupt the provision of care and services for children. Children should always be uppermost in our minds. The terror they face should be uppermost in our minds and we have a duty to them.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Mr President! I've heard a lot of real things now, but I have to confess — with all due respect: that seems pretty populist to me too. Because we just have to look at the facts: there are currently more than 50,000 unaccompanied underage refugees living in Germany. Supposedly underage refugees! Because you sometimes refuse to carry out a very specific age assessment. It is completely indisputable that underage refugees need to be particularly active. But to do this, you also have to determine who is a minor. If you don't do that, you undermine the acceptance of any sensible solution. It is an andering that you do not address this point, and it is an undoing for me that you do not address this either. If you are just talking about trying to help here, then that is not a political approach. We also need to make sure that we create a solution that is accepted by the population, and what I have heard so far is far from it.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: — Mr President, Mrs Jourová, ladies and gentlemen, although we no longer make headlines, although we no longer hear of those who flee war and death reach our borders, the truth is that we are sadly far from having solved the so-called 'refugee crisis'. The mismanagement of the humanitarian crisis that has plagued the Mediterranean and our borders, along with a Common European Asylum System, which has little in common, poorly functioning and, when it works, it works badly, has led to a number of prolonged adverse effects. Children are, unfortunately, who have felt these effects the most and most suffered from the inability of the Union. Still in 2017, more than thirty thousand children arrived in Europe, half of whom were alone. It is not acceptable for months to pass without even being appointed a guardian for these children. It is also not acceptable that more months are needed before reunification with their families takes place. We are taking away their future, as well as the nearly thousand that were detained in 2016. The Commission, I am sure, will find in Parliament all the support it needs to resolutely defend the rights of these children. But to be clear, it is the Member States that most are demanded and expected. Only the Member States have the means to save these children, who are not immigrants, refugees or asylum seekers. They're kids, just like ours.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is nothing capable of demonstrating what the true soul of a society is, other than the way it treats children, Nelson Mandela said. This resolution gives clear guidance on what should be Europe's true soul: the reception, care and integration of migrant minors. They are young people with a hard past to forget, but also a present and future project. For them we ask for a series of safeguards and protections that go beyond the emergency management of recent years and also legal and safe paths; we ask that no parent should entrust the fate of their children to desperate journeys. Therefore it is necessary to implement humanitarian corridors, to provide for relocation, speed up family reunification, to apply good practices such as those in my country, whose incessant work of the institutions, local authorities, associations and civil society gives us the strength to look forward and also helps us to rediscover the true soul of Europe.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Mr President, colleagues and colleagues, although things are progressing very slowly, we really need to say that children are the most vulnerable group among refugees and we need to give them the maximum attention. Last week I was on a mission in Greece, especially on the island of Lesbos, where I saw the plight of unaccompanied children in particular. While the Greek government is really moving very slowly, then I have to appreciate the work of people in the field who are working with great deployments, whether they are domestic Greeks or employees of international organizations. I appreciate their work they're doing right these days, whether it's in hot-spot Moria, downtown Karatepe. For the extraordinary work, I want to personally thank the mayor of Lesbos Island. In complex conditions, they strive to make life in the camps dignified and safe for everyone, especially women and children. These children, who are three thousand in Greece, are at risk of abuse, trafficking, they don't have a life perspective. Therefore, I support unreservedly a maximum reduction in the fingerprint scanning age limit to enable them to be recorded and protected.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Mr President, Commissioner Jourová, according to UNHCR, 30,000 children arrived in Italy, Greece, Spain and Bulgaria in the last year 2017. Of these almost half are unaccompanied minors: therefore, the most vulnerable, exposed to exploitation, abuse and all forms of violence. The 1989 United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union compel all Member States to comply with the resolutions of the Commission's own communication on 12 April last year, which means specialized shelters available for children who are not accompanied and for their families, the appointment of a guardian, medical, psychological support and education for these unaccompanied children in extremely vulnerable situations. Likewise, the prohibition of detention, so that prolonged and systematic detention of migrant minors and their families cannot occur, in compliance with their fundamental rights. And, of course, my group has managed to include in the text the right to education from three months and the prohibition of... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, children are children and are entitled to our protection, regardless of where they come from and irrespective of how they ended up here. It is crucial that we include in our asylum policy the instruments to make this protection a reality. This also means that we must identify and register all children who arrive here as refugees or migrants, and therefore give Member States the opportunity to guarantee that registration. It also means ensuring that Member States can control that children are really children, that we can expose adults pretending to be children precisely in order to protect those children. And much of the legislation in which we can regulate this is currently on the negotiating table. I therefore call on the Council and the Commission, and certainly also my colleagues here in Parliament, to continue with that.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, I would say to the Commissioner that children in migration are vulnerable to all kinds of trauma and they struggle in many spheres of life, but their rights are undeniable and equal. Migrant children have the same rights as our children. I call on the European Commission to take steps to ensure that the identification of children upon their arrival in the EU occurs as soon as possible. It is unacceptable that children should stay in the limbo of detention for years awaiting refugee status. The process of getting asylum must be as quick as possible for them.  Researchers on the ground tell us that the main problem is not the lack of a strong legislative framework to protect these children. The problem is the implementation of the rules. If we need more trained staff to work with migrant children, we must train them. If we need new facilities for their accommodation, we must create them. If we need to overcome the reluctance of local people to accept the children, we must lead awareness campaigns.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, my colleague Roberta Metsola outlined the position of children in the European Union arriving unaccompanied, and missing children, which is very tragic. I think our aim should be simple: to treat these children as if they were our own. I think that we should do everything we can to provide them with a home where they are warm and comfortable, and a school where they can be educated and reach their potential. I think that is what the people of the European Union want, and indeed one of the great joys of being an MEP is going round to schools in my constituency where I see children from all different nationalities from outside the European Union, sitting side by side with children from my own country, integrating properly.  On Monday, I was in the biggest primary school in my area, in Killarney – St. Oliver’s. There they are preparing for the Blue Star, and the work done by children from outside the European Union was fantastic – their knowledge, their pride and the way they are integrated and accepted. That is what we need to do. Give them a home, give them an education.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with this question we want to accelerate a genuine common European strategy for defining a framework for the protection of migrant children in Europe under the Convention on the rights of minors: it is our duty, with particular reference to unaccompanied minors — only in Italy there are 15 000 at this time. That is why we have passed, in my country, a new law which we presented to the Intergroup “Minors” and which takes up many of the points that are in our resolution tomorrow: a common system of rapid identification on arrival, prohibition of detention, persons in charge of any hotspot, standard reception conditions, legal assistance, health, access to education, regardless of their status, but above all appointment of guardians and possibility of family entrusting, family reunification. In addition, in order to prevent trafficking, we must provide for forms of protection and monitoring within partnerships with third countries.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the protection of migrant children is on the agenda in all the Member States of the European Union and they must obviously be fully protected against violence, particularly sexual violence, protection against exploitation and prostitution. At the moment, migratory flows in Greece are increasing, not only in the Aegean islands but also from the Evros region we have large migratory flows. Last Sunday I was in Lesvos. The situation has reached its inconspicuous. Over 10,000 refugees and illegal immigrants are located in Lesvos, which has 27,000 inhabitants. You do realize that this situation cannot continue. A few hours ago 160 people landed on the island of Chios. So you see that flows are increasing and we need to take measures: firstly, decongesting the Aegean islands; secondly, protecting, of course, minors; thirdly, relocating to other countries of the European Union and, finally, refocusing those who are not entitled to asylum.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: - Mr President! Madam Commissioner! Children have the right to a safe upbringing free of violence. Children have the right to health care, education and free play. Children have the right to feel future belief and to have a supportive adult who loves them, but there are many children within the EU today who do not. The very worst vulnerable are the unaccompanied refugee children. According to the UN refugee agency UNHCR, 32,039 children arrived in Greece, Italy, Spain and Bulgaria in 2017. About 46 percent of those children were unaccompanied or children separated from their parents. These children live in very vulnerable conditions, and more support is needed. In Sweden, the Green Party has ensured that over 9,000 unaccompanied children are given a second chance to stay, as the long handling time has left them reaching the age of 18 during the time they have been waiting for message. We need to do more within the EU to accommodate the rights of all children. A first step is to take real responsibility for migration policy and work against trafficking. Everyone needs to take a solid responsibility, and especially for children who get caught up in the system ensure they get the help that they need.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Mr President, I would like to ask Mr Kelly, with all due respect, that if it is such a fantastic thing that migrant children and British or Irish children are mixed, why do Members of Parliament not send their children to these schools, but instead either send their children to very expensive private schools where there are no migrant children or, in Brussels, send their children to a special so-called European School which is completely isolated from the rest of the world? All employees and Members of the European Parliament qualify for sending their children there. Why do Members of the European Parliament and the employees of the European Union not want their children to have all this fun in the world from being mixed?

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Ms Morvai, I shall make just one comment, and that is that I do have some experience of the European school and I must say that the pupils studying there are different in nature, of different origins and – you would be surprised – of different skin colour and also refugees. I myself came across that many years ago, and I do not think it has changed.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I attended basic school with a large number of Roma children and they are still my good friends. I was happy to have such an experience; it was very enriching. This was a very important and serious debate, so let me briefly react to some of the comments.  I think it is quite clear that the problem of children in migration and creating better conditions for them, especially security and perspective, requires cooperation at all levels, starting from the EU institutions, through the Member States at regional and local level, but also civil society organisations. We all have the obligation to strictly follow the principle of acting in the best interests of the child, because this is not only a legal and political obligation; it is also, and especially, a moral imperative.  We will discuss it with the Member States in June, as I said before. We will look back into the Commission Communication and Recommendation and we will discuss seriously what has been done and what still needs to be done. Much has been done in the field of training and deploying more capacities. We are continuing funding programmes. You would be surprised how flexible the funding is, because we try to react to current needs and urgent needs. I will not go into details, because of the time pressure. We will be more, let us say, strict in asking Member States to facilitate guardians for the children because, rightly, and for very good reason, we set a five-day deadline for choosing guardians for the children since if this does not happen then there are very frequent cases of children going missing. This is a sensitive moment and we have a duty to have guardians for them as soon as possible.  Regarding the fingerprinting of children, we proposed a reform of the European Asylum Dactyloscopy Database (Eurodac) to lower the age for taking fingerprints and facial images to six years, precisely to strengthen the protection of children in migration and, in all cases, fingerprinting of minors must be carried out in full respect of their rights and best interests. By the way, it was very urgently recommended by the people working on the ground, in the hot spots. They warned us that the lack of identification is also one of the causes of children going missing. My last comment is on the detention of children. I have to stress here, again, that the administrative detention of children should only be used, in line with EU law, exclusively in exceptional circumstances and where strictly necessary. It should only be used as a last resort where no less coercive measures are available, for the shortest possible time and always in dedicated closed centres. This is very important to stress.  As a very last comment, I think that we, first of all, have to offer children a perspective, because providing them with food and bed cannot be enough. I think it is our obligation, as you rightly pointed out, to provide them with an education and full integration into our society. This is absolutely essential and I think it is our common duty as well.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – The recommendations of the European Commission’s Communication on the protection of children in migration of 12 April 2017 requires an urgent and strengthened implementation across EU Member States, starting with the processes of identification and registration. According to Europol, more than ten thousands migrant and refugee children have gone missing after their arrival in EU, victims of human trafficking and extreme abuses. The main barrier in combating this worrying phenomenon is the lack of data (biometrical data and fingerprints) which leads to an incapacity of traceability of migrant and refugee children across EU. Consequently, I stress the importance to reinforce the procedures of data collecting at all EU all borders and assemble effective mechanisms of prevention and responses. With regards to prevention, it is decisive that missing children detected across the Union are immediately identified, registered and assigned to child protection authorities, and further hosted in different establishment than adults in order to prevent risks of violence and other abuses. EU Members need to step up efforts in cross-border cooperation, information-sharing and coordination among all authorities involved in order to find and protect the missing children, irrespective of their migration or refugee status.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. — The protection of the child must, of course, be a priority in all procedures — including in the process of asylum application. This is also the case for underage migrants arriving in Hungary. Minors between 14 and 18 years of age are accommodated separately in transit zones, while migrant children under 14 are already placed in special child protection institutions on the territory of the country. Social workers helping minors are constantly present in transit zones, police officers and staff working there receive special training, and minors have access to education in all cases. At the same time, a large percentage of migrants falsely claim to be minors in order to benefit from special procedures for children, thus concealing their criminal record. Therefore, I consider it very important that minors can be used as simple and rapid dating as possible, and to oblige them to provide their biometric data. At the same time, I also reject the mandatory quota for minor migrants, the implementation of which is urged in the report, as this will only result in more and more unaccompanied minors embarking on a dangerous road leading to Europe in the hope that they will lead to family reunification. you can bring your family.

name: Kati PIRI
text: in writing. — (NL) Minor unaccompanied refugees, that is what we call children who appear on our borders without parents in search of protection against war, violence and oppression. Children who survived the trip to Europe on their own or just with brothers and sisters. Children who, in the countries of arrival Greece and Italy, have long been deprived of proper care or guardianship, have created a great risk of “disappearing” into prostitution, crime or child labour, or being recruited by extremists. European governments regularly detention these children in detention centres, against all international agreements. But it is wrong not to take care of this extremely vulnerable group. These refugees must be given all the protection they deserve. Only by creating decent care and giving children enough attention will they have an opportunity to integrate into our society and work for a stable future in Europe. They must never suffer from the lack of solidarity in the EU and the lack of a political agreement on the fair distribution of refugees between Member States.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: in writing. — Children and minors are among the most vulnerable people. According to UNICEF, 5.4 million young migrants live in Europe, 46% of whom are unaccompanied or separated from their parents. Children in particular are particularly affected by the dangers of human trafficking and exploitation. Member States are therefore called upon to do everything in their power to serve the best interests of the child. There is still a lack of child protection facilities in the Member States to provide psychological and psychiatric support for refugee minors. Cross-border cooperation will need to step up the search for missing children and to step up the fight against child trafficking. In hotspots and border crossings, access to child protection officers must be provided. However, integration in the Member States must also be further promoted. In order to ensure rapid integration, the assistance of the Member States is also required. Integration into schools takes different lengths of time in different countries and some minors are still not accommodated in educational institutions three months after the asylum application has been filed. All children, especially unaccompanied minor refugees, must be provided with the greatest possible access to housing, health care, formal and inclusive education, as well as language courses. When accommodating minors, attention shall be paid to the fact that minors are placed separately from adults in order to prevent the risk of violence and sexual abuse.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the oral question to the Council on the worldwide ban on animal testing for cosmetic products by Sirpa Pietikäinen, Miriam Dalli, Bolesław G. Piecha, Frédérique Ries, Stefan Eck, Marco Affronte, Eleonora Evi, Sylvie Goddyn, on behalf of the Committee on Environment, public health and food safety (O-000040/2018 - B8-0017/2018) - (2017/2922 (RSP)) and — oral question to the Commission on the worldwide ban on animal testing of cosmetic products by Sirpa Pietikäinen, Miriam Dalli, Bolesław G. Piecha, Frédérique Ries, Stefan, Marco Affronte, Eleonora Evi, Sylvie Goddyn, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000041/2018 - B8-0018/2018) - (2017/2922 (RSP)).

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: author. — Mr President, the European Union was the first region in the world to ban animal testing in the field of cosmetics, both for ingredients and also for future products. As a result, the European cosmetics industry has prospered. It has been involved in a number of research projects and has developed excellent alternative methods that are more reliable for consumers. Consumers have thus gotten better cosmetics for themselves. We have avoided a very large amount of pointless and cruel animal testing.
