Once alternative methods have been developed — the EU is currently involved in 33 different research projects — it turns out that animal testing is also extremely unreliable. Only about 60 per cent of people's reproductive health risks, about 40 per cent of skin irritations and about 42 per cent of carcinogenic effects are noticed. Instead, alternative methods based on stem cell platforms, among other things, more quickly deliver significantly more reliable and, in many cases, lower-cost results, both for cosmetics and also for other products. So we can say on the subject that testing on animals is archaic, ineffective and extremely cruel. Indeed, the EU has been a success story that has been watched so far for many countries. However, about 80 percent of products still contain ingredients tested on animals or are tested on animals. Although it also applies to products marketed in the EU, it is very difficult to obtain information about the origin of products and their control has proved very difficult. What we need now and what Parliament is asking both the Commission and the Council at present is an active action to bring about a global ban on animals in terms of cosmetics. We need an international agreement, a code of conduct within the framework of the UN, standards and a global campaign to ban testing cosmetics on animals by 2023. We appeal to both the Council and the Commission that, following this debate and resolution, they would deploy their resources not only directly to the UN, its Secretary-General, but also to all like-minded and currently still divisive UN Member States in order to achieve this ban. It is also important that both existing and future trade agreements include a testing animal ban on cosmetics. When these tests have shown that alternative tests produce more reliable results, both for the consumer, namely for humans, and avoid unnecessary animal suffering, and in many cases also save costs, it is very important that we also invest together in the Commission and the EU budget resources to validate, develop and prompt adoption of alternative tests — including in non-cosmetic areas where results are completely similar to cosmetics tests, both in terms of reliability and development. We need international cooperation, we need resources, but we need a little humanity before everyone. It is worth remembering that what we often call the most deeply human in us, such as emotions, caring, the ability to suffer, are the most deeply animalistic parts of us all. What we do to animals speaks very much about us, about our own culture, our ethics and what kind of people we are and want to be.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for the opportunity to discuss the possibility of a global ban on animal testing for cosmetic products with you today. Your question touches upon several aspects of this important issue, which is of great interest for consumers worldwide. I would like to take the questions you raised one by one, insofar as they fall within the sphere of activity and competence of the Council.  In the introduction to their questions, the honourable Members point out that the European Union ban on animal testing for cosmetic products, which is stipulated in Article 18 of the Cosmetics Regulation, and fully applicable in the Internal Market since March 2013, has had positive consequences. As a co-legislator which is co-responsible for this outcome, the Council certainly shares your view.  Your further questions point more to the future. Regarding the current global impact and acceptance by third countries of the EU ban on animal testing for cosmetics, we have to differentiate between a statistical-economic part and a legal part. The Council does not specifically analyse the global impact of the EU ban on trade flows. This task is more for the Commission, and the Commissioner will most probably be able to say more.  According to my information, EU industry and EU consumers have so far not registered any more major problems with regard to profitability or availability of products. From the legal side, an acceptance of the EU ban by third countries is not specifically necessary in the sense that third countries can regulate their own markets as they see fit. Rather, we should speak of an acceptance by third country producers, which is an absolute condition in order to place cosmetics on the EU market. This has been confirmed by the Court of Justice in the European Federation for Cosmetic Ingredients case in 2016.  In this regard, again, I am not aware of any major disruption, but even if producers were finding it difficult to place products on the European market, the European legislator would continue to favour the public interest of animal health over the interest of individual third country producers. On the issue of ensuring that all cosmetics placed on the EU market have never been tested on animals in a third country, as the Treaty makes clear, this is in the first instance a task for Member States. As you, the honourable Members, are aware, market surveillance authorities enforce the Cosmetics Regulation in the same way as they enforce any other Union internal market legislation. Article 4 of the Cosmetics Regulation requires a responsible person within the Union to ensure compliance of the products with the Regulation, and Article 11 provides for a Product Information File for every product to be placed on the EU market, irrespective of its place of production. Article 18 specifies in great detail the EU ban on animal testing.  As for any other product, it is not for the Council as a legislative and policy-making institution, but for the market surveillance authorities of the Member States to check and verify that every product complies with the European rules. On the issue of an international agreement to put an end to the testing of cosmetics on animals worldwide, the Council would examine attentively any recommendations from the Commission to open negotiations regarding such an agreement. Any such agreement would obviously have to be compatible with the Cosmetics Regulation. It would be for the Commission to carry out such negotiations, on the basis of, and in line with, a mandate from the Council. Provided the negotiations lead to a successful outcome, the Council would then be in a position to conclude such an agreement on behalf of the Union. This leads me to the question of promoting a global ban at the UN. As I have just explained, in line with its competences under the Treaty, the Council would stand ready to exercise its responsibilities on the international level.  Finally, on the question of a possible conflict with trade agreements and WTO rules, the Council is convinced that the Cosmetics Regulation is in conformity with WTO rules and other trade agreements. It is not for the Council, as a Union co-legislator, to enforce WTO rules. Nevertheless, let me point out that under the WTO system, multilateral action is usually preferred to a unilateral one.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much for this question and for the opportunity to discuss it today. Animal welfare is an extremely important topic for European citizens. It is also important for me personally, so thank you very much.  This importance is reflected in the very high animal welfare standards that apply in the EU. It was also, may I remind you, reflected in the very unanimous and strong condemnation of the private tests, for example, mandated lately by some car makers on monkeys in the US. Over the last five years we have led the way with our animal testing ban on cosmetics. The ban not only signals our commitment to animal welfare in the European Union, but also a new approach to human safety. I want to say it very strongly: we do not need to protect humans by harming animals.  It is also visible that during those five years since the ban entered into force, our industry still remains number one in the world. The ban has had an impact also on third countries. It is difficult of course to assess the precise global impact of it, but it is clear that it has inspired many other countries in the world. We have been active in ensuring that it does so in our bilateral contacts and cooperation with third countries. We want as many countries as possible to follow. We have also been very active in developing alternatives to animal testing within the EU, and again we are promoting the acceptance and uptake outside the EU, notably through the OECD. But I have to say again, sadly, that not all of our main trading partners have followed us. We should think about what this means for the treatment of cosmetics imported into the EU. The question is first of all that of enforcement of the ban by the national competent authorities. In practice, the main way of checking compliance of individual cosmetics is the cosmetics products information file. This has to be kept for every cosmetic marketed within the EU. But of course it is clear from information that we received from Member States that this file is sometimes very incomplete.  Secondly, the Court of Justice recently confirmed that cosmetic products containing ingredients tested on animals outside the EU cannot be sold here in the European Union. The animal testing data obtained outside the EU cannot be relied on. The safety has to be proved using some alternatives, but there is of course no guarantee that cosmetics tested on animals outside the EU are not used by our European customers. This needs to change.  One solution could be a global ban. This is the reason why we will continue to support any initiative at international level to end animal testing in cosmetics. And our support will go in particular to any initiative by EU Member States proposing a UN resolution on this matter. The Commission will continue to promote the EU ban on animal testing in cosmetics through its international activities, both at bilateral and multilateral level.  We also considered proposing clauses on animal testing for future trade agreements whenever appropriate. Our ban is firmly in line with the WTO technical barrier to trade agreement. This specifies that technical regulations shall not be more trade restrictive than necessary to fulfil a legitimate objective. Animal life or health is mentioned as such a legitimate objective.  The agreement is also the guiding principle in the EU’s bilateral free trade agreements. So, it has to be said that five years after the EU animal testing ban became fully applicable, the time is ripe for global action. We are thinking carefully about how best to do this. A global ban is of course one option, but we will consider others, and I will keep you informed and involved as our thinking develops.

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I welcome Commissioner Bieńkowska’s commitment and intent, as she outlined just now, because in 2004 the EU banned animal testing for cosmetic products and five years later it banned animal testing for cosmetic ingredients. Since 2009, the marketing of any cosmetic products containing animal-tested ingredients has also been banned, so now it is time for the rest of the world to follow suit. Sadly, up to 80% of countries around the world still use animal testing and continue to allow for the marketing of animal-tested cosmetics. I am hopeful that this cruel and inhumane practice will be eliminated entirely by 2023. These EU prohibitions in recent years have been hugely significant for the promotion of animal welfare. As well as this, Europe’s cosmetic products market is the biggest in the world and provides approximately two million jobs at present. Evidently, the success of this market is achievable without sacrificing animal welfare, so we need to work with the Commission to get a worldwide ban.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office. I believe that we have an example here of where we can learn from Europe that we can be proud of. We have given industry and research long enough time — the previous speakers have said: the first move in 2004, and then a definitive general ban on marketing in 2013. This best practice shows that, together with industry, a lot can be achieved with research here. We have continued to secure our market, we can be sure that the products that reach consumers are products that are not harmful to health, and we have taken a major step towards animal welfare and animal welfare. I believe that this appeal to achieve a global ban on animal testing for cosmetics is an important one, because we may also be able to achieve pressure here for those products that are not yet covered by this regulation, namely those ingredients that can still be tested by animal testing today, because you can also find other applications in the field of pharmaceutics, in the field of detergents, etc. This means that perhaps we can really provide incentives here to ensure that these ingredients also fall under the ban in the future, because there are alternatives. I would ask you, as you have pointed out today, to work to ensure that these requirements are not softened, particularly through WTO rules. My appeal also goes to all those Members who are currently under discussion of international trade treaties for the European Union that this appeal should also be made there that international treaties in the European Union should apply in the future that there should be no animal testing of cosmetics in these countries. can be used. This is particularly true of China, because the reverse procedure is actually valid there at the moment. There animal testing of cosmetics must be carried out in order for these products to be authorised on the market.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, on behalf of the ECR Group. Close your eyes and imagine: guinea pigs spent hours in tight plastic tubes; mice, toxic substances by gastric tube, choking on their own vomit; rabbits instigating toxic substances in their eyes; swelling, extreme redness, painful burns and much more. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, animal testing is cruel — banned in cosmetics in Europe since 2013. They haven't disappeared yet — unfortunately. Ingredients of cosmetics can still be tested on animals through special rules. More than two million animals are still victims of the cosmetics industry, year after year. Globally, it looks no different. So far, only Israel and India have followed the European example and have banned animal testing for cosmetics. In most other countries — including the US — they are still allowed to be virtually mandatory — as mentioned earlier — they are in China. For us Europeans, we must be animal welfare missionaries and promote animal-free cosmetics worldwide. Let's start today, not tomorrow!

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Mr President, Madam Commissioner! The issue of cosmetics tests in animals is important and is very close to my heart, as it is a very clear example of how we humans continue to torment animals in a very pointless way. When I was 10 years old joined my first association. It was an association against agonizing animal testing, the right of animals, in Sweden. As a child, I had a very hard time understanding why and how to expose innocent monkeys, rabbits and guinea pigs to agonizing cosmetics tests for people to make up, especially when there are full-fledged options. I actually find it equally difficult today, 25 years later, to understand why we do this when we have new techniques and methods of testing cosmetics without distressing animal testing. That is why I, together with colleagues here today in the European Parliament, call for a global ban on these excruciating cosmetics tests in animals. In the EU, cosmetics tests on animals are banned since 2013, but some products from outside the EU can still be bought here. These products may have been tested on animals, as 80% of the world's countries still allow this. It is time for a global ban on distressing cosmetics tests on animals.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Mr President, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Millions of animals are cruelly killed and tormented each year for cosmetics. European legislation, and even our ban on sales, does not prevent cosmetics from being tested on animals outside the EU and then reaches our internal market. The industry has long since outsourced its animal testing to non-EU countries, and it is not possible to check whether animal testing has been carried out or not. Unfortunately, this Parliament is mostly opposed to animal welfare for economic policy reasons. Tomorrow, you'll have a chance to take some of the charged debt. Please all agree with the resolution, because the citizens of Europe want by a large majority that no more animal testing takes place. So finally start defending the interests of citizens, not those of capital. A well-known philosopher once said: the deliberate mutilation of a living being into a bundle of suffering and silent despair is a crime. And what else would be a crime? We urgently need a UN resolution on a global ban on animal testing for cosmetics to stop these crimes. Commissioner, I'm counting on you!

name: Eleonora EVI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since 2009 in Europe we have prohibitions on animal testing in cosmetics and on the trade in tested cosmetic products and ingredients on animals: prohibitions that since 2013 have no exceptions (regardless of the availability of alternative methods), which should ensure the only circulation of cruelty-free cosmetics. I say “they should” because we know — and colleagues also reminded — how it is difficult to have a full application of this ban. There are many beams and loopholes that we see in the legislation, not least that of not often having a full count of the information of products from third countries or the ingredients that are tested and retested because they are also subject to other European regulations, such as REACH. This is, however, an important step forward which the European Union makes towards animal protection, but not only, in relation to different economic development, in relation to the protection of people's health. But now we must go further and support the conclusion of a global agreement to ban this practice, which is sadly used in 80% of the countries of the world. We have to listen to those millions of people who loudly ask us to work towards an international moratorium and these millions of people are also felt through, for example, petitions. There are a large number of petitions submitted to the European Parliament which recall and call for a global call for a global call. I think the European Parliament is ready, and it is strong and cohesive in calling for this. I hope that the Member States and the Commission will be ready in turn on the international stage to ban animal testing in cosmetics and to take a leading role in the negotiations that will come. I hope yes, so that the expectations of European citizens may soon find welcome.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, hungry, with their skin and eyes burned, thousands are condemned every year to terrible suffering in the dark basements of global scientific laboratories. Abuse which, despite Article 13 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, does not spare us. While 80% of states still allow these practices, which are mandatory for the importation of cosmetics into China, it is the REACH Regulation on chemicals that enabled the largest animal testing campaign in the world, sometimes in defiance of the 2009 ban on cosmetics. A scandal that violates both scientific progress in substitution methods, including the use of human cells, as well as the massive reprobation of world public opinion. With its political and economic preeminence, Europe must finally rhyme acts and words by guaranteeing absolute respect for animal welfare, a guarantee of the degree of civilisation of a human society.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, good evening to the Chamber and thank you for the opportunity to speak on this matter.  Asian countries are the principal offenders and they all can use their considerable economic might to defy this initiative, so how does the European Union perceive any action will be effective?  The second point I want to raise is that there has been no mention, so far as I can hear, of cosmeceuticals. This is a hybrid, if you like, of a cosmetic with a pharmaceutical product. There are many examples readily available on the market and that aspect also needs to be addressed with whatever is planned.  The third element, though, that I must highlight is that without the appropriate framework to ensure that compliance and record-keeping is mandatory, companies, academia, organisations, whatever they might be, are going to have very little motivation to ensure animal welfare is safeguarded unless, of course – and I agree with the previous speaker – there is an outright ban, particularly on companies that outsource their production to other countries.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: — Mr President, over the past five years the European Union has placed itself at the forefront of animal protection by banning the sale of animal tested cosmetics, generating a global movement and inspiring many nations to apply progressive rules in this area. The European Union ban on testing cosmetic products on animals has led to increased efforts by scientists and manufacturers to develop alternative tests necessary to verify the safety of cosmetic products. However, the step taken by the European Union in the ban on animal testing of cosmetic products is exceeded in importance by the present proposal on the global ban, which is the only guarantee that global animal testing will be put to an end. Given that four out of five countries still allow animal testing of cosmetic products, we need coherent, viable, immediate measures and action to ensure the development and marketing of non-tested animal cosmetics globally based on participation all the actors involved.

name: John FLACK
text: – Mr President, as a British Conservative I sometimes criticise the ambitions of this Parliament but on this occasion I am happy to praise them, just as many speakers before me, across the political divides, have done.  Some things are more important than party politics. For me, a key one is animal welfare. Care and compassion for our fellow creatures is surely the measure of our own humanity. The EU’s ban on cosmetic testing was truly groundbreaking. Although there are still some loopholes to tighten, I am proud to be part of a Parliament that is a true world leader on this issue. As co-sponsors, my European Conservatives and Reformists (ECR) Group is now asking for the EU to show even more global leadership. I cheer this to the rooftops. If you ask people across the world whether they want cosmetics tested on animals you get a resounding no, but it still continues because big manufacturers and retailers put profit before compassion, and because we politicians have not yet done enough to stop them. So we must demonstrate by our own actions, as well as telling the world, that testing for cosmetics is a most callous form of cruelty. People cannot even pretend that it is to prevent illness or to save lives; this is cruelty for vanity’s sake. It is time to really end it, once and for all, across the globe. Let us all vote tomorrow for beauty without cruelty.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Mr President, over 115 million animals worldwide are being misused for animal testing. In Europe, too, the number of animal experiments is still rising. As early as 2004, the European Union banned animal testing for make-up, creams, shampoos and other cosmetic products. Now, 15 years later, there are still products in the store that have been tested on animals. In Europe, for example, the chemicals legislation on REACH still gives scope to carry out animal testing. That is why it is important that the EU harmonise all these laws. In addition, it also circumvents the marketing ban to test cosmetics on animals outside Europe. So the animals don't really do anything with that. I think it is a very good plan to fight for a worldwide ban on animal testing, first for cosmetics, but then, of course, for other applications. For animals it does not matter at all under what law, under what exception or for which product they are killed in laboratories. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: — Mr President, injections of chemicals into the eyes, gavages and forced inhalations, experiments on animals in the field of cosmetics are often unsustainable and should no longer take place today. If the legislation in force is satisfactory in Europe, even if it is imperfect, it is not in the rest of the world, hence the idea I supported an international convention on this issue. Indeed, as coordinator in the ENVI committee, I had proposed to my colleagues to conduct a global reflection, not just on cosmetics. Indeed, the real progress made in the development of alternative methods for these cruel tests, including in the medical field, is proof that animal testing is not an obligation, as some sometimes want us to believe. However, one problem remains: the majority of ingredients used in cosmetic products are the same as those used in the manufacture of pharmaceuticals, detergents and sometimes even foodstuffs. However, in these specific cases, animal testing benefits from a legal framework with the tests authorised under the REACH regulation. It is therefore urgent to extend the problem further to animal testing in general. One example is that almost a year ago, a cosmetic brand, which voted against animal testing, yielded to pressure from an Asian market by allowing animal testing in that country. This is therefore an additional limit to the current framework when products tested on animals take place outside the European Union. The latter can no longer act hence, once again, the need for a global international convention.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: — For a debate to take place, it should be two positions. You all agree with each other here, so I will try to lift this burden and say something else. Above all, Parliament once again forgets that it is the Parliament of Europe, not the whole world. And that proselytism of yours is already really hard to withstand, hard to bear. Secondly, Parliament is not even a European Parliament, because it is a European value to convince the absolute superiority of man over animals, and what you cultivate here is far-reaching relativism. It is a scandal that in Europe in the 21st century, animals are better protected than unborn humans. What is a scandal is that you prefer that the first cosmetics tests take place on people. If we're talking about living organisms, people will test these cosmetics because you're afraid that mice will burn their muzzles. Also I think this is a scandal and is a betrayal against the centuries-old values of Europe.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I would follow up with my pre-speaker. I'm all for the protection of life in every form of it. An animal is a living creature and should not be mistreated. That is why I appreciate that the European Union has banned animal testing and I am proud that we, as the European Union, are in the position of a world leader on this issue. But the completely opposite role is filled by China, whose government even requires testing even on foreign preparations that have undergone reliable alternative testing. Since 2014, we have seen some improvements and limitations in testing, and non-profit organisations and cosmetic firms have played a significant role in this. These seek to change China's approach, for example, by supporting Chinese laboratories through training. Indeed, it is gratifying that where European Union rules do not reach, European firms that are aware of their social responsibility help.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, it is a fact that we all agree that the total ban on animal testing for cosmetics must be achieved. We consider the fact that this ban has almost been achieved in the European Union as a major achievement. Let us not forget that we have received too many petitions on this issue for years, so the steps taken at European Union level are in the right direction. But it is a question of how to impose the bans on third countries, because both China and Asian countries are allowed to test animals for the creation of cosmetics. So you will understand that the abuse of animals, the torture they are subjected to, and all this in order to produce cosmetics, is continuing globally. We therefore need an international crusade and initiatives on the part of the European Union on this issue.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, trade in cosmetic products and cosmetic ingredients previously applied to animals is prohibited in the European Union. This decision by the European Union is commendable because, in addition to protecting animals from the application of methods of torture and inhuman practices, it shows that there is a possibility of gradually reducing the production of cosmetics previously applied to animals. It also shows that there is a possibility to find alternatives. But reality obliges us to accept that worldwide in many countries and especially in third world countries this practice is applied to the production of cosmetics. That is why, in order not to leave the European Union's effort at a wishful point or at best an initiative in the right direction, the European Union must undertake a global campaign in order to ban the production of cosmetic products which have previously applied to animals.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Mr President, I very much welcome this debate, which clearly supports the initiative of the European Union institutions to talk and work towards a global ban on animal cosmetics testing. I think we need to be a world leader in animal protection. Animals as living entities deserve to be treated differently than mere things, and this is one of the themes but, Commissioner, it is not the only topic. There are a number of animal related issues in the European Union. The question of animal behavior on fur. We banned the so-called fur farms in the Czech Republic last year. It would be a good idea to do a Europe-wide ban on these disputed animal husbandry only because of human beauty, because of furs. There is a problem of transferring tens of thousands of puppies and kittens from the eastern part of the European Union to the western one. And so on. So please see animal themes as one of the important agendas of the European Union and let us work on that.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members – thank you very much for all your remarks. Firstly, I want to thank almost all of you for your engagement and compassion and I support you along and the Commission supports you. It has to be said that you have acted as a pioneer with the animal testing ban in the cosmetics industry, and we have inspired the other regions. As some of you mentioned, we can be proud of this, because we are the world leader on this issue. Firstly, I want to say that of course we admit that the others globally use animal testing, but we should act in two ways. The first one is that the Commission will continue to be active in promoting the EU animal testing ban in cosmetics at international level including trade agreements and we will continue of course to support any initiative in that direction at international level. Secondly, we will remain fully engaged in the development, validation and promotion of alternative methods – ‘alternative’ does not mean human testing: alternative methods means alternative methods, not animals nor humans – to support the promotion of the global ban. I believe that animal testing is a bad thing and we should do our best to avoid it.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for the opportunity to speak for the Council on this important issue. We will follow any developments at international level attentively, so we take pride in the positive developments we have reached for the internal market and we will certainly continue working together to defend European interests in all relevant fora, while being realistic on what can be expected from third countries. There is already a first-mover advantage for European Union producers with regard to production methods, but this will be just one of the arguments that would have to be raised once we discuss the possibility of a global ban with our trading partners. Thank you for your attention.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: A motion for a resolution has been tabled pursuant to Rule 128 (5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday, 3 May 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Romana TOMC
text: Written. — In 2013, a total ban on testing cosmetic products on animals came into force in the EU. We have a thriving and innovative cosmetic sector that provides around two million jobs and represents the largest market for cosmetic products in the world. The level of respect for current testing and marketing bans in Europe is very high. Some 80% of countries in the world, despite legislative progress in this area, still allow animal testing. I welcome the initiative on the need to call on the Presidents, as well as representatives of the EU institutions, to advocate a global ban on animal testing of cosmetic products at meetings with global organisations, in particular the UN Secretary-General. Persistent efforts in training and education are needed to ensure proper knowledge of alternatives and procedures in laboratories and competent authorities.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Mairead McGuinness, on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats), on improving safety on farms in the EU (O-000012/2018 - B8-0015/2018) - (2018/2668 (RSP).

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: author. – Mr President, I have been trying to get this on the agenda for quite some time, so I’m happy that at least there are a few of us interested and in the Chamber, because a lot of people depend on farmers and they’re probably out eating at the moment. I was particularly struck by one of our own farm safety specialists in Ireland, and I’ll read again the heading of an article which he contributed to where he said ‘Europe is being fed on the lives of 1,000 farmers every single year’, and he was angry because he also added that in Europe we know how many calves are born, we know about their welfare but we cannot tell how many farmers are killed every year, and he described that as a disgrace and I agree with him. It is true that far too many people on farms in my country and across the European Union are killed while going about their daily lives. It’s also true that many suffer terrible accidents on farms – children, men and women. It is a silent and hidden problem and it’s something that we need to lift the lid on. So I hope that this debate this evening is a start in that process. Commissioner we need a clear picture of what’s happening on all farms across Europe. I spoke about my own Member State, and the situation there is not good, but we don’t know with any great accuracy the level of fatalities and accidents. We hear anecdotal stories, but we need the facts and we need to ask why this is happening. Is there relentless pressure on farmers today that perhaps is intensified because they are more isolated and farming alone more than in the past? Long hours, sleeplessness, physical activity when people are tired all add to the stresses and strains. I know that recently we’ve had terrible weather conditions in many countries and that affects the physical well-being of farmers and their mental well-being, and when people are tired and emotionally drained accidents do and will happen. But there is another question that I think we need to address here this evening. We all talk about the family farm. It’s a romantic notion and we defend it and we want to contribute to its survival and we hold it dear, but we need to ask ourselves is the combination of family and farm part of the problem? I’m not advocating that we move away from the family farm model, but I think we do need to ask the hard questions that by not separating the business and the family we may be creating more difficulties around accidents and fatalities – it is a question that we need to discuss. Farms are now more intensive, there are fewer people working on them, and therefore one of the things I’ve tried to do when we talk about getting the facts on this situation is to get details into one of the files we’re working on integrated farm statistics. I think there’s a lot of resistance among Council and Member States to actually work together to get accurate statistics, counting the same things, and I would have thought it’s an issue that there should be some unity on, so perhaps the Commission could help us in that regard. I want to talk also about well-being and health generally, because in my own Member State there are some very disturbing figures around the high incidence of occupational injury and disease amongst farmers. They are a very high-risk group for lifestyle diseases and yet the image of farmers is that they work outdoors, it’s fresh air and it’s healthy, while in fact the reality for many farmers is that their health is not good and indeed in the research that I’ve looked at from the Irish researchers shows that farmers in my country have significantly higher mortality rates from cardiovascular disease, cancers and other causes of death compared with other occupational groups. So again those statistics are anything but comforting. When I talk to you about the pressures farmers are under – and Commissioner you know we talked about the European budget today, so it’s not a night to discuss it in detail – farmers will be anxious about pressures on their budgets. They will welcome your attempt to tackle unfair trading practices. I dare say there are many farmers who are looking at this massive merger that’s happening in the United Kingdom between Asda and Sainsbury’s and saying to themselves, ‘well that’s something to look forward to!’ This is part of the relentless pressure farmers are under: that massive merger will put some people ‘in the money’, as the gentleman sang when he was being interviewed, but it would be very bad for suppliers who expect to see a 10% cut in the prices they get. There is a link in all of this. You can push people very far and too far, and in my view the pressures in the food supply chain heap back on the producers and on farmers, that’s why we have the horror story of accidents and fatalities, and something’s got to be done about it.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, as you know I am taking this point on behalf of my colleague, Commissioner Thyssen. I am happy to do so because both Vice-President McGuinness and I are, unfortunately, only too familiar with the issue of farm safety and the devastating effect that loss of life and life-changing injuries can have on victims and their families. Before I deal with that issue, Ms McGuinness mentioned the announcement today of the budget. This was a proposal that has been in gestation for a considerable period of time and I think that the announcement today is certainly a very good attempt to mitigate the worst effects of what may have been proposed some months ago in relation to the budget. Organisations like Farm Europe were saying that there is a cut of 15% in the CAP budget, when it is actually 5%. It should be seen for what it is, fake news. We are all aware that farmers have to work in all weathers and all conditions. This year’s long winter and frequent storms have heightened the risk to farmers working in poor light and unsafe conditions. Commissioner Thyssen and I share your concerns that the number of accidents and fatalities on European farms is far too high. Indeed, in 2015, there were more than 500 fatal accidents in agriculture, forestry and fishing. This is nearly six fatal cases per 100 000 persons employed in these sectors, and this is precisely why the protection of occupational safety and health of workers, including farmers and others working in the agricultural sector, remains a high priority for this Commission. In this respect, the European Pillar of Social Rights emphasised the right of workers to a healthy, safe and well-adapted work environment. Over the years, the EU has developed a comprehensive acquis on Occupational Safety and Health (OSH), which applies to all economic sectors, including agriculture. For example, according to the EU directives, the employers have the obligation to determine and assess the risks of hazardous chemical agents used on farms, such as pesticides, cleaning agents, veterinary medicines, fuels and oils, and the risks related to whole-body vibrations when driving tractors. They also have the obligation to provide, if necessary, personal protective equipment, free of charge. The available data on accidents at work show that the application of the acquis on OSH has contributed to improving workers’ protection in the EU, including in the agricultural sector. For example, the number of fatal accidents in farming decreased by nearly a quarter between 2008 and 2015, in the EU28. This means 100 fatal cases less, albeit it’s still a very big number, and any death is a tragedy for their family and the statistics do not show that. Applying health and safety regulations is also beneficial for businesses. Studies show that the employer may have a double return on every euro spent on OSH. At the same time, we are conscious that implementing the EU health and safety rules would be something of a challenge for farmers and small enterprises in the agricultural sector. I also take note of the concern of Ms McGuinness that there might be an unacceptable level of farm accidents on farms with low incomes. Although there is no evidence to confirm this link at this stage, it is a point that is worth taking into account. We do know that there is a particular risk to part-time farmers who often have to check their stock when they come home from work and often in poor conditions. Our main priority is to help farmers and SMEs to meet their obligations under the EU acquis. I am aware that around one-third of the workforce in the farming sector is self-employed, including farmers, and that the EU OSH Directives are not applicable to them. This is why it is important that Member States take measures at national level to promote the safety and health of self-employed workers. I note with great interest your question as to whether we would propose to fund farm safety schemes in the context of the next CAP reform. The CAP is not necessarily the framework for setting rules on working conditions or occupational health and safety at work. I would be more than happy to see the CAP used to encourage greater farm safety and I am certainly open to any ideas on how the CAP could be a positive driver of change in this area. The second pillar of the CAP provides for on-farm investment which could be used for farm safety measures. Vice-President McGuinness will be aware, and other Members will also be interested to know, that the Irish Department of Agriculture included a farm safety scheme as part of its Targeted Agricultural Modernisation Scheme (TAMS, as we call it) under the Rural Development Programme. The objective was to improve the standard of safety on Irish farms by providing grant aid for a number of specified investments. Farmers could apply for grant aid of up to EUR 8000 per holding. As I said, and reflecting Commissioner Thyssen’s concern, the occupational safety and health of all EU workers, including farm safety across the EU, is a priority. In this sense, the 2017 Commission Communication on Safer and Healthier Work for All clearly indicates our key actions for improving and modernisation of our occupational safety and health legislation and policy: firstly, fighting occupational cancer, and this is relevant for the agricultural sector as well, in particular the updates to the Carcinogens and Mutagens Directive; secondly, supporting SMEs in complying with rules for occupational health and safety and, again, this applies to farms; and thirdly, ensuring better enforcement of the rules. These three actions aim at improving the safety and health of workers in the agricultural sector. Last, but not least, I would like to stress the importance of further developing the monitoring tools, as evidence-based policies require high quality, comparability and, as Ms McGuinness said, timely data. We need to get the Member States to give us more data in order to have a more coordinated approach at EU level on how we can tackle this issue. For that, we need to work closely with our Member States and our social partners to develop the tools and to improve the quality of the data. That is not there at the moment.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, without question, activities in the agricultural sector generate a high rate of incidents at work. Thus, according to Eurostat, more than 500 fatal accidents occurred in agriculture, forestry and fishing alone in 2015, which I find very serious. The performance of these activities in sometimes difficult to reach areas, in open spaces, in winds or in the heat of the sun limits the possibilities of intervention by specialist crews in case of need or in the event of accidents. Time factor, lack of qualified human resources and financial pressures cause farmers to intensify their activities, which very easily creates the premises for unacceptable accidents. Solitary work, lack of protective equipment, fatigue and stress are risk factors to which workers in these fields are exposed daily. To all this is added the lack of awareness, training and psychological counseling programs, as well as information on risks. Often, the life and health of those who provide for many banal liter of milk or kilogram of meat times of cheese are endangered by the extremely complex work on a farm. On the basis of these realities, the European Commission and the Member States must immediately start procedures to combat this phenomenon. I also believe that we need to pay greater attention to preparedness and prevention measures in these sectors, as well as to the introduction of awareness raising programmes on the safety of workers on agricultural holdings.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, agriculture is one of those with the most accidents, but also the most occupational diseases and early deaths. Cancers are the leading cause of death among farmers, especially cancers related to the use of chemicals. On this point, Commissioner, we must accompany the transition through dedicated means and abandon the use of these products of which farmers are the first victims as soon as possible. The second cause of death among farmers — and I would like, if I may, to take advantage of this debate to come back to this point — is suicide. This is the socio-professional category most at risk in this regard. Suicide excess mortality among farmers is 20 to 30 times higher than the population average. In France, a farmer's suicide is recorded every other day. In the last two years, nearly 300 farmers have died in my country. The lack of income and cash flow, often linked to malfunctioning markets, affects the psychological state of our farmers who are only asking to live from their jobs. We must, Commissioner, secure their income and therefore, to that end, guarantee prices. This requires, as you know, the implementation of market regulation tools. This is one of the major challenges of future reform.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I congratulate Mairead McGuinness on bringing this forward, and my Group is very happy to support her in bringing this forward. I think it is very timely and very good that we are debating this today, because for many, when an accident occurs on the farm, it leaves very long-term consequences and very sad families after it.  I have to say there is no easy solution to many of the problems that arise, but also, many are avoidable. Many of them actually happen during times when pressure is on, and the pressure can be on the farmer at times when he has to sow the seed, harvest the crops, do the ploughing, spread the slurry. That is when sometimes caution is thrown to the wind and that is when some mistakes happen. Where I come from in Northern Ireland we have a Stop and Think safety policy, and that is fine and good, but I believe we could do more. I think maybe the Commissioner might want to take this on board because when finance is short, corners are cut, and that is also a danger, so I think we should look maybe at Pillar 2 to see how we can actually give some help to this particular area, especially in slurry-related accidents which have been very prevalent in my region. I take Mr Andrieu’s point, and the suicide levels as well. These are all extremely worrying to people who work in farming. And the food supply chain – by continually pushing for margin reduction – has to ask how much more can they achieve. Yes, farmers must be more aware, more conscious and realistic of danger, but when you are under pressure to get it finished, the weather is changing, then they do throw caution to the wind at times.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Mr President, Commissioner. I would like to introduce you to our German agricultural social security system. We have health insurers, professional associations and retirement covenants, financed by the membership fees of farmers and by a federal subsidy. Unfortunately, accidents are also extremely high in our case: we have 1.5 million companies, and 150 000 accidents were registered and reported last year, of which, unfortunately, 138 fatal accidents at work, especially in the forest with tractors, but also animal accidents. The psychological stress is also increasing enormously in agriculture. And what do we do about it? We have indeed prepared a good prevention system with our social security institutions: we have prevention courses, we have partnership advice, more than 160 000 farm visits are held on site, and we have also created safety days for children in cooperation with farm women's work. All these are the things we desperately need. The most important thing is to enlighten and create good offers here. What can the EU level do? Perhaps we should actually query operational reliability in the multiple application. Unfortunately, animal welfare has a higher standard than human welfare. We could integrate that here. We have had EU guidelines on machinery safety since 2006. However, the agricultural machinery manufacturers are not strongly informed that this must also be brought in there. And we must consider whether we may not be able to make more safety on forest roads or forestry in the CAP under the second pillar. All these are important issues. I thank my colleague for putting this issue on the agenda today.

name: Thomas WAITZ
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. It's a dangerous occupation. We work with heavy animals, we work with heavy machinery, we work on the chainsaw. I raised three children with agricultural work. The question at the end of the day is: after seven, eight or nine hours on the chainsaw, can I move my machine because I can afford it because I earned enough money to feed my family? Several of our Members have pointed out that the point is that agricultural incomes must be designed in such a way that I can feed a family on it and do not have to work another ten, 11, 12 hours for me to afford this. That is the crucial question! Because when I'm tired and a tree falls on my head, the best safety equipment won't help me.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (PT) Mr President, we consider it very important to address here today the issue of the health and well-being of farmers and farmers in the development of their activities. Accident prevention measures must be implemented at work, but it is also necessary to recognise occupational diseases of farmers and farmers, and also to raise awareness of the risks of the use and handling of pesticides. We know that exposure to pesticides and other chemicals is regarded as the second cause of risk to the health of farmers and farmers. We therefore believe that, in addition to prevention of its use, it is necessary for the Commission and the Member States to carry out serious, rigorous and independent studies on the potential long-term effects on the health of exposed persons and their relationship with cancers, allergies and other diseases. We also consider it necessary to incorporate the gender approach into risk prevention measures in agricultural activity.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, one of the positive attributes of farmers is their ‘can do’ attitude in overcoming the challenges of limited weather opportunities or emergency machinery repairs. The obverse of this though is a recklessness in undertaking activities that could result in death or serious injury. The thought process is ‘I know what I’m doing, I have done it before, and it’s not going to affect anybody else’, and I have been guilty of this attitude personally – despite knowing two people who died in farm accidents, and two more who lost limbs. I’ve had some near misses myself, getting away with minor injuries instead. I see here a similarity with the attitude to drinking and driving held by most of my peer group in my youth. Over the years, social pressure has changed this attitude quite significantly, and social pressure could play a part in reducing farm accidents. For a self-employed, one—man—band farmer, the onus of this social pressure falls on his immediate family. Using the right psychology, a great deal could be achieved here. A family discussion about inviting a health and safety officer to come and visit the farm for a chat would send a very powerful message. Changing attitudes is the key to reducing most farm accidents, but money can play a part as well. The second highest cause of farm fatalities, with vehicle incidents as the first, is contact with aggressive livestock. If all cattle farms possessed top—of—the—range mobile handling and restraining equipment, I think farmers would use it. If a Pillar 2 grant was available to finance it and Member States brought in punitive penalties for failing to use it, then farmers would use it.  I also believe that EU legislation on chrysotile, or asbestos, is making matters worse.

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, the question asked about accidents affecting our farmers, however relevant and unfortunately tragic as it may be, must raise the overwhelming responsibilities of the Commission more generally. The Commission has been in government service for 25 years. She is the executor of the low works of globalist interests and, of course, those of the United States. By dismantling aid to our farmers, it responds to the globalist and American orders that aim to make them disappear. From the Mansholt plan to the so-called reformed CAP, the disappearance of our traditional and family farming is scheduled. The Commission is responsible and guilty of the mal-being of farmers, for accidents to their mass suicide — a suicide every two days, in my country France. While the Commission disappears within the framework of another Europe at the service of nations and in the first place of its peasants. Our farmers must live and live with dignity from the fruit of their hard work.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as reminded by yesterday's Labour Day celebrations, white deaths in Europe continue to be an unacceptable problem, even though more in the agricultural sector, where unfortunately the level of deaths at work is steadily increasing. As Vice-President McGuinness rightly pointed out, whom I thank, the measures implemented so far by the European Union and the Member States appear completely insufficient to counter a trend whose Causes are to be sought in the decline of agricultural profitability, which does not always allow an adjustment and technological modernization of mechanization. Our farmers need certain and properly funded policies that, together with better vocational training, support them to make all the necessary investments to carry out their activities in complete safety. In view of this, Commissioner, we hope that the debate which has begun today on the future financial framework — as well as the one now on the future CAP — will lead to a policy effective and really common that safeguards not only the environmental dimension but also that of job security on farms.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. First of all, I would like to thank Mrs Mairead McGuinness for the question on farm safety — an important issue also at European level. Nevertheless, let me add three points. First, the applicability. Whatever we are initiating new safety rules for the farm here — let us do this together with the farmers. They have the experience, they know where new regulations make sense. Second: the family at work. Consider that peasant farming happens at home. This means that family members, often children, are often victims of agricultural accidents. It is important to protect them in a special way. And thirdly: the resort of the farm. This is often the agricultural business and the holiday pleasure of the guests — also a source of danger that we should devote ourselves to in the course of these considerations. Let us work together to ensure that our farmers continue to do their service not only with full passion, but also in absolute safety!

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the occurrence of deadly incidents on farms requires a multi-fronted approach to avoid what is avoidable. The proportion of fatal accidents in agriculture is higher than in other areas of the economy. Prevention and training are key words. Financial incentives and fair prices are required to allow farmers to be properly remunerated for their activity. It is essential to create the conditions for proper maintenance of equipment and, on the other hand, to provide adequate information and raise awareness of the dangers of improper handling of agricultural machinery. Vocational training for farmers should be subject to appropriate incentives, with the priority being to promote good practice to ensure greater safety in the use of agricultural machinery and vehicles.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Mr President, I would like to support my colleagues and, in fact, all my speechwriters on this matter, because this issue, in my opinion, is extremely serious. It's about safety in farm farms and businesses in general. Accidents that put a strain on these operations are extremely dangerous and the traffic is really stressful. I was having a good time with a farmer who told me that he was stressed about his job and the weather, that it was raining or that it wasn't raining at all because there was a danger of drought and rains. Those people are really at the limit of their psychic possibilities, and I don't assess the health risks that arise from these dangerous operations. I think we can help them. It's not just the question of the European budget when they didn't get too good news today. I think it is about organizing mainly preventive programs and also using pressure, for example, on insurance companies to negotiate fair terms of premiums, because many times these are farmers face unfair action even from insurance companies.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I also want to congratulate the initiator of the question. It's a very serious thing. However, I would like to point out that we have shared responsibilities here. We have to be realistic. The Commission can't handle everything. It must work with the Member States. The Commission can think of policies and share positive experiences, can think of a funding system for education and training and accident preparedness, but must work with Member States in order to have funding programmes at national and European level on occupational safety. On the other hand, we are talking about accidents, but also about occupational diseases, and it takes a lot of information to know how to use the substances they use, how long they have to work, how to prevent certain illnesses and accidents, obviously through labor protection, which must done on a regular basis.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Hogan, allow me to congratulate Mrs McGuinness on her question, because it really addresses the serious issue of tackling farm safety in the European Union. Moreover, Eurostat data show that we have more than 500 fatal accidents in agriculture in 2015. This means that, despite the measures taken at a first level in the European Union, concrete efforts are needed. It needs training, it needs education, it needs funding for farm safety programmes in order to deal with the many accidents that occur. Many times, the children themselves are victims. We have seen farmers whose tractors are overrun and unfortunately die. In this context, concrete measures are therefore needed to ensure that agricultural holdings are safe.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, dealing with the wider agricultural sector since ancient times has still been a difficult, painful and dangerous activity for humans. Unfortunately, we are witnessing many fatal accidents which are mainly due to the lack of safety of facilities, the lack of high-tech means and the lack of information and training of those involved in these activities. If we add to this the deaths and diseases caused by difficult working conditions, accidents as well as the use of pesticides, we conclude that the European Union must take action, issue funding programmes for safety of facilities and also to create incentives for young people to be involved in agricultural work, particularly in southern Europe and Greece, which is damaged by the memorandum.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: — Mr. Chairman, I thank Mrs. McGuinness above all for her dedicated work and care for farmers that I personally share because we all need to be concerned about Eurostat data from 2015, which indicate that there have been more than 500 fatal accidents in the agriculture sector . Therefore, dealing with agriculture means that we are still in a dangerous business and that the measures taken at European Union level to improve safety at work are still insufficient and that we also need to find additional funding under national and European programmes. Long work, sleeplessness, emotional exhaustion, natural disasters, unfair trading practices, high interest on loans, all of this has, of course, an impact on farmers. If we know that about 300 farmers are killed annually in France because of a bad situation, then I have to congratulate Croatian farmers because in much worse conditions they fight and try to actually take a step forward; they are my true heroes.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Mr President, I wanted to take advantage of this very important debate in relation precisely also to the safety of agricultural vehicles. Because we all know that eCall has started and is currently being implemented and that Parliament has demanded that it also apply to agricultural vehicles. Because we often find that, as in road safety, the numbers have been declining in recent years, but accidents involving agricultural vehicles — in which the farmer is also far away, isolated or not easy to get help quickly — are often and unfortunately fatal accidents. Not to mention those in full road traffic, where, due to specific circumstances, they are also serious accidents. We would therefore like to call on the Commissioner precisely to encourage and promote as soon as possible that agricultural machinery, which is not high-priced and high-cost machinery, can be included as soon as possible.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to thank all Members for their contribution. The Members have made sincere interventions in relation to this report, which I think we will find very useful. I think I can conclude from the debate that we all share the same concerns for the occupational safety and health of all our EU workers, including our farmers and others working in the agricultural sector. And of course, as Mr Nicholson mentioned, income pressure, weather, all the risks associated with agriculture, contribute at various times towards putting additional pressure on our farmers and therefore it requires more care and attention in terms of how they farm and how they go about their business. As far as the Commission is concerned, we will continue to focus on the actions that we mentioned in the 2017 Occupational Safety and Health Communication, which includes the updated carcinogens directive. We will also continue to work closely with the Member States to support them in line with what Madam Grapini said – and I agree that the European Commission cannot do everything in relation to the rules and enforcement of trying to assist our farmers to actually farm more safely. That is not what has been said by most people with the exception of one speaker, Mr Colombier. The Member States and ourselves need to coordinate better, provide additional supports, and those supports are available under the pillar 2 at the moment – under the targeted measures that I mentioned under pillar 2 – but not every Member State programmes them. And perhaps in the legislative proposal that we are discussing at the moment, we could include this as a mandatory reason for the Member States to include in their strategic plan the need to look at the issue of farm safety in pillar 2. This may help to concentrate the minds of Member States in relation to the measures they need to propose to deal with this issue and the training that is required, as mentioned by Mr Agnew and others, in order to assist our farmers to be able to cope better and to understand better the need to not take the short cuts that they often do at times of pressure.  So, I want to thank all of the speakers that have contributed to this debate, and there is a willingness on my part to do whatever we can in the context of the CAP proposal.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the brief presentation of Esther Herranz García's report on the current situation and future prospects in the sheep and goat sectors in the Union (2017/2117 (INI)) (A8-0064/2018).

name: Esther HERRANZ GARCÍA
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the sheep sector in the European Union, despite employing 1.5 million people, has suffered the loss of 25 million cattle since the 1980s, and since 2001 we have lost production by more than 20%. Data on the consumption of sheep and goats are not much more encouraging, because in 2001 the average consumption was 3.5 kilograms per person, while in the last year the average was only 2 kilograms, with the young population having reduced their consumption the most. The report that I am presenting to you today and for which you have the honour of being the rapporteur highlights this situation and proposes a series of measures with which to try to reverse this negative trend. Undoubtedly a key element of the report is the recognition of the very important environmental work carried out by the sheep and, above all, goats, especially in its extensive modality, in terms of preserving biodiversity in many European regions. This contribution of public goods should be duly rewarded by the establishment of an environmental payment. This has been my main concern, and I am particularly pleased that it appears on the first point of this document, which we will be voting tomorrow. The report highlights the need to look for ways to improve the marketing of products from the sheep and goats sectors, by promoting consumption, especially in younger populations, and also encouraging new presentation formulas at points of sale that are more adapted to current consumption habits. Attacks on herds by large predators have been the subject that has aroused the most debate within the Committee on Agriculture because of the growing losses suffered by farmers, who are in a situation of clear helplessness in the face of this phenomenon. The increase in the populations of wolves, lynx, bears and other predators, as a result of the protection measures we have already introduced in the European Union, seems to have no limits and is increasingly becoming a major concern for European farmers. This report calls for the introduction, as I would say, certain elements of the Habitats Directive in a timely manner, with the aim of controlling and managing the excessive proliferation of predators, which has been observed in many European grazing areas. However, we do not intend to produce a complete revision of the Directive. Parliament also asked in this report that, in the negotiation of trade agreements with third countries, these sectors — sheep and goats — be considered as sensitive sectors. This demand is particularly relevant in the current negotiations with Australia and New Zealand. It would be appropriate to expect a study of the impact that Brexit is going to have on the European market, since about 48% of the current 287 000 tonnes quota benefiting New Zealand and 75% of the 19200 tonne quota granted to Australia are destined directly to the United Kingdom. The Commission should clearly maintain caution in negotiating these new agreements. In this regard, the European Parliament adopted its opinion on this issue in October last year, considering sheepmeat as a particularly sensitive element in these negotiations. Finally, I would like to tell you that, in global terms, this report is very positive for the sector, so I hope it will not have any problems tomorrow to be approved by a large majority in this House. I would also like to convey a strong message of support to livestock farmers and to thank the Commissioner for his sensitivity to this sector during this term.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: — Mr President, the development of the sheep and goat sector is an essential link in sustainable and efficient agriculture. Obviously, the main role of this sector is to provide quality and affordable products for European consumers and beyond. This sector's contribution to the prevention of climate change, floods, avalanches and forest fires, but also to employment in rural areas, is also essential. However, the sector is experiencing major difficulties, with the signals received from sheep farmers who have to shut down due to lack of labour, with many farms being liquidated or have reached the threshold of bankruptcy. It is therefore necessary to encourage association, increase the amount of coupled support granted to producer organisations in the sector, forms of support for the establishment of slaughter points and simplification of authorisation procedures by national authorities. They would make a significant contribution to increasing the access of producers to outlets, a prerequisite for survival.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I welcome the work we have been able to do with Mrs Herranz García on this issue of sheep and goats. These sectors play an essential role in preserving employment in difficult sectors, but also in the preservation of ecosystems and in preventing avalanches, floods and forest fires. At a time when the Commission is proposing unprecedented cuts in the agricultural budget, I would like to point out here that CAP support is extremely important for these sectors and for the development of our territories. Furthermore, I welcome the fact that this report raises the delicate issue of wolf predation, whose attacks are increasing. This scourge poses a real threat to the survival of livestock farms, especially those in open areas, practicing pastoralism. I ask our breeders to provide adequate compensation for the losses caused, but also for the trauma left by the attacks of these great predators. The Habitat Directive, which is now outdated, needs to be amended. Finally, I am pleased that my amendment which advocates the exclusion of the sheep and goat sectors from trade negotiations with third countries has been accepted. Our sectors must be defended and our territories protected.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, I consider the report we are debating to tackle the problems of sheep and goat farming to be important. Commissioner, Mr Hogan, I just called a friend of mine, a young farmer in Thessaly, and asked him what issues he would like to raise on what is being discussed here, and he said that he considered it important and necessary to reduce the cost of farming, since soya is imported from South Africa. America. He considers the embargo on Russia to be a big problem, because it cannot export. It considers food scandals and the low price of milk due to imports from Ukraine to be a major problem. Moreover, the fall in the price of feta cheese due to the distortion of the product. Another farmer from the Kozani region raises as a serious issue protection measures against predators, especially wolves and bears. So there are serious issues raised in the report we are debating.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, dealing with sheep and goats is a difficult but also important task, because it makes it possible to meet certain food requirements for the citizens of the European Union. Because these animals are vulnerable to both natural hazards and risks arising from predators and to various diseases, their numbers are reduced, and this leads to a reduction in the consumption of meat. A number of measures must therefore be taken, some of which are to protect the lives of sheep and goats against various diseases, mainly from animals imported from neighbouring countries, such as Turkey, Skopje and less Albania, for example, in the case of Greece, since as well as the protection of consumers and workers from the various trade agreements we have concluded with Australia, with New Zealand or with other countries.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: - Mr President, my colleague Herranz García has prepared an excellent report on the future of the EU sheep and goat sector, including almost all my amendments, such as authorising grazing in dry and poor-quality ecological focus areas, or the milk package a request to extend its financial support to sheep and goat's milk. I would now like to ask for the support of the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for a new motion: in the future EU agricultural policy, direct support should be provided only to livestock farmers who are on the permanent pasture for which direct aid is requested per hectare can be granted in the EU's future agricultural policy. keep at least 0,2 animal units of ruminants. Much could be done in the direction of restoring equilibrium in agriculture for the benefit of livestock farming. A farmer should avoid receiving EU aid if he only carries out annual compulsory mowing of his grassland.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: — Mr President, Commissioner Hogan, the sheep and goat sectors are the most vulnerable in livestock farming. That is why it is important to ensure that their sector has a viable future in the European Union, taking into account the undeniable added value in the field of the environment, helping to maintain biodiversity and landscapes, and to combat phenomena such as erosion soil. Let us also not forget the contribution to the development of economies in rural areas. Sheep is also an important role for the environment, with their help maintaining a large number of hectares of pasture in the European Union. Therefore, there is a need for more support in these sectors.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Ms Esther Herranz García for this report. There are two particular issues I want to raise – both of them surround the Brexit issue. The first one is around how we are going to allocate the tariff—rate quotas that come from New Zealand and Australia to the European Union, and maybe the Commissioner would respond to that, because that is a significant issue. As I understand it, the plans – such as they are – by the UK and the European Union on this issue are not acceptable to the countries involved. You might comment.  The second issue is also Brexit—related, because many of the lambs produced in Northern Ireland come to the Republic of Ireland for processing and then go to France for consumption. Clearly, we will have problems around that issue when Brexit happens, and we’re not clear as to the shape of Brexit around customs, around borders and around standards. Maybe the Commissioner could just reference that in his response.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I also want to congratulate the rapporteur. It's a very important subject. We have to think that there are areas, countries where livestock, goats and sheep farming is the basic profession. It is a source of gain for those inhabitants, which is why I appreciate that the rapporteur has touched on all the issues, including those related to market regulation, and perhaps the Commissioner is really telling us how we can protect the sheepmeat and goat producers in the European Union, given the decrease in '80 by 25 million head, in view of imports from third markets. I also think it is very important to achieve that value chain from pasture to processing meat and milk from the two animal species. So there are things to be done, and perhaps in the future agricultural policy you do not lose sight, Commissioner, to think about regulations for these two trades too: sheep and goat breeding.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, before I refer to Ms Herranz García’s report, can I say to my friend, Mr Andrieu, that the 5% cut in the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) budget today is not unprecedented, that is untrue, it’s actually fake news. You shouldn’t be looking at Farm Europe on the website because they are giving you the wrong information. I look forward to France being very strong supporters of getting Member States, particularly Denmark, the Netherlands, Sweden and Austria in unanimity in order to do more, so that we can reduce this particular impact on our farmers. I look forward to the leadership of France in this regard. Mr President, I want to thank the rapporteur, Ms Herranz García, for her report on the sheep and goat sector. This report rightly highlights the very specific features that are associated with this type of farming in the EU.
