Recognising the contribution of the sheep sector as well as its vulnerability, I established a sheepmeat forum in the autumn of 2015 to provide our stakeholders, together with my services, with the opportunity to discuss the challenges and opportunities that face the sector. Ms Herranz García’s report is another valuable contribution to the discussion about this important sector. The Commission shares the rapporteur’s view in regard to the importance of small ruminants, not only for producing a whole range of market goods like meat, milk, wool and skins, but also in relation to landscape conservation, the fight against countryside desertification and the preservation of our cultural heritage. Maintaining current production levels in sensitive sectors is one of the reasons why the CAP foresees the possibility for Member States to provide voluntary coupled support for the sheep sector. The report’s suggestion to increase this level of support has to be seen in the context of the proposals for the future CAP. Promotion is a key element for a product like sheepmeat that is comparatively more expensive than others. I have therefore decided that sustainable sheep and goat production is a priority for the 2018 Annual Work Programme of EU promotion for agricultural products and I have allocated EUR 2 million for national programmes and EUR 4 million for multi-Member State programmes, and these figures have been ring-fenced for promotion campaigns on the internal market, on the sustainable aspects of sheepmeat production. In an effort to improve market transparency, the Commission has established a dedicated sheep and goatmeat dashboard, which is published on its website. This gives regular market updates and provides stakeholders with information about the main market developments inside and outside the EU. Strengthening the farmers’ position in the food chain is also important. Since January 2018 the sector can benefit from new rules on producer cooperation that are contained in the Omnibus Regulation, but they also relate to public goods. The Omnibus has also played its part here in changing the definition in terms of permanent grassland and this will help some countries, in particular Spain, Portugal, Italy, Greece and the south of France. Unfair trading practices, of course, are also impactful on the meat sector, particularly the sheepmeat sector where operators are operating in a highly fragmented sector, such as this one. The Commission appreciates that the potential of the sheep sector could be heavily impacted by Brexit. In the sheep sector the UK plays a central role as a producer and also as an importer and in intra-European Union trade. The European Union and the UK, as Ms McGuinness has asked, have recently presented a proposal to the World Trade Organisation (WTO) to allow for the proportionality of the Tariff Rate Quotas (TRQs) to be shared out in line with what they are today. The first countries that actually objected to this were the United States, Australia and New Zealand, and these are supposed to be the best friends of the United Kingdom when it comes to a future trading relationship. If you have friends like that, it’s not easy to resolve these issues in relation to tariff rate quotas. Ms Herranz García’s report highlights the importance of the sheep and goat sector as a provider of public goods. Supporting it is in the interest of all of us. I welcome a report that will give, pardon the pun, food for thought. Once the Commission proposals for the CAP are tabled a greater focus on performance will no doubt be beneficial for the sheepmeat sector due to its specificities and fragility. I can assure you that the Commission will continue supporting the sector’s efforts to become more market-orientated and secure its long-term sustainability.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 3 May 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. — — This report aims to provide an overview of the situation and prospects of two fragile but very important sectors of livestock farming in Europe: the goat sector and the sheep sector. It is the result of collective work and I would like to commend the work of my colleague Esther Herranz Garcia. This report presents avenues and proposals for the development of the sector: better support under the CAP, promotion and segmentation of the market, increased use of supply management tools for quality cheeses with a request to extend these tools to meat, and derogations from competition law opened by the Regulation Omnibus. It also discusses the dangers facing the sector: Brexit with future New Zealand and Australian tariff quotas, and more broadly trade agreements on the one hand, and the issue of health and predator proliferation, which is increasing pressure on herds and our livestock producers on the other. These proposals are on the table. I hope that we will collectively complete these projects, particularly with the reform of the CAP as of June next year, for the development of these sectors.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: in writing. — Breeding of sheep and goats in the European Union constitutes an important traditional agricultural activity ensuring maintenance for thousands of producers and providing products of exceptional quality and specific characteristics, as well as derived products (meat, milk and wool). As the sector has suffered losses in recent years, the AGRI committee has been agreed that it deserves special attention. The report addresses a number of issues: grazing habits, threats from predators, health and welfare (including animal transport), products, electronic identification, carcass standardization, poor financial stability and low farm incomes, declining consumption, preparation and promotion of lamb. Competitive pressure on imports from third countries is also increasing. The rapporteur recognises the urgent need for action to ensure profitable and sustainable future production of sheepmeat and goat meat in Europe. It encourages the production of products of this origin and the attraction of new, young goat and sheep farmers. It also recommends maintaining this traditional and environmentally friendly farming activity. The rapporteur also calls for the creation of an EU Implementation Task Force to ensure that specific measures are adopted over the next two years, securing the future of the sheep and goat sectors in Europe. Bearing in mind the good of European agriculture, I vote in support of this report.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the brief presentation of Barbara Spinelli's report on media pluralism and freedom in the European Union (2017/2209 (INI)) (A8-0144/2018).

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: rapporteur. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Facebook and Cambridge Analytica scandal erupted when my report had already been completed, but the analyses and recommendations it contains do not change in substance. The scandal reinforces us even more in our regard: to defend and encourage the independence and pluralism of information, both on paper and online, and not to multiply the means of controlling it or even repress her. This is why we were cautious in dealing with the subject of fake news — remembering that these are not born with the Internet: they are, in my opinion, the fruit of group behavior, the so-called groupthink — that they plague and have plagued mainstream communication as well as online. The notion of fake news, as is written in the report, should not be used to exclude or criminalize critical voices. Internet misinformation has a viral and offensive nature that should not be underestimated and it is true that few giants of the Internet, outside the Union — Google, Facebook, Apple, Microsoft — wield power immense, control and selection of news, surveillance and user profiling. But censorship, especially if it is entrusted to the giants themselves, cannot be the answer. At the moment, the most serious analyses agree that neither fake news nor psychographic profiling of users, nor Cambridge Analytica — now finally closed — determined the outcome of the election American or French or the Brexit referendum. Accusing the algorithm is too convenient a loophole to avoid analyzing an election result. Removing the most dangerous content from the Internet, especially in cases of child pornography and terrorism, is an often necessary solution, but it cannot be entrusted to private companies, nor can it neglect the three principles of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights: necessity, proportionality, legitimacy. We asked that judging be independent bodies that at the same time ensure net neutrality and the protection of personal data. Still for the same reason, we express concern about libel laws, emphasizing the crippling effects they may have on the right to branch and receive information. At the same time, we recalled the key role of whistleblowers in safeguarding investigative journalism. In this framework we paid tribute to those who, as a journalist, paid their independence with their lives: to Daphne Caruana Galizia as to Ján Kuciak. The economic crisis, combining with the rise of online communication, has severely hit a key craft in democracies. The fourth power is now impoverished and the conditions of the investigator are so precarious that we can no longer really speak of an independent power, capable of avoiding self-censorship and dependence on others political, financial or advertising powers. This degradation is underlined in our report. Not all my conviction is reflected in the report, especially on the decriminalisation of the crime of defamation, on which an understanding has not been reached, but I thank the various groups, which have shown spirit of collaboration in drawing up this text.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The news has been spread that Cambridge Analytica has closed down just this evening or so. I am sorry, Mr Mamikins, but the rule has been established, so there are no blue cards.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr President, the report states that access to the media of minorities and local and regional communities is at risk. It also states that every citizen has the right to have independent information in his native language, whether the official language of the state or minority language, and therefore considers it important to provide training opportunities for journalists working in minority languages. In this regard, it calls on the Commission and the Member States to support initiatives targeting minority groups, such as traineeships for minority language media. We have to see that even print and digital media published in the official language of the state are in an extremely difficult situation today, but the operation of minority language media is impossibly impossible. While minority communities need their own media products more, as the prestige of a language without official status is even more violated in the absence of an independent media. This issue also demonstrates the need for the Commission to take a positive attitude towards the European citizens' initiative, which has been successfully collected 'Minority SafePack'.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mr Spinelli and my fellow shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation on the report, which, I believe, can be said to balance respect for freedom of the press and expression with security requirements arising primarily from the dissemination of illicit material online. The brutal killing of investigative journalists Ján Kuciak and his companion, and before that of Daphne Caruana Galizia, is a serious attack that harmits not only freedom of the press but also those acquired rights of freedom of expression and democracy which the Union has always protected and defended. It is therefore necessary to establish a European regulatory framework for the protection of whistleblowers and journalists of inquiry and, on the part of the States, the creation of independent bodies responsible for the protection of journalists and monitoring cases of violence and intimidation against their harm. If the Internet has amplified freedom of expression, it has given space for new dangers, including cyberbullying, terrorist propaganda or the dissemination of fake news, which the rapporteur mentioned. The well-being of information is a value that Western societies have acquired over time and which we have a duty to defend.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, ensuring pluralism and freedom of the media in the European Union is particularly important, especially now, as we approach the European elections. This means that political parties should have the right to participate in information broadcasts in the media, depending on the parliamentary power of the political groups here in the European Parliament, which is systematically ignored by the media in the European Parliament. Greece regarding the ECR and our movement “Greece - The Other Road” and attempt to silence us. Moreover, journalists need objectivity; to present the news and activities here in the European Parliament. Last week I asked President Macron a question about France's support for Greece in the event of a threat from Turkey, yet a significant proportion of media and correspondents tried to make the news disappear and to show that it was generally after by a question from a Member of the European Parliament. Shame!

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Mr President, media pluralism and media freedom is an important, even crucial, report. We have achieved to allocate adequate funding in the EU budget to support the media pluralism monitor and that’s very, very important and very good. As the rapporteur has stated we tackled very important topics like fake news, whistle-blowers, geo-blocking and licences, always defending freedom of expression which is the crucial and the central point of our concern. The result is not ideal, it is not ‘my’ report so to speak, but it is reasonably good and we accept it. I wish to pay homage to the rapporteur Barbara Spinelli. She presents a good and intelligent report. My group will support this report tomorrow.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, freedom of expression and information are basic human rights and cornerstones of a democratic state. The main actors of this self-evident reality are journalists. Journalists, because they criticize each authority, often become the subject of pressure, extortion and often pay for that attitude with his own life. It is for this reason that I strongly condemn any State interference in the operation of objective and fair information to the citizen. After all, the party I belong to, the third most powerful political party in Greece, is a victim of this unacceptable philosophy and practice. On the other hand, journalists must also exercise their duties consistently, objectively and not guide public opinion according to various interests.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I think that the problem of independent media is really crucial to our democracy and the role of independent and impartial media is irreplaceable in democracy. It's such a role of blood circulation in a healthily functioning body. I would therefore like to support the rapporteur's report I consider her very good, and I would like to add to her one question that she does not mention too much, and that is a question of the risk of concentration of power, which manifests itself in the aspect of economic power, strength money, in the power of political, it means truly in that power to exercise your will, and precisely the risks of concurrent media ownership. Unfortunately, in the Czech Republic and not only in the Czech Republic, this is a high current problem, and it seems to me that without a relevant European initiative, we will fail to resolve this issue. That is, I don't call this often for new European rules, but it is on plurality and media freedom that I think an eventual European initiative would be very spot on.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education on media pluralism and media freedom recalls that public opinion is based upon a relationship of trust between citizens and media professionals, aimed at informing the public and fostering a culture of public accountability and transparency, for the purposes of general interest. In order to actively and effectively participate in public life and take part in political debates, citizens need to be properly and fully informed. They need to know that the media are providing them with impartial and trusted quality information. So, in the context of an increasing digitisation and alarming media concentration, this guarantee of trust and impartiality has been proven more and more difficult to ensure. So how can we make sure the changes in the media landscape take place in the interest of democracy and pluralism, and not the contrary? Well, I believe it is by ensuring that media literacy and education for citizenship, including e-citizenship, is at the top of the education agenda.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, dear Mrs Spinelli, I have thoroughly read your report and I think this is a good basis for discussion. Not to create anything to anyone and rather to open up topics that need to be opened today, such as fake news topics, such as the influence of certain foreign powers on democracy and on events in the member States of the European Union. But one thing intrigued me there because I miss quite a bit there. And that's a matter of accountability for journalists. Journalists, too, are responsible for what they write. And I think it's spot on that if they ever make a mistake, they should actually be trying to correct that mistake. And I think that's not emphasized enough in that report. I understand all the caucuses that are linked and that are directed against journalists. I understand the political pressure on journalists. That's what I think is well accounted for in that report. But on the other hand, we can also reflect on the experiences of some politicians who have been untruthfully soothed about something, and the journalist did not put it on the right measure.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr President! This report prepared in the framework of the work under the leadership of Mrs Spinelli shows well the difficulties of our policy. Very often, when we take on a significant problem, we quickly clash with such iron-clad political or ideological barriers. Why, please, in this report we do not talk about the situation of the Central European nations liberated from communism, especially in the nineties, but also long after, when millions of people did not, did not really hear their voice in the media and it was necessary to engage the authorities public in the promotion of precisely pluralism, free speech? Is it because this is what is happening in Hungary today? Or how, speaking of free speech, can we keep quiet about introducing new forms of open censorship, like, for example, the regrettable law on the prohibition of publicist, journalistic obstruction of abortion in France? If we keep quiet about these forms of censorship, we will say nothing about freedom of speech.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I also want to congratulate the rapporteur. Obviously, it is a report that tried to remind us all that freedom of expression is a fundamental right and not only of journalists, of any citizen. Obviously, there must be a balance between the responsibility of the information we give. We are dealing with that fake news, as the rapporteur said, not only online, but also with false written information. However, I reply to my colleague who said that journalists' responsibility was not included, in point 2, the rapporteur stresses that a joint responsibility of legislators, journalists, publishers, media in general is needed. So there is a provision in Article 2, and it's good that it is so. Of course it is good to have neutral media monitoring institutions and, yes, it is overcentration of the media, and I believe that there needs to be further work on the internal level of the European Union.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: “We all agree that freedom of expression and opinion are basic human rights. Nevertheless, the report on this treatment is too long, contains redundant elements and has badly distributed accents. For example, it is referenced to the Istanbul Convention, which as many as a third of the Member States of the European Union have not joined, as read in the opinion of the minority. The text lacks condemnation of spreading totalitarian views in the media, particularly communism. It is not perceived that there has been world-view asymmetry in the media, especially countries in Central and Eastern Europe. Clearly less, and often in general, there is no Christian and Catholic media there. In Poland broadcasts the only nationwide Catholic television Trwam and Radio Maryja, which are permanently attacked. It must be pointed out that this is not a criticism, but a headstone using fake news, or a denigration, as the rapporteur said. Particularly on their founder from liberal media outgoing in Poland, but with foreign capital. Many concerned Polish citizens write complaints to the Ministry of Justice on the matter, asking for intervention. It would be good for this problem to be seen in such a resolution as well.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am taking this point on behalf of my colleague Commissioner Gabriel, who unfortunately is not able to be here with you this evening. On her behalf I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Spinelli, as well as the shadow rapporteurs for drafting a report on such a very important topic. Media freedom and pluralism are pillars of modern democracies and prerequisites for an open and free democratic debate. They are also fundamental rights enshrined in Article 11(2) of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. We have seen that unfortunately the European Union is not immune from risks to media, freedom and pluralism. Recently two journalists were killed in the European Union for simply doing their job. These crimes have left the whole European Community deeply shocked and we must do our utmost to ensure that such tragic events do not happen. Last week Reporters Without Borders published its yearly Press Freedom Index, confirming the worrying trend that media freedom and pluralism is deteriorating in several EU Member States. While it is for Member States to guarantee media freedom and pluralism, the Commission is taking a number of measures to strengthen media freedom across the European Union within its competences. In legislative terms, it is likely that, once adopted, the revised audiovisual media services directive will include new provisions on the independence of regulators, on media literacy and on transparency of media ownership. All of these provisions are expected to have positive spillovers on the media environment within the European Union. I welcome the political agreement of the co-legislators achieved last week in this House. On the 23 April the Commission proposed new rules for the protection of whistle-blowers who are often valuable sources of information for journalists. Protecting them is therefore crucial for safeguarding the watchdog role of investigative journalism. Beyond the legislation, the Commission also acts as a facilitator. With the help of the European Parliament we fund independent projects which support journalists under threat, promote cross-border investigative journalism and provide financial support to the media freedom community. One of our main projects is the Media Pluralism Monitor. It is run by the University Institute of Florence and allows us to have an independent and in-depth analysis of the changing media landscapes in all the EU Member States. Others, such as the Index On Censorship or the International Press Institute, map and report violations of media freedom or provide legal support to journalists. We also need to counter the increase in polarisation and disinformation in online media and the resulting distortion of the democratic debate. Last week the Commission set forth its policy on this question, building on the results of the various consultations. The policy reflects the Commission’s commitment to improving European citizens’ access to unbiased, quality information online. This comprehensive approach to tackle disinformation seeks to be both inclusive and action-oriented in order to aid stakeholders to take immediate actions from July, to achieve a speedy reduction in the volume of online disinformation. I thank the European Parliament again for the high quality of this report and for the insightful views expressed by the Members. The Commission has only limited competence in the area of media freedom and pluralism, but it does however not turn a blind eye to the challenges of media freedom and pluralism and will continue to follow the situation in the Member States carefully. There is no doubt that Europe needs a strong, competitive, free and pluralistic media sector. Quality journalism and free media are the watchdogs of our societies. We must all collaborate to uphold and strengthen media freedom and pluralism, values that keep our democracies healthy and vibrant. In order to achieve this, there is still a lot of work to be done and it is very encouraging to see that all of us here share a common vision on these values we hold dear.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 3 May 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — The working conditions of journalists continue to worsen. They increase victims of intimidation, verbal and physical attacks, and increase killings. The Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, which calls on the states to take concrete measures, as well as ensuring full compliance with all standards of the pan-European organization on press freedom. To this situation, photographed by reports of the Council of Europe, should be added to the cases of murdered journalists, such as Jan Kuciak, a Slovak journalist, and Daphne Caruana Galizia, a Maltese journalist. I don't know if we are in the presence of a generalized attack on the free press in Europe as they claim in many months. Surely there are disturbing signs such as the many journalists under protection or protection by law enforcement according to data released by Reporters sans Frontières's latest report on freedom of print. We must strongly reiterate that freedom of opinion is a fundamental principle for the EU and practices such as pressures and threats to information operators must be fought by all means.

name: Damian DRĂGHICI
text: in writing. — The increasingly easy and rapid access to a broader and diverse range of information makes the role of media in meeting contemporary democratic, cultural and social standards more important than ever. With its motion for a resolution on media pluralism and freedom in the EU, the European Parliament addresses the problem issues in the current media (excessive concentration of property, “fake news “phenomenon, violence against journalists, online abuses, etc.) and proposes to the European Commission and the Member States a series of measures for authentic media freedom and diversification. In an increasingly complex and interconnected media environment, the discerning use of information and new possibilities of expression is essential. That is why I believe that, both at Union and Member State level, special attention must be paid to quality media education, addressed from a lifelong learning perspective and accessible to all citizens, including the elderly and those in vulnerable or disadvantaged groups.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: in writing. — Dear colleagues, Tomorrow we celebrate World Press Freedom Day, at a time when freedom of expression and freedom of the press are threatened in Europe and around the world. We have recently seen how the spread of 'fake news' has created a 'hybrid war' against the Union's values. This is one of today's great challenges. This report therefore highlights the need to promote well-informed public opinion and ensure that journalists can carry out their work without external political pressure. By ensuring the independence and transparency of the media, we can safeguard the proper functioning of democracy and prevent it from being used as a vehicle of propaganda and indoctrination. I would also like to add a comment about the role that science can play together with journalism, as both share a common goal: to reveal the truth for the benefit of public opinion. Therefore, I consider it important to formulate evidence-based policies as a tool to prevent and combat the spread of fake news on the European political agenda.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – Media freedom is a fundamental right in the European Union. Media is the most important source of information and an important factor enhancing European democracy by encouraging public opinion. Sadly, the recent events of assassination of two investigative journalists in Malta and Slovakia clearly sends a message that media pluralism in the EU is in danger. So as our democracy, because without independent media we cannot expect to foster our democratic values. That is why Member States have to create and maintain a safe and secure environment for journalists. Strong legislative basis to protect journalist against the political and commercial influence is necessary. We have to send a clear message that media freedom is protected in the EU.

name: Julia PITERA
text: in writing. — In December 2014, a monitoring report carried out at the behest of the KE in 9 Member States by the Centre for Media Pluralism and Media Freedom was published. At the time, the 9 countries surveyed found risks arising from concentration, lack of transparency and ownership structure. Earlier, in 2013, the A free and pluralistic media to sustain European democracy report was published. In this report, in turn, the authors saw barriers and obstacles of both political and economic nature, commercial pressures, and the impact on the media systems of new media that destabilise guarantees of freedom and pluralism in member countries. Perhaps these aspects, especially political ones, led to the situation that the 2018 Reporters Without Borders report saw a significant decline in positions in some new EU countries (for Poland there was a decrease of four items compared only to 2017, Hungary by two positions, in Slovakia by ten positions, and in the Czech Republic by eleven positions). While the main responsibility for creating and maintaining media freedom and pluralism lies with the Member States, the EU itself can play a positive role in this process. The Union should, above all, protect fundamental rights and democracy in a situation where there is a threat in one or more of the Member States.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: in writing. — The problem of fake news, i.e. misleading or false news, deliberately disseminated, has become more pronounced in the digital age. While the new digital environment has made things worse, it is not a phenomenon created by social media. Over the decades, traditional media houses have also been guilty of biased and coloured news coverage. A surprising novelty in the world of many kinds of fake news and propaganda are fake nonfiction books. It is astonishing that one has been published by the reputable Finnish Kustestock company Tammi in spring 2018. The dissemination of intentional and false information as truth takes away the credibility of the disseminating media, be it an online magazine, a traditional newspaper or a cost-share company. Organizations sharing information, whether operating them online or in traditional ways, should commit to the disclosure of information based on evidence. Ethics rules for suppliers and cost suppliers should include an obligation to certify data and sources of information. Presenting false accusations or misleading information can have far-reaching consequences, and corrections made to them rarely achieve high visibility. Access to quality, free and independent information is a fundamental right. Citizens should have access to reliable information through the media. The media literacy of the people must also be promoted, and I support efforts to do so.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. — Freedom of expression and information is recognised internationally as one of the essential elements of the architecture of human rights and fundamental freedoms. At the same time, freedom of the press and freedom of expression are guarantees of the health of a democracy. I am deeply concerned about the restriction of the expression of some journalists of the Romanian Television and I strongly condemn any act of intimidation of journalists from any corner of the world. I am in solidarity with Romanian journalists and demand that both the Romanian and European authorities ensure that the freedom of information is respected by the Romanian Television leadership. I call on the European Commission to be actively involved in guaranteeing freedom of the press not only outside the European Union, but also inside it.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: in writing. — Against the background of the data scandal in recent weeks, the European Parliament's debate on media pluralism and media freedom in the European Union is extremely relevant both for the naming of threats to media freedom and for the possible response to the situation. Among the threats identified in the resolution, I would highlight the dangers of fake news (fake news) as the brightest and perhaps the most relevant. Such news undermines trust both in the media itself and in the democratic principles of the state. Ensuring the objectivity and impartiality of the media is one of the fundamental aspirations. It can be implemented both by raising awareness and critical thinking of the media workers themselves, as well as the public itself, by checking sources of information, etc. By accepting the position of the drafters that pluralism is inseparable from democracy and freedom, and the right to inform is one of the fundamental rights and freedoms, I believe that the strengthening of the independent media is necessary. In cooperation with media content creators, we must jointly create levers that allow all participants in the digital space to ensure the reliability of content and the impartiality of information. As guardians of the treaties, the European Commission plays an important role not only in ensuring the monitoring of media freedom in EU Member States, but also in shaping the highest criteria to ensure both media freedom and fundamental protection of human privacy and human dignity principles.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – The freedom of expression and information, media freedom and pluralism are fundamental values to the architecture of freedoms and human rights, enshrined in the European Charter of Fundamental Rights and in the European Convention of Human Rights. However, across Member States, journalists continue to be victims of attacks which include threats of violence, interferences of security and intelligence services, and pressures to disclose confidential materials and sources. All these pressures and interferences lead to magnifying the self-censorship phenomenon and enhances precariousness in the media sector. I fully support the call on the Commission that the EU takes legislative measures to protect, guarantee and promote media freedom, pluralism and the safety and security of professionals in the media sector. It is vital that the EU Member States carry out an annual monitoring of media freedom and pluralism, an assessment of transparency of ownership and conflicts of interest, such as political control over media outlets ownership. Member States must take measures against violent attempts on media freedom and independence in order to safeguard a pluralist media environment. Moreover, these mechanisms should be concrete and legally binding to ensure that Member States will guarantee a proper implementation of the Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: in writing. — Today marks the International Day of Freedom of the Press. Media freedom is a key part of democracy and EU values. Maintaining critical media literacy for EU citizens, quality journalism and free media are the best ways to combat fake news and propaganda. Respect for free speech is included in all EU policies and development programmes. Still, according to Reporters Without Borders's most recent Press Freedom Index, press freedom has weakened considerably in Europe recently. It is disgraceful that the index has several EU Member States in really poor (over 70th) positions when all EU countries should reach the top ten. There have been attacks on journalists and independent media in the EU recently. This is unacceptable. Under the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, the European Union is based on the values of democracy, human rights and the rule of law, as well as free and pluralistic media. Freedom of the press plays a critical role in promoting good governance, transparency and accountability. Independent journalism is needed to monitor democratic processes. The media must have the freedom to act without pressure and the threat of prior centennial. It is up to us politicians to defend media freedom even when the content of journalism does not appeal. Any violence against journalists and the kind of legislation, regulation and political pressure that limits freedom of opinion and expression must be brought to an end. Concrete steps need to be taken to prevent pressure and threat to journalists, bloggers and human rights defenders.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. — In adopting the Lisbon Treaty, the European Union has identified itself as a community of values whose cornerstone is human rights. Freedom of expression and information is recognized in the world as one of the fundamental elements of the structure of human rights and fundamental freedoms in modern society. Freedom of expression and pluralistic and independent media not only in themselves constitute human rights, but also play an essential social role, as tools of public oversight, providing citizens with protection against abuses arising from the realisation of the interests of the state or interests private and enabling them to actively participate in democratic life. Among the main threats to freedom of expression can be mentioned, among others, areas such as violence, threats and pressure on journalists — even nowadays in the Member States of the European Union, journalists are still the target of deadly attacks — the digital environment — undoubtedly have provided new and profoundly transformative tools of participatory democracy, expanding it revolutionary and providing citizens, who are hitherto users of information, with the opportunity to create them. The other side of the medal is the risk of misinformation, which is inherent in viral dissemination of online content, the difficulty of challenging and correcting it in a timely manner and scope, and the possibility of social media platforms and giants technological.

text: The next item is one-minute speeches on important political issues (Rule 163).

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: — Mr President, in mid-April, a meeting of the UN General Assembly was held in New York, which was also the issue of road safety. That this is a serious global problem is proved by statistics from the World Health Organization. Annually, I stress annually, due to road accidents, 1.25 million people die on roads worldwide and an estimated another up to 50 million people are injured, many of them suffering life imprisonment. The European Union is a world leader in transport safety, despite our goal of a 50 percent reduction in road accident deaths by 2020 compared to 2010 apparently will not be achieved and we are still from vision zero too far away. Therefore, in our efforts for safer roads not only in the European Union, we cannot be relieved. In a few days, the European Commission will unveil a new road safety framework for the next decade. We as Members and Members of the European Parliament will contribute significantly to its fulfillment, so it is necessary to encourage cooperation between Members not only in the European Union but around the world.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: — Recently, Prime Minister of the Free Country of Bavaria Markus Söder decided to suspend crosses in official buildings. In justification, he argues that the cross is a visible sign of admitting fundamental values, order, legal and social order in Bavaria and Germany, is a symbol of his country's identity. I think, not just him, but all the countries of the European Union. It would therefore be good to extend this initiative to the EU institutions, the European Parliament. Given that the leader of the largest political group — the EPP, which refers to Chadec traditions and values, is Manfred Weber, CSU MEP from Bavaria, I encourage him and expect him to come out with a similar proposal in Brussels and Strasbourg, which will be met not only with my strong support, but also many other Conservative MEPs.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, the Bulgarian initiative, the Western Balkans Summit in Sofia, almost failed because some Member States could not accept the idea of labelling the Western Balkan countries as states. So, a solution has to be found to name them as countries and as partners. This just shows how difficult and sensitive this enlargement process is. The problem is that ahead of us, there are much bigger issues. Money has to be invested in this project, the reasons for enlargement have to be explained to citizens, we have to shape and mould public opinion, Serbia and Montenegro have to finish their negotiations, Macedonia and Albania have to start them, Kosovo has to get visa liberalisation, Bosnia has to get responses to the questionnaire. If we do not put and invest everything that we have in that process, we will risk failure of the enlargement process and that would be a catastrophe, not just for the Western Balkans but even for the credibility of the European Union.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: Mr President, we are outraged. We women are outraged by the sentence of La Manada. Zero tolerance with sexist violence and solidarity with the victim. Social scream of Galician women, Spanish women, European women. The sentence is disappointing, humiliating, without humanity. The victim suffered is not an abuse: it is a rape, it is an open door to the permissiveness of violence. What are we going to tell our daughters? Because this sentence is a judgment of all of us, of all of us, and that is why Europe must be involved, because ethics oblige us to do so. That is also why the States must be forced to comply with the Istanbul Convention.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: Mr President, I would also like to draw attention to the great outrage we feel at a sentence that considers sexual abuse the brutal sexual violence exercised by the five men of La Manada against a young woman in Navarra. It wasn't abuse. It was rape. It is a sexist sentence, which strikes a hard blow to the rights of us, women, our right to feel free, to live without fear of being raped, to be sexually attacked. It was urgent to end the culture of rape and ensure a gender perspective in all those who have to enforce the laws. Justice professionals without training and gender perspectives cannot be allowed to address issues that are directly related to women. And I ask the Commission once again: when is a directive to combat violence against women?

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: — Mr President, the Paris demonstration on 1 May was spoiled by very serious violence. In fact, 1,200 hooded individuals ransacked Paris and confronted law enforcement forces with hammers and Molotov cocktails. These individuals belong to the “black bloc”, an anarchist movement born in Germany in the 1980s. The “black bloc” not only defies the French Republic by regularly ravaging cities, especially in my constituency, as in Nantes and Rennes, it defies the whole European Union and, beyond, the whole world. For example, 8,000 of its members ransacked Hamburg in July 2017, at the G20 summit. The European Union cannot remain silent in the face of the violence practiced by this far-left militia. If it wants to be worthy of the values it constantly claims, it must condemn the “black bloc”, but it is the States, solely responsible for security in their territory, that must act sovereignly as a last resort and dissolve this nihilist group.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, yesterday's Commission communication on the adequacy of pensions and the OECD guidelines for Greece in the so-called post-memorandum era show that there is no greater lie or anecdote than that the memoranda is coming to an end. The new bloody pension reductions following the formal expiry of the memorandum in August and the reduction of the duty free for the popular classes have already been legislated by the champion of unpopular demolitions, the government SYRIZA-ANEL. Considering the reform of the SYRIZA-ANEL Act, which sent pensions and the overwhelming majority of pensioners below the poverty line to Tartarus, the European Commission recommends an escalation of reforms. The OECD talks more specifically: another increase in the retirement age by four years; more flexibility in work; more tax robbery and social spending cuts. Exactly what the Association of Industrialists asked for yesterday: money for capital, poverty for the people who have no other way but organisation, rupture and overthrow.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Mr President, many of my amendments to the Herranz García report have been accepted by the rapporteur, and I think we have succeeded in bringing together a good report. However, I had a modifier that did not come in, so let me say this to the public. This is an amendment to rationalise the allocation of coupled aid in the sheep and goat sector. My goal was to pay for pet animals with fewer than 15 animal units, while larger professional sheep and goat farmers specifically for better access to the target markets, the stables to modernise or improve product quality, they would receive coupled support in the traditional way. I believe that this proposal would have been as beneficial to pet and pet farmers as well as breeders with large ruminants.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, yesterday morning I was proud to stand alongside the McStrikers on the picket line outside McDonalds in Cambridge. The young workers and trade unionists I spoke to told me that they are sick and tired of zero-hours contracts, insecurity and wages that do not pay the rent. Across Europe there have been McStrike protests in Belgium, Finland, France and Germany. We stand in solidarity.  And so, my message to CEO Steve Easterbrook, who hails originally from Watford – also in my constituency – is that your Big Macs would taste so much better if we knew that the workers who prepared them were getting a fair deal. Better working conditions, an end to zero-hours contracts, union recognition, a GBP 10 an hour minimum wage. Across the UK, across all of Europe, McDonalds workers are hungry for justice.

name: Marek JUREK
text: — The European Commission today announced a restriction on the budgetary rights of countries who would be charged that they violate the rule of law. Only that the European Union, as the Treaty on Union explicitly says, is formed by states that observe the rules of the rule of law. In order to conclude on the basis of the differences between us, that one of our countries is abrogating this, all countries in the European Council would have to be declared, and in order to conclude that such risks are occurring — at least 22 countries. The European Commission has no such rights, so what is it about? Firstly, we seem to be trying to raise budgetary funds at the expense of those countries whose policies do not like the current, but those whose term of office is still a year, to the authorities of the European Union. And secondly with trying to use financial instruments for political pressure. One and the other is outright denial of the principles of democracy the rule of law And the European Union authorities should step back from these threats as soon as possible.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: Mr President, I too would like to join my outraged voice with that of my colleagues who spoke before, to hundreds of thousands of Spaniards and to some international bodies which have clearly condemned that a very benevolent sentence has been given to an obvious case of rape, in which even a civil guard and a police. It seems to me that some Spanish judges have a serious problem with the concept of violence. When Catalan citizens were to vote peacefully on October 1, when the Catalan government took absolutely peaceful measures, they were accused of violent, and now that an absolutely violent and execrable gesture has occurred, this is not considered to be violence. With these judges, democracy really suffers, suffers seriously.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: — Mr President, in the previous two years Greece has achieved primary surpluses of more than the targets set. But this happened at the expense of the real economy, as Gross Domestic Product declined in 2016 and increased slightly in 2017. European lenders must realise that this policy they have enforced is a deadlock. No level of primary surpluses can make a government debt of 180% of a stagnant GDP manageable. The only way to make Greek public debt viable is to have strong growth rates in Greece. This requires a reduction in the burden of servicing public debt by lenders in order to reduce tax rates to more reasonable levels. Respect the sacrifices of the Greek people and give Greece a real chance!

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: — Mr President, as part of the co-chairmanship of the youth group, young MEPs here, I have developed an initiative that deals with the payment of internships, and I think that this is an issue that has not been and is not answered in the long term by the leadership of the European Parliament or the European institutions. A number of trainees are still working in European institutions for free, doing menial work, most of the time they arrange shopping for various officials or MEPs, and I want to see this situation alert. I think that a number of colleagues who laugh, in their offices, maybe it doesn't always work that way, and I think the complaints that come from the interns who describe their internships. so that during the internship they were so able to learn how to brew coffee well or bring parliamentarians lunch, I think speaks for everything.

name: Răzvan POPA
text: — Mr President, today the Commission presented the proposal for a budget for the future financial framework of the European Union. Although we are talking about a draft that starts negotiations and debates that will lead to a final formula of the post-2020 budget, I cannot fail to note the worrying signs that the Commission proposal brings. The challenges facing the European Union today cannot be faced by bringing a vision that weakens the European project. By reducing the amounts for cohesion policy, the most recently entered countries in the European Union, such as Romania, are directly exposed. The reduction of economic and social disparities depends fundamentally on European money, especially on cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy. Reducing funding in this area can only lead to a de facto division of the European Union on the basis of development. I believe that the draft presented by the Commission needs to be substantially improved. I appreciate the efforts to propose a draft budget, but I do not think that it fully corresponds to the development needs of the European Union. It is for European leaders, but also for Parliament as an institution representing citizens, to build a budget that does not affect the development of Member States, which does not result in faults within the Union.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Mr President, Facebook recently launched a pilot project on greater transparency in political advertising for the upcoming ‘Repeal the 8th’ Referendum in Ireland. It was nothing but window dressing, an attempt by Facebook to be seen to be doing something. Citizens have a right to know who is behind advertising campaigns and what data is being harvested from them. This week, websites targeting undecided voters with claims of providing unbiased facts have been found to be linked to the ‘no’ side in the referendum. Clicking on the adverts identified you as an undecided voter, vital information to have if you are an active player in the campaign. Once exposed, the website disappeared but it took with it a cachet of information on the identity of undecided voters, voters to target in the run-up to polling day. Ireland needs to get real on regulating social media platforms. It is not about shutting down debate, but we need equality of opportunity for all sides and transparency of electoral spend. We need onerous transparency obligations imposed on the social media platforms. If we do not, then we might as well hand over our democracy to Mark Zuckerberg.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, I just want to highlight the merger that was announced between two retail giants, Sainsbury and Asda in the United Kingdom, to create a mega retail company and there has been much reporting of this in the business papers saying it’s a wonderful thing. But there are many suppliers, not just in the United Kingdom but in Ireland and across Europe, who are terrified of this merger because the company plans to bring about a cut of 10% in the price of popular products and you can imagine who will take the hit for that 10% – it will be the suppliers and the producers and farmers. They will enjoy – and it is been described as never-before-seen – bargaining power, and in my view the bargaining power they will have is appalling. It is not something to be praised or warmly welcomed, it is something to be feared and I think that Commissioner Hogan is in the Chamber and is trying to tackle unfair trading practices and he might take note of this merger.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I want to talk about the rule of law, especially as President Juncker today said that we need a more stable, stronger Europe, a Europe and not more Europe. The conditionality that the Commission has presented today, linked to the rule of law and European funds, worries me, because I do not know what the instruments are. They did not present a definition. What does the rule of law mean? Each state, once entered the European Union, is considered to be a rule of law, has a constitution, has institutions, Parliament, institutions to verify the application of legislation. I believe that, in addition to not having this information, conditionality violates the Treaty of Lisbon, violates principles and values. It is not good, now, when the Euroscepticism after Brexit is growing, it is not good, before the elections, to come up with such messages. I am asked in my country why in France when windows are broken there is democracy, but in Romania when it comes out on the street it is said that there is no rule of law, that it was not voted correctly in Parliament. Who says whether or not it was voted in a fair national Parliament?

name: László TŐKÉS
text: — Mr President, while the EP Special Report on Hungary unfounded accuses the country of anti-Semitism and anti-Roma, on the contrary, the EU/EP regularly and biasively turns a blind eye to the systemic anti-Hungarianism in Romania. I protest against discrimination against the minority Hungarian community and the application of double standards! In 1959, the Hungarian Bolyai University of Cluj-Napoca was liquidated under the leadership of the later dictator Nicolae Ceauşescu. After sixty years, I am still haunted by the Romanian national communist past, when the nationalist rector Leonard Aramfirei wants to terminate the long-established Hungarian medical university in Târgu Mureş and merge it into a local Romanian university. We rightly expect the European institutions, including the European Parliament, to protect the Hungarians in Romania, our Hungarian institutions and the training of doctors in Transylvania.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, we often talk here about the deficit of democracy in the European Union. Usually, we speak about the European citizens; they do not want to take part in the European elections and blablabla. But 12% of the population of Latvia don’t have the possibility to vote in any elections. By this I mean people with the special status of former USSR citizens who are not citizens of Latvia or any other state; in short, non-citizens of Latvia. The Soviet Union collapsed more than a quarter of a century ago, but people with the official status of former USSR citizens still live and continue to be born in the European Union. Many of the non-citizens of Latvia were born in Latvia. They lived there for generations – for a quarter of a century in Latvia. These people could not vote in the local parliamentary or European Parliament elections. Dear colleagues, let us give them the possibility at least to vote in the European parliamentary elections.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Mr President, I wanted to draw the attention of the colleagues of the European Parliament, as well as the representatives of the Commission, that an international day will take place on the territory of most countries of the European Union on 14 June, which is intended to raise awareness of live animal transport, and we should not underestimate the subject. On the one hand, we create, and I very much welcome and support this, a single European market for the free movement of goods, and on the other hand, unfortunately, live slaughteranimals, which are often transported over a thousand-kilometer distance in very severe conditions. I think that the European Union should address this problem and we should think about some regulation in the future that will, in short, ensure that an animal that is driven thousands of kilometres to execute , for slaughter, so that it should therefore ensure conditions in which it will not suffer and will not be thus mistreated. So please June 14 should be an important day for us to obtain information about this phenomenon.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Mr President, we’re all aware of the violence perpetrated in Myanmar in Rakhine State. But I want to draw your attention to another conflict. The longest-running on-going civil war in the world is being fought in the same country and is being waged by the same military. The similarities between Kachin and Rakhine are obvious. 120 000 civilians have been displaced; the UN has received reports of military abuses, including killings, rape, abductions, torture and forced labour; and the military is blocking humanitarian aid to civilians. Myanmar’s neighbours must mediate talks for a resolution. A peacekeeping mission should be appointed to Kachin State. This is a military with unfettered power that targets ethnic minorities in violent campaigns. I applaud last week’s EU decision to adopt a legal framework for targeted sanctions against officials from the Myanmar armed forces for their human rights abuses. We have seen the result of the escalation of Myanmar’s human rights violations in Rakhine. It must not be allowed to be repeated in Kachin and there is every danger that it will be.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: — Mr President, I asked for the opportunity to speak because I want to draw attention to one serious systematic shortcoming in Parliament's work. It is going beyond competences and approving opinions, challenges and recommendations in areas falling within the competence of the Member States. In some committees, it is slowly impossible for me and some of my colleagues to vote in favour of initiative reports because they contain ideological requirements and recommendations on marriage law and family policy, health policy and moral-ethical issues that are within the exclusive competence of Member States. I would therefore like to call on Parliament's leadership to stop tolerating the lack of respect for the treaties in initiative reports and amendments, because it is such behaviour that leads to a loss of voters' confidence in Europe.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Mr President, first of all, I would like to express my great joy at the fact that I have been given the opportunity to speak as part of these speeches, however, for the third time at the end of the whole series, and I would therefore ask for some fairness in the distribution of the position within those thirty minutes. I wanted to talk about cohesion policy today. The proposal for a multiannual financial framework has been published today, and the cohesion policy does not come out entirely well. That's a finding of fact. In doing so, this policy should really be the heart of the European Union, their policies, because it eliminates disadvantage, reduces differences between regions, so I would like to burn for its strengthening and I would like to fire for its strengthening, primarily on the grounds that we have very dramatically depopulated rural areas and internal peripherals within the European Union. Europe functions as a sure funnel that sucks people, potential into its midst, leaving empty seats in its wake. Therefore, we should support mainly rural areas under agricultural and cohesion policies. It's a significant problem, 80% of Europe's population will live in Europe's biggest cities within ten years. This will indeed be a serious risk to our future.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The centrifugal force is always smallest at the centre.
